componenttext: Good morning. Welcome to Noble Energy's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. David Larson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued 2 news releases: One covering the fourth quarter and full-year earning; and the second one, laying out o
componenttext:
Thanks, Melanie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued 2 news releases: One covering the fourth quarter and full-year earning; and the second one, laying out our outlook for 2015. A few supplemental slides for this call were also posted to our website.
Following today's remarks by Dave Stover, we'll open the call for Q&A with the executive team, and hope to wrap things up in less than an hour. [Operator Instructions] 
Finally, I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as references to non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of these. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. I'll start out with a few highlights of Noble Energy's fourth quarter before focusing on our finance for 2015. From an execution perspective, it was an excellent quarter, where we delivered significant growth in
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. I'll start out with a few highlights of Noble Energy's fourth quarter before focusing on our finance for 2015. From an execution perspective, it was an excellent quarter, where we delivered significant growth in our U.S. onshore programs and progressed a number of deepwater development projects towards start up. Sales volumes averaged a record 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, a 14% increase versus the fourth quarter of 2013 after adjusting for asset sales. Highlighting our performance was our U.S. onshore horizontal volumes up more than 50%. We ended the year with total proved reserves of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent as production and noncore asset sales were offset by additions and revisions in our core areas. Over 90% of the reserve editions came from the execution of our low risk U.S. onshore program with the remaining coming from the Gulf of Mexico. We replaced 200% of our production in the U.S., even with pud bookings reflecting future growing activity based on the current price environment. 
On the financial side of the business, we remain highly focused on maintaining substantial liquidity, protecting our balance sheet and sustaining our investment grade rating. Late in 2014, we've proactively issued $1.5 billion in long-term notes at record low coupons for Noble, and ended the year with $5.2 billion in liquidity, including $1.2 billion in cash and $4 billion on our undrawn credit facility. Over the last 3 years, we've been very active in generating cash flow to the business through portfolio optimization, realizing over $2 billion in after-tax proceeds from noncore asset sales and our CONE MLP IPO. And I think it's important to mention that, looking forward, we will continue to seek additional ways to protect our financial strength and flexibility and monetize assets that we feel are undervalued. 
We've been very proactive in our hedging for 2015, with approximately 70% of global crude oil and 48% of U.S. natural gas hedged at attractive prices. Our Israel gas is also acting as a great natural hedge, an important contributor to our cash flow during the year, highlighting the benefits of our diverse portfolio. Obviously, everyone is focused on how the energy landscape has changed in the past several months. I believe the combination of our high-quality assets, deep drilling inventory, strong balance sheet and fiscal discipline have us well positioned, not only for the current year, but for the long-term as well. The key to our success and forward focus remains diversification, which has proven to be a competitive advantage in volatile markets. Our portfolio of opportunities around the world is well-balanced between liquids and domestic and international gas, includes thousands of drillable locations in 2 top-tier U.S. unconventional plays, both of which are well positioned on the industry cost of supply curve. These assets are essentially held by existing productions so we're not restricted in our ability to ramp up or down when appropriate. Offshore, our assets do not require large amounts of maintenance capital, that contributes significant cash flow to the business and provide running room for future growth. This combination of assets gives us a tremendous amount of optionality in how we allocate capital and manage risks. 
As we look at the uncertainty surrounding commodity prices and service costs, it is clear that now is not the time to push near-term production growth. The rapid decline in commodity prices has caused industry margins and project economics to be squeezed. With commodity prices at depressed levels, cost must find a new equilibrium with product prices before we resume investing for significant growth. The depth and duration of the current commodity cycle is unknown. So we believe starting 2015, with the capital budget of $2.9 billion, allows us to retain our financial strength and flexibility for an extended period of time. This program aligns us with the investment environment and cash flow, and we continue to be very disciplined in capital allocation and focused on cost management. 
We're intensely scrutinizing our cost and have already captured significant cost savings and reductions from our service providers. While these are primarily focused on achieving immediate cost reductions, we're also looking at the opportunity to implement some structural cost the changes that will have a long-term impact on margins and the efficiency of our business. 
Now let's walk through some of the details of our 2015 program. We've talked previously with many of you about the capital optionality in our portfolio, including the U.S. onshore program, major projects spendings and exploration as our primary levers in the allocation process. This year's program allocates approximately 60% of our CapEx to our core U.S. onshore and about 35% towards development of our offshore sanction major projects, which deliver substantial cash flows and value to the business. Exploration is set at around 5% of the budgets, although we're still testing a couple of varied material prospects that we're excited about. 
In the DJ Basin, we're coming off a year in which we delivered about 30% growth in our horizontal volumes and further advanced our understanding of the value upside from long laterals, downspacing and enhanced completion techniques. We're currently running a 4 rig program and have focused our activity in the Wells Ranch and East Pony development areas where we can drill a higher percentage of long laterals and can optimize the use of existing infrastructure. Total capital allocation to the basins this year is around $900 million. 
In 2015, we will continue to evaluate well performance from our 2014 downspacing test to assess incremental value in the basins above our standard 16-well-per-section development plan. We now have a high density test across all of our development areas, with early performance meeting and in certain areas, outperforming expectations. We're not anticipating a one-size-fits-all downspace program across our acreage. Additional production data collected this year will help fine-tune our understanding of high density spacing and ultimate recovery throughout the season. Early indications from downspacing continue to suggest that there's a huge price for us in the DJ. 
Our capital budget assumes a $4 million average well cost for standard length in Wells Ranch and East Pony which is down meaningfully from prior years. This has been achieved through supplier price reductions, use of existing infrastructure and sustainable efficiency improvements, much of which has already been captured to date. Our teams have been on the forefront of testing multiple completion methods in the DJ, and we continue to see evidence that our sliding sleeve design is the best value.  In 2015, we will continue to modify this design for optimal stage length and fluid type, both of which have the potential to reduce well cost even further. 
Another factor driving efficiency enhancement in our program is the ability to drill extended-reach laterals, which continue to deliver higher recovery and lower well cost per lateral foot. Approximately 50% of our 2015 wells will be extended reach. Overall, the program lateral length will average 6,500 feet per well, a 20% increase over last year. These are all components a very competitive, unconventional liquids play, and the economics, even at today's prices, remain very attractive, with before tax rates of return of approximately 40% and payout in under 2 years. We expect third-party infrastructure to improve in 2015. Beginning with the start up of the 70 Ranch Compressor Station, which commenced in the first quarter of this year. While  Lucerne-2 plant and Rocky Compressor Stations are progressing for start up in the second quarter providing necessary expansion of infrastructure in the northern Greater Wattenberg Area. In addition, we have recently committed to a third-party low-pressure gathering loop in Greater Wattenberg, which will have a positive impact to the overall operation of the field as early as the beginning of next year. 
On the operated side, we continue to build out our infrastructure in the basin and we'll investigate strategic opportunities to monetize these assets. In the Marcellus, total capital for 2015 is currently planned at $900 million with about 15% of the amount for midstream infrastructure. We're continuing to work with our partner on the optimal investment or 2015. This is not the time to be accelerating gas production, therefore, we have reduced Noble operated activity in the Marcellus to 2 rigs, while retaining the ability to accelerate drilling should that make sense for the future market. 
Performance in the Marcellus shows that this is a world-class asset. This being even further enhance with the completion such as reduced stage and cost for spacing. The RSCS design continues to outperform standard completion by approximately 30% on our operated wells, and we will continue to increase our use of this design in our 2015 program. Recently, gross daily production from the joint venture reached 1 billion cubic feet equivalent per day, with a major contributor growth in 2014 being down the wet Noble operated volume. 
As mentioned earlier, we're completing our sanctioned oil projects in the Gulf of Mexico. Our estimated Gulf of Mexico development budget is $600 million with 3 new fields to come on in the for next 15 months. The lineup of production includes Big Bend start up in fourth quarter; Dentler, which has moved up to around the end of 2015; followed by Gunflint by mid-2016. While these project don't have a meaningful impact on 2015 average production, they're certainly big contributors to our year-end and 2016 liquids rate. 
We're currently finishing completion operations of the Dentler #2 well and expect all drilling and completion operations in the Rio Grande area to be finished by mid-March. Remaining 2015 investment is focused on subsea pipeline installation at Big Ben and Dantzler, and drilling and completions operations at Gunflint. 
In West Africa, the majority of the development capital will be directed to the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which will create additional value by lowering decline and extending the life of the field. We plan to resume exploration in West Africa with the Cheetah prospect offshore Cameroon. Cheetah is an oil prospect with a 47% working interest targeting over 100 million barrels of gross resources and representing Noble's first cretaceous test in the Duala basin. 
Moving to the Eastern Mediterranean. Tool continues to perform exceptionally well, both from the reservoir and facility standpoint. These high demand and de-bottlenecking of the facilities has resulted recent record production days in excess of 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas and gross sales. 
I want to spend a couple of minutes discussing the regulatory environment in Israel. For over 15 years, we've been working with the government and people of Israel to explore for develop and produce natural gas. Our success has delivered substantial volume in Israel in terms of reduced fuel and electricity costs as well as new energy security. Early last year, Noble Energy, its partners and the Israel and antitrust authority reached an agreement for the consent decree that included the divestiture of the word gas fields in an effort to support competition of supply and move forward the development of word. The recent decision by the antitrust authority did not submit the agreed consent decree for final approval with a direct reversal of their prior agreement and another example of the uncertain regulatory environment in Israel. Now as a consequence, we have suspended essentially all investment in Israel, except for our Ashdod compression project which is nearly complete. Resolution of antitrust manner, along with progress on a number of additional regulatory matters, is required before we can proceed with significant further investment in Israel's energy sector. A predictable and stable regulatory environment is critical requirement in decisions related to major energy development projects. We continue to have discussions with the government in an effort to establish the regulatory framework necessary to progress development of these world class resources. While no agreement has been reached to date, we remain committed to finding appropriate and workable solutions. However, we're also prepared to vigorously defend our right related to our assets in Israel. 
It's worth remembering that Israel's only been producing gas for just over a decade. The discoveries of the giant and fields provide opportunity for substantial regional exports, which is changing the energy landscape of the Eastern Mediterranean. We're excited to be leading the way as further expansion of Tamar and initial development of LeVitus have the potential to material -- materially expand energy, economic and environmental benefits to Israel and the region. 
We were able to sign multiple LOIs for regional export in 2015. The most recent of these was an LOI with a customer in Egypt to supply interruptible volumes from Tamar. The terms of the LOI include up to 250 million cubic feet per day with pricing equivalent to other export LOIs that we signed. It's an opportunity that can have a near-term impact, requires very little capital and will provide relief from gas shortages in Egypt. We have not assumed any of these potential sales in our base guidance but are hopeful to commence exports this year, pending government approvals. 
To wrap up the Eastern Mediterranean, we continue to progress plans for development in Cyprus with our discovery there providing another option to meet growing regional demand. 
Our exploration investments this year company-wide will be about 5% of total planned expenditures. Lower than past years given the environment. While the budget is reduced, the program will test and underexplored area in the Falklands Island with multibillion barrel potential as well as our large prospect in Cameroon. We will use 2015 as an opportunity to further strengthen and enhance our exploration portfolio. I am confident that our best-in-class process and talented employees will continue to deliver exploration projects that will be a key contributor to the long-term growth of Noble Energy. 
As I mentioned earlier, now is not the time to be pushing near-term production growth. We have scaled our capital program back and expect modest growth of approximately 5% from 2014 driven primarily in the U.S. onshore business as well as Israel. In the U.S. onshore, we expect meaningful growth with more than 5% growth in the DJ Basin and 40% plus in the Marcellus. Natural gas sales from Tamar and Israel are expected to rise 10% or so year-over-year. Volumes are anticipated to be down about 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day year-on-year in West Africa, with approximately half of this amount being attributed to natural just field decline and the remaining from plant turnarounds. In the Gulf of Mexico, we anticipate flat to modest declines through the year until the Big Bend start up in the fourth quarter. While quarter-to-quarter volumes for us can vary quite a bit, contribution from our Gulf of Mexico development project sets us up well for 2016. In fact, excluding whatever Israel investment turns out to be, we can maintain an even slightly growth 2016 volumes at even lower capital levels than this year. It is this portfolio and diversity of projects that provides Noble a differential advantage going forward. 
For the first quarter of 2015, we expect sales volumes to range from 305,000 million to 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with the primary variance from the fourth quarter of last year being the timing of liquid listings and planned facility downtime in West Africa. Our U.S. onshore business post the DJ Basin and the Marcellus are anticipated to show growth, with Deepwater in Israel relatively flat. Due to uncertainty of the depths or duration of the present cycle, we believe the prudent approach to 2015 is to manage the spend more closely to cash flows. While this plan provides us with a more modest growth rate than we previously projected, our actions will continue to be focused on ensuring that we exit the current cycle with substantial operating and financial strength that will allow us to either resume a more accelerated pace of activity or pursue other opportunities that may arise. I believe this strategy is the appropriate course of action in a volatile market. Our U.S. onshore development, major project execution and exploration capabilities have us uniquely positioned to differentially outperform over the coming years. Now Melanie, at this time, I would like to go ahead and open the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, what I talked about in the inventory that we're drilling this year has about a 40% average return on that. So what we're focusing on our activity this year is in what we would consider our best economic areas, which are Wells Ranch and East Pony, and as I've mentioned, allows us to also take advantage of infrastructure up there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that. And just as a follow-up here. A number of your competitors have been delaying completion. Why not do the same? And also to follow up to that, coming into the year, what is your uncompleted backlog in both the DJ and the Marcellus?
componenttext: Appreciate that. And just as a follow-up here. A number of your competitors have been delaying completion. Why not do the same? And also to follow up to that, coming into the year, what is your uncompleted backlog in both the DJ and the Marcellus?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we had a number -- if you go back to what we talked about last year, we had a number of completions that will be coming on towards the end of the year and beginning of this year. What we've done is we looked at our inventory for this year and how we
componenttext: Well, we had a number -- if you go back to what we talked about last year, we had a number of completions that will be coming on towards the end of the year and beginning of this year. What we've done is we looked at our inventory for this year and how we've laid the program out for this year. We've actually set it up so we've spaced out our completions more through the year. Part of doing that was tailoring that to some of the discussions on what the suppliers and service companies that went along with how we implemented some of this cost reduction very quickly here into the beginning of the year. And part of that was also tailoring them to pace of the completions. So we've actually slowed down and tailored that completions to tie it in with what we have set up from a frac crude standpoint that went into the discussions on how we implemented some very quickly reductions and completion cost here at the beginning of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The DJ's really interesting, but I think you did a good job explaining what's going on there, Dave. I wonder if you could give us a little bit more detail on how your conversations are going on the Marcellus? And there's a language in your press release t
componenttext: The DJ's really interesting, but I think you did a good job explaining what's going on there, Dave. I wonder if you could give us a little bit more detail on how your conversations are going on the Marcellus? And there's a language in your press release that you're still working to figure out the plan for '15. And one other kind of wrinkle to it seems to me is that, it seems to me that actually because of the NGL pricing and some of the infrastructure problems up there, actually the dry gas areas seem to me to be more attractive right now, at least for 2015. And so could you work that into your discussion?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Charles, it's a good question. And one, we've continued to be in discussion with our partner up there on what is the right activity level. Now what they've got ability and right now reflect -- reflects probably a decrease of where we started last fal
componenttext: Yes. Charles, it's a good question. And one, we've continued to be in discussion with our partner up there on what is the right activity level. Now what they've got ability and right now reflect -- reflects probably a decrease of where we started last fall, when we started in this budget process. I'm not going to say it's an ongoing discussion to kind of optimize what the program should be. I think we're probably still on the camp that we could probably continue to push that down a little. And I think we'll see how that progresses over time. But it's a good healthy discussion, I think. In any good partnership, even if you aren't completely aligned upfront, the structure of a good partnership is you continue to have good discussion, and that's where it's going. I mean, we continue to bring down the program over time when you go back to last fall. So.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Would it be fair, Dave, that bringing the program down would be more on the non-op side for you guys than on operated?
componenttext: Got it. Would it be fair, Dave, that bringing the program down would be more on the non-op side for you guys than on operated?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we've already brought the operated side down, we brought that down to 2 rigs on the wet gas. I think the discussion now is continue to move around what is the right amount of activity level on the dry gas portion.
componenttext: Well, I mean, we've already brought the operated side down, we brought that down to 2 rigs on the wet gas. I think the discussion now is continue to move around what is the right amount of activity level on the dry gas portion.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And if I could ask a question about Cyprus. This may be too far field, but I thought I'd try. Given the hurdles have been thrown up in Israel, as I look at it, the idea in the Cyprus is not that far west of your word finding, and you're t
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And if I could ask a question about Cyprus. This may be too far field, but I thought I'd try. Given the hurdles have been thrown up in Israel, as I look at it, the idea in the Cyprus is not that far west of your word finding, and you're talking about doing some pipeline exports from Leviathan. So I wonder, is that a possibility to do pipeline exports from Cyprus now? And I'm thinking that you didn't quite had LNG facility but that was really before this regional export market popped up, and I'm wondering if the Cyprus find can plug into that possibility?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think we believe Cyprus can still play a role in that whole Eastern Med regional picture there. I mean, one of the things we're working with them on what will be development plan in Cyprus. As you mentioned, we kind of moved away from LNG projects a
componenttext: No. I think we believe Cyprus can still play a role in that whole Eastern Med regional picture there. I mean, one of the things we're working with them on what will be development plan in Cyprus. As you mentioned, we kind of moved away from LNG projects and probably more something that would be more of regional peace. I think the other thing I would mention and remind you to, when we talked about even the regional markets on what you we're looking at for our Israel volumes, as we were marketing that and looking at what the size of that market could be, we we're seeing a market that was potentially double the size of what we even we're having in those LOIs, so I think there's definitely a role to be played for additional gas there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Irene Haas with Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Irene Haas with Wunderlich Securities.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I may, I would like to ask you about your year-end resource bookings, it's a little flat. So I want to kind of pick your brains on how you have approached the puds. It sounds like you're taking a pretty conservative approach probably using something lo
componenttext: If I may, I would like to ask you about your year-end resource bookings, it's a little flat. So I want to kind of pick your brains on how you have approached the puds. It sounds like you're taking a pretty conservative approach probably using something low pricing. Then also, how did the events in Israel might or may not have impacted year end booking in 2014?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, on the first part of that, Irene, yes, we took the approach. We don't want to be in the position where you have, if this is an extended low-priced environment that you're having to bring reserves off the books. So we actually made sure, when we look
componenttext: Okay, on the first part of that, Irene, yes, we took the approach. We don't want to be in the position where you have, if this is an extended low-priced environment that you're having to bring reserves off the books. So we actually made sure, when we looked at our 5-year projection of activity levels, that we took into account the current environment without knowing when this current price environment would add. So we were looking at it more from the aspect of being in this environment for a while. So that influenced our onshore pud bookings. I think when you think about it from an Israel piece, the next big booking there will be with either some expansion at Tamar or sanctioning of Leviathan. And I think we all know, we still have some regulatory hurdles and things to get in place on Leviathan to get that assumption. So that will be the next big booking from Israel. So I guess, when you look at pud bookings and especially with this 5-year rule and whatever price you want to assume, it's kind of moved away from the puds representing any change in quality assets or anything, but more of how you're looking at tailoring your timing of your activity depending on what environment you want to project it through.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So you're really taking a very cautious approach, assuming sort of the worst and hoping that things won't turn out of that way, but regardless, your booking is pretty solid.
componenttext: Got you. So you're really taking a very cautious approach, assuming sort of the worst and hoping that things won't turn out of that way, but regardless, your booking is pretty solid.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And then it gives you the room for, as the environment turns up, you're adding to it.
componenttext: Absolutely. And then it gives you the room for, as the environment turns up, you're adding to it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to maybe just ask a little bit about your anticipated cash flow out spends in 2015? And you mentioned earlier in your comments that you could look to monetize assets that you feel are undervalued. So what's your intention to plug the cash flow ou
componenttext: I wanted to maybe just ask a little bit about your anticipated cash flow out spends in 2015? And you mentioned earlier in your comments that you could look to monetize assets that you feel are undervalued. So what's your intention to plug the cash flow outspend gap with those asset sales? And if so, kind of which assets would you be thinking about?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, obviously, anything we can do on some assets monetization helps with that. I think the real driver in how we've set up our program and what we're looking at this year is to move as quickly as we can regardless of those other kind of portfol
componenttext: Well, I think, obviously, anything we can do on some assets monetization helps with that. I think the real driver in how we've set up our program and what we're looking at this year is to move as quickly as we can regardless of those other kind of portfolio levers, as we've called them, to get our cash outflows more in line with our cash inflows. And with what we've set up and realizing it takes a little bit of time based on spending last year rolls into this year, that we expect, by mid-year, we should be in a good place on matching up our outflows and inflows. And then anything else, we can do with other portfolio things can just supplement that and keep us in an even better position.

So thought here that this costs, which are getting on the structural side would actually continue to stay low even if you see commodity prices rebound, and then potentially get service cost inflation picking back up again?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's great a great opportunity to make sure everybody's laser-focused on the efficiency part of the equation and what we're working on. I mean, we wanted the things we've put in motion a couple of years ago and talk about what kind of this I
componenttext: Well, I think it's great a great opportunity to make sure everybody's laser-focused on the efficiency part of the equation and what we're working on. I mean, we wanted the things we've put in motion a couple of years ago and talk about what kind of this Integrated Development Plans, and so forth, and then we what you're seeing is a large part of our drilling, for example, in the DJ this year is focused in areas where we can start to see more advantage of that. We're already seeing some advantage to that on capital savings coming from the result of our handling facility cost, water handling, and so forth. We're also seeing some of that impact on LOE, and that's a little bit of what I referenced when I talked about how we want to continue to embed more of these structural changes into how we go forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to David Tamrin with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go next to David Tamrin with Wells Fargo.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. And you've referenced this a number of times. But do we start to think about going forward if we look at the macro? One of your competitors put a slide out today saying at $65 oil, they can earn the same return as they did at $95 oi
componenttext: A couple of questions. And you've referenced this a number of times. But do we start to think about going forward if we look at the macro? One of your competitors put a slide out today saying at $65 oil, they can earn the same return as they did at $95 oil in 2012. Like how do you view internally? How much work cost reductions or efficiency do you need to get back to seeing the normalized $80 [ph] oil price environment a year ago now going now that number becomes $60, I'm just trying to get a framework about how you think the longer-term cost curve in the U.S.?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to consider and tell you to match the current certain price with certain cost reduction. I can say that the emphasis this year is starting to see more of this cost reduction you've seen folks talk about 10% to 20% reductions on cost because
componenttext: I'm not going to consider and tell you to match the current certain price with certain cost reduction. I can say that the emphasis this year is starting to see more of this cost reduction you've seen folks talk about 10% to 20% reductions on cost because they want to embed more reduction on LOE basis to some of this. So I just this cost focus this year as folks have moved away more from an activity focus as that was driven by growth, but now's a chance to step back a little bit and look very hard at the cost side of the business, the efficiency side of the business, how we optimize things. We'll see the ability to change the economics of different prices. By how much, we'll have to continue to watch as we go through the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Okay, all right. I guess for a follow up. If I think about your cash flow CapEx. I know there are some assets in the DJ that could be monetized from a midstream standpoint. componenttext: I like the first thing you look at is the nonproducing asset piece, and you kind of hit on one of that's high on our radar screen is the infrastructure in the DJ Basin. We took first step last year and what we did was our Marcellus infrastructure, and I think that's turned out to be a very nice business opportunity for us. So I think we'll continue to look at things like that. I think the infrastructure in the DJ wins itself. I mean, we continue to look around our growing infrastructure in the Gulf even for example. Who knows, but that's something else that we'll continue to look at. So there's various pieces of the business that still lends themselves to highlighting what their value can be and potentially unlocking some real value here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, I wanted to start off talking about the DJ. I know you guys in the some of the analyst meeting have talked about your view of the DJ kind of under a major project type of umbrella where you're introducing the IDPs. I'm just wondering, what the IDPs?
componenttext: Dave, I wanted to start off talking about the DJ. I know you guys in the some of the analyst meeting have talked about your view of the DJ kind of under a major project type of umbrella where you're introducing the IDPs. I'm just wondering, what the IDPs? And how nimble you can be in a down cycle given your development approach that you're taking there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I mean, the nice thing is we have a huge inventory and a large playing field out there when you think about the 600,000 acres or so. When we've talked about the IDPs and what we've implemented, we kind of started with Wells Ranch and then we've
componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, the nice thing is we have a huge inventory and a large playing field out there when you think about the 600,000 acres or so. When we've talked about the IDPs and what we've implemented, we kind of started with Wells Ranch and then we've been moving towards East Pony. So hand-in-hand with that is where we're going to concentrate this year's activity. So I think we have the ability to be pretty flexible. I think we've got the ability to adapt either way pretty quickly. I think -- in this environment, we probably won't do as much front-end loading of facility capital right now. I think what it does is probably move us back just slightly on when we will see some of these other IDPs bigger facility capital come in place. But I think it is a great time to benefit from this facility infrastructure that we've put in place and that we've already built. I think we're going to capture some tremendous benefits to that as we match our drilling program the where we have these facilities infrastructure in place this year.

componenttext: I think just the top of my head, I think in the DJ, it's probably about half, close to half of what we had in 2014. headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could just sneak one more in, Dave. I just wanted to get some details around Israel. Obviously, there's been a U-Turn in terms of the antitrust decision. What do you think drove that? And what are the potential -- what are the some of the remedies th
componenttext: If I could just sneak one more in, Dave. I just wanted to get some details around Israel. Obviously, there's been a U-Turn in terms of the antitrust decision. What do you think drove that? And what are the potential -- what are the some of the remedies the potentially seeking in terms of your assets there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, as far as remedies, I mean, we're in a lot of discussion with the government and the antitrust on this. I mean, as far as remedy, and what they're trying to accomplish, I mean their concern is about competition over there. And tha
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, as far as remedies, I mean, we're in a lot of discussion with the government and the antitrust on this. I mean, as far as remedy, and what they're trying to accomplish, I mean their concern is about competition over there. And that really was driven by the fact that when you go back in time, where the only ones that were really successful, and we were successful on a large scale over there. I think -- so where we are, and I think we were surprised, I think a lot of people over there were surprised with the reversal of that decision. And if you never focused on now and what that highlighted is the need to put together a comprehensive framework to provide some regulatory certainty and stability going forward, to make the investment decisions. I mean, when you go back to the discussions with the antitrust commission and where we've gotten to last year, we essentially agreed to and thought everybody had agreed to the resolution to that competition was selling word. When you think about that, Thinning in total, is about 3x the size of what Mary B was. And Mary B produced about 600 million a day for a number of years. So we thought that was a pretty good solution at that time. So right now, what have entered into the equation is a discussion now of, "Okay, so how do we move forward on this?" The good part of it is that it's throughout the ministries together to even better understand the situation and better understand even the importance of resolving this and resolving this quickly for the betterment of Israel and actually the whole region over there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Your comment on 2016 growth on lower CapEx was encouraging. One of the things we've been trying to think about is, I know you have deepwater projects that are coming online. But with the lower activity level in the Wattenberg, do you have a shallower base decline at an exit at '15 as opposed to where you're exiting '14 on a higher activity level?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean, Dave, based question to that is you've got a lower amount of new production coming on, so it lowers your delta on absolute volume coming off of this late. I think the other piece, and it points to our diversified asset base and why we t
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean, Dave, based question to that is you've got a lower amount of new production coming on, so it lowers your delta on absolute volume coming off of this late. I think the other piece, and it points to our diversified asset base and why we think that these especially strength in volatile price times. One of the decisions we made was to continue with the completion in the development of our Gulf of Mexico projects. That's going to add significant volume by the end of this year that gives us a year-on-year nice improvement out there for 2016. The other piece not to forget about is the Tamara volumes over there. And that continues to have growth potential based on in-country demand without additional investment. So I mean, that is a -- 2 pieces of our portfolio that we think are definitely differentiators is for us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the political landscape in Israel, clearly, has weighed on evaluation some. Thinking about where Israel is now with Tamara online, the revenues of the country generates, where does that go to whenever a planned Leviathan comes online, whenever
componenttext: And then on the political landscape in Israel, clearly, has weighed on evaluation some. Thinking about where Israel is now with Tamara online, the revenues of the country generates, where does that go to whenever a planned Leviathan comes online, whenever that may be at this point. But I'm just trying to think of how much of value it's created to kind of the nation of Israel? And what is the incentives that they're kind of thinking about from Leviathan development?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean there's a huge incentive for them to get these projects on. When you think that they actually capture over half of the value that comes from many volume of gas, whether it's sold in country or sold in export arrangement. If you remember on the
componenttext: Yes. I mean there's a huge incentive for them to get these projects on. When you think that they actually capture over half of the value that comes from many volume of gas, whether it's sold in country or sold in export arrangement. If you remember on the Leviathan, we're talking about a capacity -- facility capacity of 1.6 Bcf a day, and probably a run rate that will be closer in the 1 to 1.2 Bcf a day. A large part of that will be targeted from -- would be targeted to go to export with some portion for filling whatever's needed in the domestic demand. You think of that relative to the perspective of Tamar and what it's doing now, I mean we've seen the figures indicate, that's 1% of their GDP growth over there. So I mean it's a huge impact.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: When the export rules were passed, there were external study done by McKinnsey, and if I remember correctly, the delta value to the citizens in the GDP was $230 billion. So over the life of exports. And also, it was 20 more -- it was estimated to be 20 mo
componenttext: When the export rules were passed, there were external study done by McKinnsey, and if I remember correctly, the delta value to the citizens in the GDP was $230 billion. So over the life of exports. And also, it was 20 more -- it was estimated to be 20 more years more of domestic supply because of further exploration activity. So it's a material impact on the nation and to this industry.

componenttext: I think in this environment, we'd say that we'd monitor that as we go through the year. But I'd say, we just assumed this kind of level in the next year. componenttext: On Wattenberg, it looks like you have some line of the sites to some of the third-party midstream opportunities bottlenecks getting into place and online in the second quarter. Do you see this clearing the deck on midstream bottlenecks or others emerging? And should we see a step change in second half one production or is that just offset by reduced investment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at the bottlenecking portion, I think there's a lot of things, as we mentioned, Brian, that are going in place in the second quarter. There's also that what we call the grand parkway system, which is a big loop, if you will, to de-bo
componenttext: I think when you look at the bottlenecking portion, I think there's a lot of things, as we mentioned, Brian, that are going in place in the second quarter. There's also that what we call the grand parkway system, which is a big loop, if you will, to de-bottleneck and be more efficient on how gas is distributed around the field that will come into place towards the end of the year, beginning of the next year as when we'll really see the impact on that. So there's some staggered things that will be coming in place, and then you start to get into the next plan to beyond that. So I mean will continue to have to keep our eye on what else can be done as we move through the cycle here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: I mean, that's going to be have to be matched with the activity. I think when you think the company overall, I think the fourth quarter will probably be our, what we would say, foresee now probably be our highest volume quarter when you consider the influx that some Gulf of Mexico production.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really appreciate all the color on '15, and certainly understand the adjustments to CapEx, seems prudent, et cetera. In the past, you guys have given us longer dated plans that go as far as 5 years. Any ability to kind of update of that forecast for folks
componenttext: Really appreciate all the color on '15, and certainly understand the adjustments to CapEx, seems prudent, et cetera. In the past, you guys have given us longer dated plans that go as far as 5 years. Any ability to kind of update of that forecast for folks right now in terms of how we should think about building through the model? I know you're being super conservative with $50, $55 deck, but just trying to help triangulate the next several years.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we ought to be going out too far in this environment, Dave, because I think we've got to tailor that to what activity levels are you going to assume and how quickly you're going to ramp back up. I think what we wanted to do was give folks so
componenttext: I don't think we ought to be going out too far in this environment, Dave, because I think we've got to tailor that to what activity levels are you going to assume and how quickly you're going to ramp back up. I think what we wanted to do was give folks some perspective on how we see 2016 at certain level of investment that just given some comfort on how we can sustain ourselves and even still grow some in '16 at very low investment levels. I think starting to project beyond that is going to depend on where you start to ramp up, especially you're onshore programs. What I will say when you go back to that 5-year outlook, no, none of the resources in there have changed, at least, to the downside. If anything, what we've learned through our drilling programs that continues to put upward pressure on that. So the nice thing is that resources there. Now the timing and pace activity is going to be dependent on how we handle and how we match up with the financial aspect of it. That's going to be dependent on price environment and cost structure.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate this clarification. I know it's a difficult question, obviously, in the current environment. But maybe tying that a little bit to the financials and the current liquidity position. Essentially, it seems like your target or at least what you'r
componenttext: I appreciate this clarification. I know it's a difficult question, obviously, in the current environment. But maybe tying that a little bit to the financials and the current liquidity position. Essentially, it seems like your target or at least what you're communicating here is to just be pushing forward that liquidity position into '16, '17, when the environment does change so that you can wrap at that point given that the resource space is, as you just highlighted, actually increasing during this time period.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, when you think about it, we've got a wealth of inventory here. So it makes sense for us to maintain our liquidity such that when the time is right, we can move as rapidly as we want to move to start to capture this additional value. So I thin
componenttext: Yes. I mean, when you think about it, we've got a wealth of inventory here. So it makes sense for us to maintain our liquidity such that when the time is right, we can move as rapidly as we want to move to start to capture this additional value. So I think you've got to tie the financial management with the operational management. The thing I liked about our position is we've got a very strong financial position. We're committed to keeping it a strong financial position. We've got an inventory, huge inventory of opportunities, and we've got a great proficiency in onshore development, offshore development, exploration and major project execution. And we're going to continue to fine-tune and improve those efficiencies and proficiencies as we go. It's one of the nice things about even our program of this year. Even at these reduced capital level, we still are exposing ourselves to some very significant material exploration prospects even at this level. So we continue to keep that exploration proficiency going. We continue to move the major project proficiency along with these development in the Gulf of Mexico. So it's not like we've set any portion of our program and capabilities on the shelf.

componenttext: I was hoping you could follow up on what type of pricing we need to see here on the oil side and I guess the natural gas side for the Marcellus to where you start to see comfortable what activity increases? And could activity increases happen during 2015 if we saw a nice read down as we move into the second half, how quickly can Noble respond?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what we've talked about, Leo, is making sure that we're in a position that we can respond quickly. I think when that will be is open to interpretation at this point. But 2 things are going to play into effect is what the outlook on the commod
componenttext: Yes. I think what we've talked about, Leo, is making sure that we're in a position that we can respond quickly. I think when that will be is open to interpretation at this point. But 2 things are going to play into effect is what the outlook on the commodity price and how much cost are we seeing being able to pull out of the business that we feel we can sustain being out of the business and continue to keep out of it. And how does that world match up on commodity price and cost as we look forward. Our objective is to maintain our flexibility so that when the time is right, we can move very quickly.

Part of that whole discussion has been also -- it's not just us in that discussion, they've had to bring in, if you think about this in the way we've talked about our investment, our future investment in Israel, we've talked about ring fencing that about it being tied to financing and project financing and so forth. So that lends itself to where some of these folks who would potentially find in some this type of activity, the banks, and so forth, financial institutions around the world are also weighing in on what it takes to have a sustainable investment climate.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued 2 news releases: one covering the fourth quarter and full-year earnings; and the second one, laying out
componenttext:
Thanks, Melanie. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Noble Energy's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2014 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued 2 news releases: one covering the fourth quarter and full-year earnings; and the second one, laying out our outlook for 2015. A few supplemental slides for the call were also posted to our website.
Following today's remarks by Dave Stover, we'll open the call for Q&A with the executive team, and hope to wrap things up in less than an hour. [Operator Instructions]
Finally, I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as references non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of these. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. I'll start out with a few highlights of Noble Energy's fourth quarter before focusing on our plans for 2015. From an execution perspective, it was an excellent quarter, where we delivered significant growth in ou
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. I'll start out with a few highlights of Noble Energy's fourth quarter before focusing on our plans for 2015. From an execution perspective, it was an excellent quarter, where we delivered significant growth in our U.S. onshore programs and progressed a number of deepwater development projects towards start up. Sales volumes averaged a record 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, a 14% increase versus the fourth quarter of 2013 after adjusting for asset sales. Highlighting our performance was our U.S. onshore horizontal volumes, up more than 50%. 
We ended the year with total proved reserves of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent as production and non-core asset sales were offset by additions and revisions in our core areas. Over 90% of the reserve editions came from the execution of our low-risk U.S. onshore program, with the remaining coming from the Gulf of Mexico. We replaced 200% of our production in the U.S., even with pud bookings reflecting future drilling activity based on the current price environment. 
On the financial side of the business, we remain highly focused on maintaining substantial liquidity, protecting our balance sheet and sustaining our investment-grade rating. Late in 2014, we proactively issued $1.5 billion in long-term notes at record low coupons for Noble, and ended the year with $5.2 billion in liquidity, including $1.2 billion in cash and $4 billion on our undrawn credit facility. Over the last 3 years, we've been very active in generating cash flow to the business through portfolio optimization, realizing over $2 billion in after-tax proceeds from non-core asset sales and our CONE MLP IPO. And I think it's important to mention that looking forward, we will continue to seek additional ways to protect our financial strength and flexibility and monetize assets that we feel are undervalued. 
We've been very proactive in our hedging for 2015, with approximately 70% of global crude oil and 48% of U.S. natural gas hedged at attractive prices. Our Israel gas is also acting as a great natural hedge, an important contributor to our cash flow during the year, highlighting the benefits of our diverse portfolio. Obviously, everyone is focused on how the energy landscape has changed in the past several months. I believe the combination of our high-quality assets, deep drilling inventory, strong balance sheet and fiscal discipline have us well positioned, not only for the current year, but for the long-term as well. A key to our success and forward focus remains diversification, which has proven to be a competitive advantage in volatile markets. 
Our portfolio of opportunities around the world is well-balanced between liquids and domestic and international gas. It includes thousands of drillable locations and 2 top-tier U.S. unconventional plays, both of which are well positioned on the industry cost of supply curve. These assets are essentially held by existing productions, so we're not restricted in our ability to ramp up or down when appropriate. Offshore, our assets do not require large amounts of maintenance capital, but contributes significant cash flow to the business and provide running room for future growth. This combination of assets gives us a tremendous amount of optionality in how we allocate capital and manage risk.
As we look at the uncertainty surrounding commodity prices and service costs, it is clear that now is not the time to push near-term production growth. The rapid decline in commodity prices has caused industry margins and project economics to be squeezed. With commodity prices at depressed levels, cost must find a new equilibrium with product prices before we resume investing for significant growth. The depth and duration of the current commodity cycle is unknown. So we believe starting 2015 with a capital budget of $2.9 billion, allows us to retain our financial strength and flexibility for an extended period of time. This program aligns us with the investment environment and cash flow, and we continue to be very disciplined in capital allocation and focused on cost management.
We're intensely scrutinizing our cost and have already captured significant cost savings and reductions from our service providers. While these are primarily focused on achieving immediate cost reductions, we're also looking at the opportunity to implement some structural cost changes that will have a long-term impact on margins and the efficiency of our business. 
Now let's walk through some of the details of our 2015 program. We've talked previously with many of you about the capital optionality in our portfolio, including the U.S. onshore program, major project spending and exploration is our primary levers in the allocation process. This year's program allocates approximately 60% of our CapEx to our core U.S. onshore and about 35% toward development of our offshore sanction major projects, which deliver substantial cash flows and value to the business. Exploration is set at around 5% of the budget, although we're still testing a couple of very material prospects that we're excited about. 
In the DJ Basin, we're coming off a year in which we delivered about 30% growth in our horizontal volumes and further advanced our understanding of the value upside from long laterals, downspacing and enhanced completion techniques. We're currently running a 4-rig program and have focused our activity in the Wells Ranch and East Pony development areas, where we can drill a higher percentage of long laterals and can optimize the use of existing infrastructure. Total capital allocation to the basin this year is around $900 million. 
In 2015, we will continue to evaluate well performance from our 2014 downspacing test to assess incremental value in the basin above our standard 16-well-per-section development plan. We now have high-density test across all of our development areas, with early performance meeting and in certain areas, outperforming expectations. We're not anticipating a one-size-fits-all downspace program across our acreage. Additional production data collected this year will help fine-tune our understanding of high-density spacing and ultimate recovery throughout the basin. Early indications from downspacing continue to suggest there's a huge price for us in the DJ. 
Our capital budget assumes a $4 million average well cost for standard length in Wells Ranch and East Pony, which is down meaningfully from prior years. This is being achieved through supplier price reductions, use of existing infrastructure and sustainable efficiency improvements, much of which has already been captured to date. Our teams have been on the forefront of testing multiple completion methods in the DJ, and we continue to see evidence that our sliding sleeve design is the best value. In 2015, we will continue to modify this design for optimal stage length and fluid type, both of which have the potential to reduce well cost even further. 
Another factor driving efficiency enhancement in our program is the ability to drill extended-reach laterals, which continue to deliver higher recovery and lower well cost per lateral foot. Approximately 50% of our 2015 wells will be extended reach. Overall, the program lateral length will average 6,500 feet per well, a 20% increase over last year. These are all components of a very competitive, unconventional liquids play, and the economics, even at today's prices, remain very attractive, with before tax rates of return of approximately 40% and payout in under 2 years. We expect third-party infrastructure to improve in 2015. Beginning with the start up of the 70 Ranch Compressor Station, which commenced in the first quarter of this year. While  Lucerne II plant and Rockies and Trout Compressor Stations are progressing for start up in the second quarter, providing necessary expansion of infrastructure in the northern greater Wattenberg area. In addition, we have recently committed to a third-party low-pressure gathering loop in greater Wattenberg, which will have a positive impact to the overall operation of the field as early as the beginning of next year. 
On the operated side, we continue to build out our infrastructure in the basin and we'll investigate strategic opportunities to monetize these assets. In the Marcellus, total capital for 2015 was currently planned at $900 million, with about 15% of the amount for midstream infrastructure. We're continuing to work with our partner on the optimal investment for 2015. This is not the time to be accelerating gas production, therefore, we have reduced Noble-operated activity in the Marcellus to 2 rigs, while retaining the ability to accelerate drilling, should that make sense in the future market. 
Performance in the Marcellus shows that it is a world-class asset, and is being even further enhanced with completion such as reduced stage and cost for spacing. The RSCS design continues to outperform standard completion by approximately 30% on our operated wells, and we will continue to increase our use of this design in our 2015 program. Recently, gross daily production from the joint venture reached 1 billion cubic feet equivalent per day, with a major contributor growth in 2014 being the wet Noble operated volumes. 
As mentioned earlier, we're completing our sanctioned oil projects in the Gulf of Mexico. Our estimated Gulf of Mexico development budget is $600 million with 3 new fields to come on in the for next 15 months. The lineup of production includes Big Bend start up in fourth quarter; Dantzler, which has moved up to around the end of 2015; followed by Gunflint by mid-2016. While these projects don't have a meaningful impact on 2015 average production, they are certainly big contributors to our year-end and 2016 liquids rate. 
We're currently finishing completion operations of the Dantzler #2 well and expect all drilling and completion operations in the Rio Grande area to be finished by mid-March. Remaining 2015 investment is focused on subsea pipeline installation at Big Bend and Dantzler, and drilling and completions operations at Gunflint. 
In West Africa, the majority of the development capital will be directed to the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which will create additional value by lowering decline and extending the life of the field. We plan to resume exploration in West Africa with the Cheetah prospect offshore Cameroon. Cheetah is an oil prospect with a 47% working interest, targeting over 100 million barrels of gross resources and representing Noble's first cretaceous test in the Douala Basin. 
Moving to the Eastern Mediterranean. Tamar continues to perform exceptionally well, both from the reservoir and facility standpoint. These merely high demand and de-bottlenecking of the facilities has resulted recent record production days in excess of 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas and gross sales. 
I want to spend a couple of minutes discussing the regulatory environment in Israel. For over 15 years, we've been working with the government and people of Israel to explore for develop and produce natural gas. Our success has delivered substantial value to Israel in terms of reduced fuel and electricity costs as well as new energy security. Early last year, Noble Energy, its partners and the Israel Antitrust Authority reached an agreement for the consent decree that included the divestiture of the Tanin and Karish gas fields in an effort to support competition of supply and move forward the development of Leviathan. The recent decision by the Antitrust Authority did not submit the agreed consent decree for final approval, with a direct reversal of their prior agreement and another example of the uncertain regulatory environment in Israel. Now as a consequence, we have suspended essentially all investment in Israel, except for our Ashdod compression project, which is nearly complete. Resolution of the antitrust matter, along with progress on a number of additional regulatory matters, is required before we can proceed with significant further investment in Israel's energy sector. 
A predictable and stable regulatory environment is critical requirement in decisions related to major energy development projects. We continue to have discussions with the government in an effort to establish the regulatory framework necessary to progress development of these world class resources. While no agreement has been reached to date, we remain committed to finding appropriate and workable solutions. However, we are also prepared to vigorously defend our rights related to our assets in Israel.
It's worth remembering that Israel's only been producing gas for just over a decade. The discoveries of the giant Tamar and Leviathan fields provide the opportunity for the substantial regional exports, which is changing the energy landscape of the Eastern Mediterranean. We're excited to be leading the way as further expansion of Tamar and initial development of Leviathan have the potential to material expand -- materially expand energy, economic and environmental benefits to Israel and the region. 
We were able to sign multiple LOIs for regional export in 2014. The most recent of these was an LOI with a customer in Egypt to supply interruptible volumes from Tamar. The terms of the LOI include up to 250 million cubic feet per day, with pricing equivalent to other export LOIs that we signed. It's an opportunity that can have near-term impact, requires very little capital and would provide relief from gas shortages in Egypt. We have not assumed any of these potential sales in our base guidance, but are hopeful to commence exports this year, pending government approvals. To wrap up the Eastern Mediterranean, we continue to progress plans for development in Cyprus with our discovery there providing another option to meet growing regional demand. 
Our exploration investments this year, company-wide, will be about 5% of total planned expenditures, lower than past years given the environment. While the budget is reduced, the program will test an underexplored area in the Falkland Islands, with multibillion barrel potential, as well as our large prospect in Cameroon. We will use 2015 as an opportunity to further strengthen and enhance our exploration portfolio. I am confident that our best-in-class process and talented employees will continue to deliver exploration projects that will be a key contributor to the long-term growth of Noble Energy.
As I mentioned earlier, now is not the time to be pushing near-term production growth. We have scaled our capital program back and expect modest growth of approximately 5% from 2014 driven primarily in the U.S. onshore business as well as Israel. In the U.S. onshore, we expect meaningful growth with more than 5% growth in the DJ Basin and 40%-plus in the Marcellus. Natural gas sales from Tamar and Israel are expected to rise 10% or so year-over-year. 
Volumes are anticipated to be down about 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day year-on-year in West Africa, with approximately half of this amount being attributed to natural field decline and the remaining from plant turnarounds. In the Gulf of Mexico, we anticipate flat to modest declines through the year until the Big Bend start up in the fourth quarter. While quarter-to-quarter volumes for us can vary quite a bit, contribution from our Gulf of Mexico development project sets us up well for 2016. In fact, excluding whatever Israel investment turns out to be, we can maintain and even slightly growth 2016 volumes at even lower capital levels than this year. It is this portfolio and diversity of projects that provides Noble a differential advantage going forward. 
For the first quarter of 2015, we expect sales volumes to range from 305,000 to 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with the primary variance from the fourth quarter of last year being the timing of liquid liftings and planned facility downtime in West Africa. Our U.S. onshore business, post the DJ Basin and the Marcellus are anticipated to show growth, with Deepwater in Israel relatively flat. Due to uncertainty as to the depth or duration of the present cycle, we believe the prudent approach to 2015 is to manage the spend more closely to cash flows. While this plan provides us with a more modest growth rate than we previously projected, our actions will continue to be focused on ensuring that we exit the current cycle with substantial operating and financial strength that will allow us to either resume a more accelerated pace of activity or pursue other opportunities that may arise. 
I believe this strategy is the appropriate course of action in a volatile market. Our U.S. onshore development, major project execution and exploration capabilities have us uniquely positioned to differentially outperform over the coming years. Melanie, at this time, we'd like to go ahead and open the call for questions.

componenttext: Appreciate that. And just as a follow-up here. A number of your competitors have been delaying completion. Why not do the same? And also to follow up to that, coming into the year, what is your uncompleted backlog in both the DJ and the Marcellus?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we had a number -- if you go back to what we talked about last year, we had a number of completions that were coming on towards the end of the year and beginning of this year. What we've done is we looked at our inventory for this year and how we've
componenttext: Well, we had a number -- if you go back to what we talked about last year, we had a number of completions that were coming on towards the end of the year and beginning of this year. What we've done is we looked at our inventory for this year and how we've laid the program out for this year. We've actually set it up so we've spaced out our completions more through the year. Part of doing that was tailoring that to some of the discussions on what the suppliers and service companies that went along with how we implemented some of this cost reduction very quickly here into the beginning of the year. And part of that was also tailoring them the pace of the completions. So we've actually slowed down and tailored that completions to tie it in with the what we have set up from a frac crude standpoint that went into the discussions on how we implemented some very quickly reductions and completion cost here at the beginning of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The DJ's really interesting, but I think you did a good job explaining what's going on there, Dave. I wondered if I -- you could maybe get us a little bit more detail on how your conversations are going on the Marcellus? And there's language in your press
componenttext: The DJ's really interesting, but I think you did a good job explaining what's going on there, Dave. And there's language in your press release that you're still working to figure out the plan for '15. And one other kind of wrinkle to it seems to me is that, it seems to me that actually because of the NGL pricing and some of the infrastructure problems up there, actually the dry gas areas seem to me to be more attractive right now, at least for 2015. And so could you work that into your discussion?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Charles, it's a good question. And one, we've continued to be in discussion with our partner up there on what is the right activity level. What we've got built in right now reflect -- reflects probably a decrease over where we started last fall, when
componenttext: Yes. Charles, it's a good question. And one, we've continued to be in discussion with our partner up there on what is the right activity level. What we've got built in right now reflect -- reflects probably a decrease over where we started last fall, when we started in this budget process and I'd say it's an ongoing discussion, to kind of optimize what the program should be. I think we're probably still on the camp that we could probably continue to push that down a little. And I think we'll see how that progresses over time. But it's a good healthy discussion, I think. In any good partnership, even if you aren't completely aligned upfront, the structure of a good partnership is you continue to have good discussion, and that's where it's going. I mean -- and we've continued to bring down the program over time when you go back to last fall. So...

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And would it be fair, Dave, that bringing the program down would be more on the non-op side for you guys than operated?
componenttext: Got it. And would it be fair, Dave, that bringing the program down would be more on the non-op side for you guys than operated?

componenttext: Well, I mean, we've already brought the operated side down, we brought that down to 2 rigs on the wet gas. So I think the discussion now has continued to move around, what is the right amount of activity level on the dry gas portion.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could ask a question about Cyprus. And this may be too far field, but I thought I'd try. Given the hurdles have been thrown up in Israel, your -- as I look at it, the find you have in Cyprus is not that far west of your Leviathan find, and
componenttext: Okay. And if I could ask a question about Cyprus. And this may be too far field, but I thought I'd try. Given the hurdles have been thrown up in Israel, your -- as I look at it, the find you have in Cyprus is not that far west of your Leviathan find, and you were talking about doing some pipeline exports from Leviathan. So I wonder, is that a possibility, to do pipeline exports from Cyprus now? And I'm thinking that -- where, you didn't quite have enough for an LNG facility, but that was really before this regional export market popped up. And I'm wondering if the Cyprus find can plug into that possibility?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think we believe Cyprus can still play a role in that whole Eastern Med regional picture there. I mean, one of the things we're working with them on what would be the development plan in Cyprus. As you mentioned, was kind of moved away from an LNG p
componenttext: No. I think we believe Cyprus can still play a role in that whole Eastern Med regional picture there. I mean, one of the things we're working with them on what would be the development plan in Cyprus. As you mentioned, was kind of moved away from an LNG project and probably more something that would be more of a regional piece. I think the other thing I would mention and remind you to, when we talked about even the regional market on what we were looking at for our Israel volumes, as we were marketing that and looking at what the size of that market could be, we we're seeing a market that was potentially double the size of what we even were having in those LOIs, so I'd say there's definitely a role to be played for additional gas there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
