componenttextpreview: I think just off the top of my head, I think in the DJ, it's probably about half, close to half of what we had in 2014. In the Marcellus, I'm trying to think here and look and see if I've got something on actual completion inventory. I don't know if I've
componenttext: I think just off the top of my head, I think in the DJ, it's probably about half, close to half of what we had in 2014. In the Marcellus, I'm trying to think here and look and see if I've got something on actual completion inventory. I don't know if I've got the completion number on the Marcellus here right offhand.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could sneak one more in, Dave. I just wanted to get some details around Israel. Obviously, there's been a u-turn in terms of the antitrust decision. What do you think drove that? And what are the potential -- what are the some of the remedies that th
componenttext: If I could sneak one more in, Dave. I just wanted to get some details around Israel. Obviously, there's been a u-turn in terms of the antitrust decision. What do you think drove that? And what are the potential -- what are the some of the remedies that they're potentially seeking in terms of your assets there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, as far as remedies, I mean, we're in a lot of discussion with the government and even antitrust on this. I mean, as far as remedies and what they're trying to accomplish, I mean, their concern is about competition over there. And
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, as far as remedies, I mean, we're in a lot of discussion with the government and even antitrust on this. I mean, as far as remedies and what they're trying to accomplish, I mean, their concern is about competition over there. And that really was driven by the fact that when you go back in time, we were the only ones that were really successful, and we were successful on a large scale over there. I think -- so where we are, and I think we were surprised, I think a lot of people over there were surprised with the reversal in that decision. And the thing that we're focused on now and what that's highlighted is the need to put together a comprehensive framework to provide some regulatory certainty and stability going forward, to make the investment decisions. I mean, when you go back to the discussions with the antitrust commission and where we had gotten to last year, we essentially agreed to, and thought everybody had agreed to, the resolution to that competition was selling Karish and Tanin. When you think about that, Karish and Tanin in total, is about 3x the size of what Mari-B was. And Mari-B produced about 600 million a day for a number of years. So we thought that was a pretty good solution at the time. So right now, what they have entered into the equation is a discussion now of, "Okay, so how do we move forward on this?" The good part of it is, that it's brought the ministries together to even better understand the situation and better understand even the importance of resolving this and resolving this quickly for the betterment of Israel and actually the whole region over there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: And we'll go next to David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your comment on 2016 growth on lower CapEx was encouraging. One of the things we've been trying to think about is, I know you have deepwater projects that are coming online. But with the lower activity level in the Wattenberg, do you have a shallower base
componenttext: Your comment on 2016 growth on lower CapEx was encouraging. One of the things we've been trying to think about is, I know you have deepwater projects that are coming online. But with the lower activity level in the Wattenberg, do you have a shallower base decline at an exit at '15 as opposed to where you're exiting '14 on a higher activity level?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, David. I mean, the base question to that is you've got a lower amount of new production coming on, so it lowers your delta on absolute volume coming off, obviously. I think the other piece, and it points to our diversified asset base and why we
componenttext: Well, yes, David. I mean, the base question to that is you've got a lower amount of new production coming on, so it lowers your delta on absolute volume coming off, obviously. I think the other piece, and it points to our diversified asset base and why we think that is especially a strength in volatile price times. One of the decisions we made was to continue with the completion in the development of our Gulf of Mexico projects. That's going to add significant volume by the end of this year that gives us a year-on-year nice improvement out there for 2016. The other piece not to forget about is the Tamar volumes over there. And that continues to have growth potential based on in-country demand without additional investment. So I mean, that is a -- 2 pieces of the portfolio that we think are definitely differentiators for us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the political landscape in Israel, clearly, has weighed on your valuation some. But thinking about where Israel is now with Tamar online, and the revenues that the country generates, where does that go to whenever a planned Leviathan developme
componenttext: And then on the political landscape in Israel, clearly, has weighed on your valuation some. But thinking about where Israel is now with Tamar online, and the revenues that the country generates, where does that go to whenever a planned Leviathan development comes online, whenever that may be at this point. But I'm just trying to think of how much value is created to kind of the nation of Israel? And what is the incentives that they're kind of thinking about, from a Leviathan development?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean there's a huge incentive for them to get these projects on. When you think that they actually capture over half the value that comes from any volume of gas, whether it's sold in country or sold in an export arrangement. If you remember on the
componenttext: Yes. I mean there's a huge incentive for them to get these projects on. When you think that they actually capture over half the value that comes from any volume of gas, whether it's sold in country or sold in an export arrangement. If you remember on the Leviathan, we're talking about a capacity, a facility capacity, of 1.6 Bcf a day, and probably a run rate that would be closer to that 1 to 1.2 Bcf a day. A large part of that would be targeted from -- would be targeted to go to export, with some portion for fill-in with whatever's needed in the domestic demand. But you think of that relative to the perspective of Tamar and what it's doing now. I mean, we've seen the figures that indicate that's 1% of their GDP growth over there. So I mean it's a huge impact. And Ken can add some color to that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, when the export rules were passed, there was an external study done by McKinsey, and if I remember correctly, the delta value to the citizens in GDP was $230 billion. So over the life of exports. And also, it was 20 more -- it was estimated to be 2
componenttext: David, when the export rules were passed, there was an external study done by McKinsey, and if I remember correctly, the delta value to the citizens in GDP was $230 billion. So over the life of exports. And also, it was 20 more -- it was estimated to be 20 more years of domestic supply because of further exploration activity. So it's a material impact on the nation and to this industry.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: I think that's probably all across the board. So everybody's in discussion with their suppliers.

Do you see this clearing the deck on midstream bottlenecks? Or are others emerging? And should we see a step change in second half one per production? Or is that just offset by reduced divestment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at the bottlenecking portion, I think there's a lot of things, as we mentioned, Brian, that are going in place in the second quarter. There's also that what we call the grand parkway system, which is a big loop, if you will, to de-bo
componenttext: I think when you look at the bottlenecking portion, I think there's a lot of things, as we mentioned, Brian, that are going in place in the second quarter. There's also that what we call the grand parkway system, which is a big loop, if you will, to de-bottleneck and be more efficient on how gas is distributed around the field. That will come into place towards the end of the year, beginning of the next year, is when we'll really see the impact on that. So there's some staggered things that will be coming in place, and then you start to get into the next plants beyond that. So I mean, we'll continue to have to keep our eye on what else can be done as we move through the cycle here.

componenttext: I mean, that's going to be -- have to be matched with the activity. headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: No. I think, actually, what we are investing in this year is completing the compression project. So that actually gives us a little more capacity. So I would say, at this level of investment, or essentially minimal to no investment going forward, you ought to be able to stay flat to grow, and that's going to depend on the demand. Up to the level of what that Ashdod compression capacity gives us, so up to about that 1.2 Bcf a day or so.

componenttext: Really appreciate all the color on '15, and certainly understand the adjustments to CapEx, seems prudent, et cetera. In the past, you guys have given us longer-dated plans that go out as far as 5 years. Any ability to kind of update that forecast for folks right now in terms of how we should think about building through the model? I know you're being super conservative with a $50 to $55 deck, but just trying to help triangulate the next several years.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we ought to be going out too far in this environment, Dave, because I think we've got to tailor that to what activity levels are you going to assume and how quickly are you going to ramp back up. I think what we wanted to do was give folks s
componenttext: I don't think we ought to be going out too far in this environment, Dave, because I think we've got to tailor that to what activity levels are you going to assume and how quickly are you going to ramp back up. I think what we wanted to do was give folks some perspective on how we see 2016 at a certain level of investment to just give them some comfort on how we can sustain ourselves and even still grow some in '16 at very low investment levels. I think starting to project beyond that is going to depend on where you start to ramp up, especially your onshore programs. What I will say when you go back to that 5-year outlook, no, none of the resources in there have changed, at least, to the downside. If anything, what we've learned through our drilling programs it continues to put upward pressure on that. So the nice thing is the resources there. Now the timing and pace activity is going to be dependent on how we handle and how we match up with the financial aspect of it. And that's going to be dependent on price environment and cost structure.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate those clarifications. I know it's a difficult question, obviously, in the current environment. But maybe tying that a little bit to the financials and the current liquidity position, essentially, it seems like your target or at least what you
componenttext: I appreciate those clarifications. I know it's a difficult question, obviously, in the current environment. But maybe tying that a little bit to the financials and the current liquidity position, essentially, it seems like your target or at least what you're communicating here is to just be pushing forward that liquidity position into '16, '17, when the environment does change. So that you can ramp at that point, given that the resource space is, as you just highlighted, actually increasing during this time period.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, when you think about it, we've got a wealth of inventory here. So it makes sense for us to maintain our liquidity such that when the time is right, we can move as rapidly as we want to move to start to capture this additional value. So I thin
componenttext: Yes. I mean, when you think about it, we've got a wealth of inventory here. So it makes sense for us to maintain our liquidity such that when the time is right, we can move as rapidly as we want to move to start to capture this additional value. So I think you've got to tie the whole financial management with the operational management. The thing I like about our position is we've got a very strong financial position. We're committed to keeping a very strong financial position. We've got an inventory, huge inventory of opportunities, and we've got a great proficiency in onshore developments, offshore developments, exploration and major project execution. And we're going to continue to fine-tune and improve those efficiencies and proficiencies as we go. It's one of the nice things about even our program this year. Even at these reduced capital level, we still are exposing ourselves to some very significant material exploration prospects even at this level. So we continue to keep that exploration proficiency going. We continue to move the major project proficiency along, as with these developments in the Gulf of Mexico. So it's not like we've set any portion of our program and capabilities on the shelf.

componenttext: I was hoping you could follow up on what type of pricing we need to see here on the oil side, and I guess the natural gas side, for the Marcellus, to where you'd start to feel comfortable with activity increases? And could activity increases happen during 2015, if we saw a nice rebound as we moved into the second half? How quickly can Noble respond?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what we've talked about, Leo, is making sure that we're in a position that we can respond quickly. I think when that will be is open to interpretation at this point. But 2 things that are going to play into effect is: what's the outlook on co
componenttext: Yes. I think what we've talked about, Leo, is making sure that we're in a position that we can respond quickly. I think when that will be is open to interpretation at this point. But 2 things that are going to play into effect is: what's the outlook on commodity price; and how much cost are we seeing being able to pull out of the business that we feel we can sustain being out of the business and continue to keep out of it. And how does that world match up, both on commodity price and cost as we look forward. But our objective is to maintain our flexibility so that when that time is right, we can move very quickly.

componenttext: Okay. And I guess just in terms of Israel, can you maybe just put a little bit more color around the situation? Is it one where you guys are negotiating with the government and the ministry on what the potential outcome may be? Or is it more of one where you're awaiting sort of the government to kind of tell you what they need on their side? And can you maybe just discuss what Noble's legal rights are, with regards to its assets as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think where we are in discussion is -- we're engaged in discussion. I mean, we always think it's helpful to be engaged in discussion. So we're engaged in discussion with this government committee that's been pulled together that represents the minis
componenttext: No. I think where we are in discussion is -- we're engaged in discussion. I mean, we always think it's helpful to be engaged in discussion. So we're engaged in discussion with this government committee that's been pulled together that represents the ministries. And I think one of the things I mentioned earlier, this is probably the first time we've had the opportunity to be truly engaged in a discussion with a group that represents all the ministries. All the folks we need to get in a room together. And that discussion's centered around setting up a comprehensive solution that has a regulatory framework that can sustain the investment and development for future projects, and that's really the nature of the discussion. Part of that whole discussion has been also -- it's not just us in that discussion, they've had to bring in, if you think about this and the way we've talked about our investment, our future investment in Israel, we've talked about ring fencing that, about it being tied to financing and project financing and so forth. So that's lent itself to where some of these folks who would potentially finance some this type of activity, the banks, and so forth, financial institutions around the world, are also weighing in on what it takes to have a sustainable investment climate.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. David Larson. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. David Larson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joshua. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued our earnings release and also posted to our website a few supplemental slides for this call.
componenttext:
Thanks, Joshua. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued our earnings release and also posted to our website a few supplemental slides for this call. Later this morning, our 10-Q will be available.
Following the remarks by Dave Stover, we'll open the call for Q&A with the executive team and wrap things up in less than an hour.
Finally, I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements, as well as references non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those.
With that, let me turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm extremely pleased with how Noble Energy has performed in the early part of 2015. This is highlighted by our production, which has been very strong across the board. And whil
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm extremely pleased with how Noble Energy has performed in the early part of 2015. This is highlighted by our production, which has been very strong across the board. And while still early, we're confident enough to raise our full year volume outlook. Our successes also include improving capital efficiency and reducing operating costs. And results so far this year are right where we expect it, if not a little better. Another major accomplishment was gaining alignment with our partner in the Marcellus to reduce our activity levels. And in the DJ Basin, strong results and continued operational efficiencies are driving additional capital allocation in the second half of the year.
Starting off with sales volumes. We sold a record 318,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter, an increase of 17% over the same period last year after adjusting for asset sales. Full year sales are now expected to average between 300,000 and 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, as we have raised the bottom end of our range by 5,000 barrels equivalent per day. The up -- this update range now reflects the first quarter our performance while maintaining our prior expectations for remaining quarters of the year.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, core U.S. onshore sales volumes increased more than 35%, driven by record production in both the DJ Basin and Marcellus Shale. Horizontal production in these 2 plays were up in combined 60% versus the same time period. 
Offshore, including the Gulf of Mexico and our international businesses, volumes were relatively flat with the first quarter of last year after adjusting for asset sales. Our offshore assets continue to perform very well with world-class runtime and lower-than-expected decline rate. 
Highlighting this performance is nearly 100% runtime at both Tamar offshore Israel and Aseng in Equatorial Guinea. As the combination of these high-quality, low-cost asset and managing a diversified portfolio that continues to provide Noble competitive advantage, our U.S. onshore development, major project execution and exploration activities provide material resource opportunities and tremendous investment optionality.
As mentioned earlier, we have made substantial progress towards lowering both our capital and operating cost. We've worked closely with our suppliers to achieve an average of 20% savings, the most prominently in our U.S. onshore business. Our suppliers have moved quickly to assist in adjusting our cost structure, and we continue to work with them in partnership to ensure these early achievements are turned into sustainable cost improvements.
Highlighting our production cost reduction was lease operating expense, which is already down $0.50 per barrel from the fourth quarter, a material change in such a short period of time and putting us on track to meet our full year average expectation. 
General and administrative costs are down from previous quarters as well. We've also recently completed an organizational realignment, which better positions our workforce for this current environment.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were a little over $900 million, slightly below our internal expectations and trending lower as we move through the year. Total capital for 2015 remains $2.9 billion, with $1.8 billion allocated to the onshore U.S. business. The DJ Basin has increased to more than 60% of the onshore U.S. amount, with Marcellus now representing slightly less than 40%.
Focusing on our DJ operations. Growth in the first quarter exhibited our strong operating capacity. Total volumes were a record 116,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 22% versus the first quarter last year. Growth in the horizontal program was even more impressive, up more than 50% over the last year and more than 110% the last 2 years.
Slide 4 highlights continued drilling efficiencies being delivered by our teams. And as you can see, we're now averaging 7 days from spud to rig release for standard lateral length well, almost as fast as we use to drill vertical wells. In fact, we recently drilled a 9,300-foot horizontal well in Wells Ranch in just 7 days.
Compared to last year, we're drilling 70% of the total footage while utilizing 40% of the rig count. This is a result of our focus on drilling execution, utilizing the best rigs and cruise in the basin, and continuing to increase our average lateral lengths per well.
Reduced drilling times are resulting in an increased number of wells that can be completed this year. And we're reallocating some capital here to keep up with a drilling pace supplementing our one full-time completion crew with a second completion crew in the second half of the year. These efficiencies along supplier cost reductions are driving a downward trend in our well cost. Based on today's drilling completion costs, we're already meeting our budgeted well cost expectations for the year. 
We have highlighted on Slide 5 a $3.8 million Wells Ranch well. Our overall cost reductions from 2014 include 5% to 15% sustainable cost savings from continuing to reduce drilling times and optimizing equipment usage and a range of 15% to 25% savings from our major suppliers. It is worth noting that the these well costs are all in and include items that just pad construction and associated facilities cost.
And we have opportunities continue to drive cost down further. Using slick water for fracs in certain parts of the basin may allow us to save an additional $100,000 to $200,000 per well on a standardized lateral. We recently brought online 11 wells in East Pony that were completed with slick water, and these wells are performing at/or above expectations.
Third-party infrastructure uptime improved at the start of the year, and I am pleased with the progress of the expansion projects that are currently underway. 
The Lucerne-2 plant and additional compressor stations are on track for start-up in late second quarter, providing a material increase in processing and compression capacity on the DCP system. The grand parkway low-pressure loop has been approved and is expected to start-up by the end of the year, which will have a positive impact on the performance of legacy vertical wells and earlier horizontal wells.
Operating performance in the Marcellus Shale remains exceptional as well and our production grew 73% versus the first quarter of last year to nearly 400 million cubic feet equivalent per day. Similar to the DJ Basin, we're seeing substantial reduction in drilling times and lower well cost through a combination of utilizing top full rigs, drilling longer laterals and supplier cost reductions.
Improvements in drilling times have resulted in a larger inventory of uncompleted wells than we had originally anticipated in both the operated and non-operated the areas of the Marcellus. This affords us the opportunity to reduce rig count in the second half of the year to 1 operated rig and 2 non-operated rigs while still meeting our plant completion and production goals. Overall, this is a $200 million net reduction to our prior Marcellus expectations.
We continue to diversify our natural gas markets and recently began transporting approximately 100 million cubic feet per day of gas out of the basin, including our first sales in the Gulf Coast market. This firm transportation has a relatively low overall cost and gives us further access to better price markets.
Moving offshore. We achieved a number of key milestones on our major projects in the Gulf of Mexico during the first quarter. At Rio Grande, all drilling and completion operations are now complete and pipeline installation is scheduled to begin in the second quarter. Rio Grande remains on schedule for first production in the fourth quarter. Development drilling operations at Gunflint are underway and are expected to continue throughout the remainder of 2015. Pipeline installation will commence following the Rio Grande installation and first production from Gunflint remains on schedule for mid-2016.
Our Gulf of Mexico projects highlight the benefits of our diverse portfolio by providing strong oil growth exiting 2015 with another step up in 2016. The cash margins for these projects are very competitive with the U.S. onshore resource place, evident by nearly all of the production being oil and priced at a premium to WTI, combined with attractive production cost.
Moving to the Eastern Mediterranean. To mark continues to exhibit exceptional reliability and set new milestones for delivery, achieving a net record weekly grow sales average of over 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day, driven by seasonal demand and coal plant maintenance. A recently signed agreement to supply interruptible sales of up to 250 million cubic feet per day gross from Tamar to Egypt's domestic market is another example of the strongly general demand for our natural gas. We and our customer are now working to finalize regulatory approvals and transportation agreements needed to start sales. We believe these can be included in the next few months, setting us up for initial sales of later 2015 by utilizing existing infrastructure. Once we have those approvals, we will provide an outlook for sales and adjust our production guidance at that time.
During the first quarter, we received regulatory approval for export sales to the Arab Potash Company and Jordan Bromine Company in Jordan. While relatively small volumes, this does represent the first formally approved regional export of natural gas from Israel and sets forward a path for additional agreements to follow. 
Meanwhile, we continue to work very intently to establish a comprehensive framework for energy development. Our teams are meeting regularly with the interministerial group established by the Prime Minister's office for this purpose, and we are encouraged by their efforts to create a sustainable climate for energy development in Israel. 
Early progress has been made, and we look forward to working with the new government. Resolution about standing regulatory matters, including antitrust concerns and export taxation, along with a comprehensive framework for energy development, is still necessary to enable additional project development. We believe the interministerial working group is on track to achieve this objective over the next few months following the seating of the new government.
In Cyprus, we're working closely with the government and plan to submit a preliminary field development plan in the near future. Our Cyprus discovery can be another important contributor toward meeting regional gas demand. We've begun export marketing activities and are greatly encouraged by the local of interest expressed by potential counterparties, not only for gas purchases, but also regarding participating in export infrastructure investment.
Also within our offshore business, you can certainly feel the exploration excitement around our office as we're nearing a very impactful 2015 drilling program. 
In West Africa, we recently signed a rig contract for the Cheetah exploration prospect in Cameroon and expect this low-cost well to spud earlier in the third quarter. Cheetah represents our first test in the developed basin and has a main resource size in excess of 100 million barrels of oil equivalent gross. A sizable discovery at Cheetah will deliver very attractive development in less than 100 feet of water depth where we can move very quickly to first production.
By the end of the second quarter, we anticipate commencing drilling offshore to Falkland Islands where we plan to drill 2 exploration wells this year. Our first prospect, Humpback, which we operate with a 35% as a gross main resource size of over 250 million barrels of oil. If successful, Humpback with de-risk other large prospect shown on Slide 10 that have cumulative growth resource potential in excess of 1 billion barrels of oil.
We recently formed into the Rhea prospect also with 250 million barrels of oil potential, which will be our second exploration well in the Falkland Islands. Adding the Rhea opportunity further diversifies our exploration inventory and enhances our overall chance of success as it offsets other oil discoveries in the basin. The prospect is anticipated the spud by year-end. We operate Rhea and currently have a 75% working interest.
Let me now provide some insight into our volume profile throughout the year. As mentioned earlier, we've not made any production guidance changes to the remaining quarters. Second quarter sales volumes are anticipated to range between 290,000 and 300,000 barrels of oil per day, impacted by the plant facility maintenance and turnarounds in West Africa and the Gulf of Mexico, along with the usual seasonal demand softness for Israel volumes. 
For their sales are expected to build in the second half of the year with strong seasonal demand in Israel in the third quarter followed by new oil volumes from the start-up of our major projects in the Gulf of Mexico in the fourth quarter. Our diversified portfolio is setting us up to exit 2015 on a nice trajectory. 
So in summary, we're off to a strong start this year. Performance and volumes, capital efficiency and costs is where we expect it, if not a little better -- not a little bit better at this point. And we're on a path approaching cash flow neutrality around midyear as we anticipated.
So Joshua, this time, we'd like to go ahead and open the call to questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys delivered impressive efficiencies, drilling efficiencies in from the first quarter. I guess, 2 questions. What do you see is the scope there to improve efficiencies further? And secondly, how are you planning to preserve those efficiencies as act
componenttext: You guys delivered impressive efficiencies, drilling efficiencies in from the first quarter. I guess, 2 questions. What do you see is the scope there to improve efficiencies further? And secondly, how are you planning to preserve those efficiencies as activity increases in an off cycle? More of a secular benefit been cyclical like service cost benefits you're enjoying today?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Evan, it's good to point out that the efficiencies are continuing to improve. And I don't think we're done there. I'll have Gary Willingham talk a little bit about his view up there. But I've been extremely impressed and pleased with what the team h
componenttext: Well, Evan, it's good to point out that the efficiencies are continuing to improve. And I don't think we're done there. I'll have Gary Willingham talk a little bit about his view up there. But I've been extremely impressed and pleased with what the team has done by concentrating on each aspect of the drilling cycle, if you will. I mean, if you think about it now, we've actually drilled long lateral in the same time that we used to drill vertical wells 4 to 5 years ago. So it's been a remarkable improvement. But I'll get let Gary what he sees as far as trajectory this year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you look at the slide on Page 4, you can see the improvement over time and especially focusing on that spud to rig release curve, how that's continue to come down over time, so we're our able to do that even in a much higher commodity price envi
componenttext: Yes. When you look at the slide on Page 4, you can see the improvement over time and especially focusing on that spud to rig release curve, how that's continue to come down over time, so we're our able to do that even in a much higher commodity price environment, obviously. I think some of the recent performance improvement we've seen to be fair is we're running 4 rigs and we tended to keep the 4 best rigs out of the 10, but I think that's a fairly small part of the improvement that we've seen. Most of it comes from just continuing focus on how can we make each little part of the drilling process better. And as Dave mentioned, while we average to 7 days for normal in collaterals in first quarter in DJ, wells are drilled 9,300-foot well in 7 days. And we also drilled a long length lateral well in 5 days in East Pony. So that gives us confidence that they're still more improvement 2 come and that's where we'll be taking over the next quarters.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my second question, given you have reduced activity in the Marcellus, how do you consider reallocating capital in the Niobrara beyond the completion crew added? Just maybe more broadly, many companies have cited various approaches into a commodity pri
componenttext: And my second question, given you have reduced activity in the Marcellus, how do you consider reallocating capital in the Niobrara beyond the completion crew added? Just maybe more broadly, many companies have cited various approaches into a commodity price recovery with some looking to balance sheet repair earlier adding rigs in the back half of the year. How do you anticipate responding and improve commodity price environment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, for now, for '15, we're really still looking at just 4 rigs. So the capital that we're shifting from the Marcellus to the DJ, we're that to kind of back-end load those of 4 rigs that we've already got because again, we're drilling wells a lot fast
componenttext: I mean, for now, for '15, we're really still looking at just 4 rigs. So the capital that we're shifting from the Marcellus to the DJ, we're that to kind of back-end load those of 4 rigs that we've already got because again, we're drilling wells a lot faster. So that kind of back-end loads of those rigs and provides for a few more completion of this year. Most of those completions, incremental completions will be in 2016.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's regardless of what the commodity looks like in the back half of the year? You're pretty set for this year or is it responsive were reflective of what that environment?
componenttext: And that's regardless of what the commodity looks like in the back half of the year? You're pretty set for this year or is it responsive were reflective of what that environment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say at this point, it's too early to change anything for the year. I mean, the one change that you've noted is that we brought down the capital spending working with our partner in the Marcellus. And then as Gary pointed out with the efficiencies that
componenttext: I'd say at this point, it's too early to change anything for the year. I mean, the one change that you've noted is that we brought down the capital spending working with our partner in the Marcellus. And then as Gary pointed out with the efficiencies that these 4 rigs and just assuming we stay at 4 rigs this year and in the DJ, we're going to drill more wells, and now we're going to allocate more money to completion. So we'll come out of the year putting ourselves in I'd say even better position heading into '16 there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with the Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with the Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions, if I may. You've comment in the press release about the efficiency gains in DJ will result more wells this year than perhaps you originally planned. So I guess, I've kind of 2 questions around that. One is why continue to drill in thi
componenttext: Couple of questions, if I may. You've comment in the press release about the efficiency gains in DJ will result more wells this year than perhaps you originally planned. So I guess, I've kind of 2 questions around that. One is why continue to drill in this, I guess, as an improvement environment, but why continue to drill what some of your peers are deferring completions, what's your take on that? And secondly, how does that change the mix of those incremental wells between long laterals and, I guess, and I got a quick follow-up, please.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll start with that. But I'd say where we are right now and as Gary's pointed out, we continue to get more and more efficient with these 4 rigs, And I would expect we can continue to see that trend this year. So we've kind of got a base load of
componenttext: Yes. And I'll start with that. But I'd say where we are right now and as Gary's pointed out, we continue to get more and more efficient with these 4 rigs, And I would expect we can continue to see that trend this year. So we've kind of got a base load of operation now between what we're focusing on in East Pony and Wells Ranch with this rig activity, with this 4-rig activity. And what is enabling us to do is to bring more wells ready for -- more wells drilled by the end of year more wells rate complete by the end of the year, which I think will give us some very nice momentum as we exit this year and look towards 2016. It just gives us a lot more capacity with what we can do there as we continue to gain efficiency. And I think that part of that efficiency is driven by focusing on this continued improvement with these 4 rigs in with these dedicated crews of we have up there. Gary has another view.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the only thing I would add to the view how does that make the mix if you're else. We've been looking at increasing our spud count this year by probably about 15% in the DJ. I think those incremental wells that will be targeted towards year-end wil
componenttext: I think the only thing I would add to the view how does that make the mix if you're else. We've been looking at increasing our spud count this year by probably about 15% in the DJ. I think those incremental wells that will be targeted towards year-end will be roughly the same, 50% year, that we got in the budget, but if it's off from that much, it's not going to change the annual average that much either way.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate the answer. Dave, my follow-up I guess, is this your question around the regulatory situation in Israel. I think you'd suggested that postelection, things were perhaps looking a little bit more promising in terms of getting going again on
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate the answer. Dave, my follow-up I guess, is this your question around the regulatory situation in Israel. I think you'd suggested that postelection, things were perhaps looking a little bit more promising in terms of getting going again on Leviathan sales and so on. Any update you can share to the extent?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the main thing while they've been going through their election cycle when putting the new government together, the works continued behind the scenes with this interministerial committee. And I think we've been very pleased with the progress we see
componenttext: I think the main thing while they've been going through their election cycle when putting the new government together, the works continued behind the scenes with this interministerial committee. And I think we've been very pleased with the progress we seen, especially the focus on coming up with what we've talked about this comprehensive solution, this kind of roadmap, the sanction, if you will. And so I've been very pleased with the progress we've seen in the commitment to getting this thing ready so that we can start back up as things develop here. and part of the reality of it is the new government is going to get in place, going to get seated. But the real positive part of that is nobody's waiting or has been waiting for that. Everybody's been working diligently to address the things that need to be addressed. So you can put this comprehensive of framework together. I can ask key. Keith's been the one -- Keith Elliott more intimately involved with and give you his feel for his outlook on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Doug, that the -- my sense is that the government through the formation of the interministerial committee is really reflecting that the recognition that the establishment of this investment framework, a framework that lends itself to compani
componenttext: Yes. I think, Doug, that the -- my sense is that the government through the formation of the interministerial committee is really reflecting that the recognition that the establishment of this investment framework, a framework that lends itself to companies, ourselves and other players, new entrants into the basin, get providing sort of stable and attractive investment climate just leaves us to be optimistic that they're going to deliver a solution in a reasonable time frame here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to be engaged with all of those potential customers. We're engaged with them on an ongoing basis. The LOIs are either in place or extensions have been agreed. And all parties really continue to be very prepared to move toward consummation of t
componenttext: We continue to be engaged with all of those potential customers. We're engaged with them on an ongoing basis. The LOIs are either in place or extensions have been agreed. And all parties really continue to be very prepared to move toward consummation of these contracts once we can get the regulatory framework in place. I mean, I think the thing and Dave alluded to it in his comments, the thing that I would just call out is there really is a fundamental supply demand imbalance that the resources in Israel and Cyprus are -- can really land in to helping to address. And I think that hasn't been lost on any of the potential buyers.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Real quickly, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you thought the decrease in service cost could be sustained over time. Can you give us some more color on that, specifically to the cost reductions, not necessarily the efficiency gain? And are yo
componenttext: Real quickly, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you thought the decrease in service cost could be sustained over time. Can you give us some more color on that, specifically to the cost reductions, not necessarily the efficiency gain? And are you looking at locking down some of the service cost going forward in the form of contracts or anything like that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that gets all back to how we're working with our major service providers. And I think the way we look at it is this is a partnership. It's not about just beating cost down, but it's a partnership on how do we do business, not only for now, but goi
componenttext: I think that gets all back to how we're working with our major service providers. And I think the way we look at it is this is a partnership. It's not about just beating cost down, but it's a partnership on how do we do business, not only for now, but going forward in a way that we can make this more economical for all of us. And so a lot of discussion, when you look at actually contracting and a lot of that's on an annual basis on some of our major suppliers, that can be a little on longer on some of this. So we'll put in place some of that. But we're looking at the combination of service cost and what else can we do just from improved efficiency on some of this and the combination of those to lock in a lower-cost profile, if you will, for longer term here. But it's -- back to Gary's point earlier, it's working on all aspects of that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate that. And then one of the things -- I know I've talked to you guys about in the past service companies are highlighting. And that's the ability to go back and refrac wells, which at this juncture some people are posing that that could be
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate that. And then one of the things -- I know I've talked to you guys about in the past service companies are highlighting. And that's the ability to go back and refrac wells, which at this juncture some people are posing that that could be a significant driver to higher rates of return obviously for lower care capital spending. How are you guys thinking about that in the Wattenberg at this juncture? And how are you setting up currently?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you would expect, especially up in Wattenberg and the DJ Basin, we've had a long history and our predecessors had a long history of utilizing existing wellbores, especially in the vertical world, where they were -- we've been in the mode of refra
componenttext: Well, as you would expect, especially up in Wattenberg and the DJ Basin, we've had a long history and our predecessors had a long history of utilizing existing wellbores, especially in the vertical world, where they were -- we've been in the mode of refracs and even try fracs. So there's a lot of history there. I think in the horizontal world, obviously, poses some other complexities, if you will, with using the long lateral, especially on long lateral lengths. But we did a few up there previously. We've also done a few in the Marcellus. And I think it's probably going to take a little more time. The ones initially did were probably in areas formed as well initially. So we saw some benefit from that. The real test will be when we start, at some point, trying to do this in areas that have had very good results. But after 3 or 4 years or so like, we did in the vertical program you start to look at can you go back in and bust open some more rock and get some more incremental recovery. I think, David, it's just part of what's in the toolbox of things we're looking at as to how we take the percent recovery from single-digit to double-digit up there in the basin. And Gary, anything else on that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think we've said, we've done some in both places the Marcellus, we did some refracs, as well as some perforating on some older wells. And that's very nice results on those where the production rates came back up to actually the initial rates of the
componenttext: No. I think we've said, we've done some in both places the Marcellus, we did some refracs, as well as some perforating on some older wells. And that's very nice results on those where the production rates came back up to actually the initial rates of the well. DJ, we've done a number. Results have been a bit more mixed there, being able to mechanically isolate the fracs remained the big issue there. You've seen a lot of talk recently around different means of diverting. We've tried some of those. we've not really to comment on the results yet. We're also working on a couple of other ideas that haven't seen -- mention too much publicly. So we'll continue to chase a few things. I think this is something that eventually a lot of smart engineers in the industry figure out how to fix it and create a whole another way of opportunity in these fields.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate that. One last one if I could just make it in. How are you guys thinking about hedging in '16 at this juncture with the movement we've seen in the forward strip?
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate that. One last one if I could just make it in. How are you guys thinking about hedging in '16 at this juncture with the movement we've seen in the forward strip?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've got some volume hedged in '16, I think.
componenttext: We've got some volume hedged in '16, I think.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think about 29%.
componenttext: I think about 29%.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the way our hedging program has been very successful over time in that we know -- we try to average in. So we'll set up plan rate and then we'll watch the market and go slowly. So that's allowed us to be well hedged in -- through time and we've ha
componenttext: I think the way our hedging program has been very successful over time in that we know -- we try to average in. So we'll set up plan rate and then we'll watch the market and go slowly. So that's allowed us to be well hedged in -- through time and we've had a big hedge settlements in '09, big positive hedge settlements in '09, and of course, this year, and again '16 depending on how things play out. At the same time, we haven't given up much headroom -- had negative settlements of any note. So the programs been effective, but we'll continue to do with current year plus 2 and typically about 50% of the volume and average in.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll continue to look for opportunities in an upswing and commodity market. But as Ken said, the target is 50% on global oil and 50% on U.S. gas. It's kind of what we hold ourselves to.
componenttext: We'll continue to look for opportunities in an upswing and commodity market. But as Ken said, the target is 50% on global oil and 50% on U.S. gas. It's kind of what we hold ourselves to.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll move on to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And next, we'll move on to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could ask a question on the DJ. We see 8% sequential production growth there quarter-over-quarter. I think that's the highest we've seen in a while. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether that's maybe the beginning of a trend we see
componenttext: I wonder if I could ask a question on the DJ. We see 8% sequential production growth there quarter-over-quarter. I think that's the highest we've seen in a while. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether that's maybe the beginning of a trend we see as you kind of unload the spring and get the midstream bottleneck or maybe if it's more reflective of kind of reduced operational pace and so kind of reduced offset well shut-ins as fracs and can you kind of give us a sense of the bigger picture there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Charles, appreciate it. I think it was a bit quarter in the DJ. Obviously, I think we benefited some from coming off the activity levels late last year, which we actually drop for reduced from 10 rigs late last year into starting this year, we'll say star
componenttext: Charles, appreciate it. I think it was a bit quarter in the DJ. Obviously, I think we benefited some from coming off the activity levels late last year, which we actually drop for reduced from 10 rigs late last year into starting this year, we'll say starting this year off here in the first quarter moving down to 4 on that. So we'll see that change a little bit. Gary can talk on how he sees the year laying out as we go through the year and we still have some of the big processing facility to come on here in the end of the second quarter, too, which will impact things.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't attribute any of it really or much of it to lower activity levels and less offset shut-ins with fracs. You probably remember a lot of our completions in 2014 were towards the back-end loaded. So a lot of wells came on late in 4Q and we certainl
componenttext: I wouldn't attribute any of it really or much of it to lower activity levels and less offset shut-ins with fracs. You probably remember a lot of our completions in 2014 were towards the back-end loaded. So a lot of wells came on late in 4Q and we certainly got a uplift from that in the first quarter of this year. We have dropped down from the 10 rigs to the 4 rigs. So we're working off the completion backlog that we brought into the year as well. I think when you look at our profile through the year, we expect to 1Q to be the highest, be fairly flat, maybe through the first half and then start to decline in the second half as we get back in the more of an equilibrium that would expect with only running 4 rigs. However, it remains to be seen on top of that how much uplift we truly get from the start-up of the Lucerne-2 gas plant that DCP is bringing on in June. That's a $200 million a day plant. We would certainly expect to see some recovery from our legacy program, the vertical wells, the older horizontal wells for reduced pressures when that plant comes on. We've got a little bit of that baked into the plan, but we can see more than that. And don't forget, as we talked last call, we've kind of level loaded our completions here for the year. So as we get more completions later in the year, as I mentioned earlier, that actually helps us on next year's of volume.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That makes sense, Dave. And Gary, that's good detailing on what you guys have kind of that you have a portion of the Lucerne portion of I guess say the possible Lucerne uplift rate in. Dave, if I could get you to go back to talk about the Eastern
componenttext: Got it. That makes sense, Dave. And Gary, that's good detailing on what you guys have kind of that you have a portion of the Lucerne portion of I guess say the possible Lucerne uplift rate in. Dave, if I could get you to go back to talk about the Eastern Med. I recognize that maybe you guys don't want to go into too much detail, but try see if we can a little more out of you. But -- so you got -- I recognize that they have new part and have worked up a new coalition that sort of thing. But maybe you can talk a bit about how you got this finalized agreement because it seems like -- I know this news came out a little bit early, but that to me, seems like well it's not a big deal, it's important hurdle that you now have exports approved to go out of the country. But kind of how did that come together in the absence of a city parliament? And how should we -- does that have any indications what the process looks like for your interruptible Egypt agreement?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good connection there, Charles. I'd say that yes, even though it is a small volume, it is a important from the standpoint that that was the first real export agreement. So we had a chance to work through the process, if you will, and get some of the kinks
componenttext: Good connection there, Charles. I'd say that yes, even though it is a small volume, it is a important from the standpoint that that was the first real export agreement. So we had a chance to work through the process, if you will, and get some of the kinks out in that process on how you approach that and how you get an approval that type of thing. So for that first agreement over there to Jordan. Keith can expand and that a little more since he's been closer to it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, I think with respect to the Jordan and bromine agreement that you're referring to, that really is the result of ongoing engagement with the government really over a period of probably a year, 1.5 years, where we've been pursuing the really i
componenttext: Yes, Charles, I think with respect to the Jordan and bromine agreement that you're referring to, that really is the result of ongoing engagement with the government really over a period of probably a year, 1.5 years, where we've been pursuing the really implementation of the export policy that the government established back in 2012 and 2013 time frame. So a number of these things are within the control of specific ministries. And so this is the case in point where it's completely within the of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources. Others are more complex that require the alignment across ministries. And that's really been the benefit that we've seen in this interministerial working group. It's caused a number of ministries that typically don't work as closely together as might be needed to create the kind of framework that investors look for. It's provided a venue for those groups to work together. And that's been the real positive thing, I think, that's come out of this force.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But I think the second part of your question, does it help with setting a pathway for the interruptible contract approval by the governments and actually both governments, Israel and Egypt, for that? And I think it does help with that. And that's one we'r
componenttext: But I think the second part of your question, does it help with setting a pathway for the interruptible contract approval by the governments and actually both governments, Israel and Egypt, for that? And I think it does help with that. And that's one we're continuing to keep our eye on and push because we think that could be another very important milestone, if you will, in how things are progressing over there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Because in just this in David, because that would establish Israeli exports to Egypt even though it's testing pipeline that so if you get that in place, then presumably, you've got one big hurdle down on the idea of getting divide and gas through s
componenttext: Right. Because in just this in David, because that would establish Israeli exports to Egypt even though it's testing pipeline that so if you get that in place, then presumably, you've got one big hurdle down on the idea of getting divide and gas through some offshore pipeline to Egypt?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple questions on the DJ. The first, you highlighted $3.8 million well cost for the Wells Ranch, 4,500-foot lateral. I just wanted to see go based on the trends in service cost deflation and efficiency gains that you're seeing. And then whether you thin
componenttext: Couple questions on the DJ. The first, you highlighted $3.8 million well cost for the Wells Ranch, 4,500-foot lateral. I just wanted to see go based on the trends in service cost deflation and efficiency gains that you're seeing. And then whether you think as you allocate more capital and drill more wells given the rig efficiencies whether you actually see any upward pressure on the cost as more of the operators seem to be willing to allocate or may be willing to allocate more capital there towards the end of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes. I think, Brian, as you pointed out, we showed a $3.8 million Wells Ranch cost in the case. And that's reflective of what we've been experienced and are experienced here earlier in the first quarter is there room forward to continue to come down
componenttext: Okay. Yes. I think, Brian, as you pointed out, we showed a $3.8 million Wells Ranch cost in the case. And that's reflective of what we've been experienced and are experienced here earlier in the first quarter is there room forward to continue to come down? I'd say probably as we continue to get more efficient. But probably, Gary talking little bit about how he sees that playing out.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I probably feel a little stronger about it than Dave. The $3.8 million is what we had in the budget. We essentially have achieved that by the end of the first quarter. And when you look at other wells that we drilled in Wells Ranch since then, by the
componenttext: Yes. I probably feel a little stronger about it than Dave. The $3.8 million is what we had in the budget. We essentially have achieved that by the end of the first quarter. And when you look at other wells that we drilled in Wells Ranch since then, by the end of April, we were drilling wells as low as $3.4 million, some in the $3.6 million, $3.7 million range, drill and complete and continuing to drive that cost down. So I think one thing worth noting and I think we had it in the notes, but when we talk drilling complete numbers, whether it's the $3.8 million on the side or the $3.4 million that we've done since then, that really is an all-in cost that includes all the pad cost that's allocated to the wells, new facilities allocated to the wells, as well as when we get into areas where there's vertical legacy wells, if any prep work needs to be done on those, that gets allocated back to the wells. So that truly is an all-in costs. I think hitting the $3.4 million in April says a lot about our ability to continue to drive it down, especially as we continue to drive drilling times down to those 5 the records I mentioned on a long length collateral and 7 days on a long length lateral. But the cost savings really coming across the board. It's coming in drilling efficiencies, it's coming in supply cost reductions, it's coming in greater utilization of consolidated facilities. And we're just going to continue to push it. We've got a technical limit case that's actually significantly below $3.4 million even. we're working towards that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say Brian what we've represented is what we've done now on a fairly consistent basis for the first quarter, probably too early to call victory on beneath that yet, but we're getting some very good indications that there's more to come there.
componenttext: I'd say Brian what we've represented is what we've done now on a fairly consistent basis for the first quarter, probably too early to call victory on beneath that yet, but we're getting some very good indications that there's more to come there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then couple months ago, it seems like there's a level of either optimism or hopefulness that there would be some consolidating, consolidation opportunities that may come up. I just wanted to see what the oil price is in valuatio
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then couple months ago, it seems like there's a level of either optimism or hopefulness that there would be some consolidating, consolidation opportunities that may come up. I just wanted to see what the oil price is in valuations higher how you're thinking about that and where you see opportunity.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I mean, I think like everybody, were continuing to keep our eye open. We probably, with some of our realignment of internal resources, we've dedicated some more folks to our business development group to continue to proactively look at what would
componenttext: I mean, I mean, I think like everybody, were continuing to keep our eye open. We probably, with some of our realignment of internal resources, we've dedicated some more folks to our business development group to continue to proactively look at what would be of interest to us. I think as far as anything new, it would have to be something that would have the scale to be in a core area or at the core area and have to be something at that inventory that would compete with inventory we have from an economic development standpoint. So I'm sure like most everybody else, if you got a position of strength like a financial position that we have, you'll continue to look for as there are things that would be accretive to your opportunities, but too early to tell right now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: It's really a reflection of bringing down that rig activity on both sides, the wet gas and the dry gas, for the really the biggest impact that'll be the second half of the year. And with the efficiencies that we continue to gain out there, too, we continue to build up inventory of completions. So it just didn't make sense to continue drilling a lot of wells and stacking up a lot of completions out there at this point in time.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And just one question on the Eastern Mediterranean program. With the added capacity from the Ashdod compression project, realistically, how often do you think you'll be able to take advantage of that additional capacity in other words, do you
componenttext: Okay. Great. And just one question on the Eastern Mediterranean program. With the added capacity from the Ashdod compression project, realistically, how often do you think you'll be able to take advantage of that additional capacity in other words, do you foresee enough domestic demand growth to about 4 more net sales on top of just seasonal peaking needs for air-conditioning in the third quarter?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we saw, I think, quarter-on-quarter, first quarter versus first quarter last year, it was up about 10%. I think as far as truly using all that capacity, it'll just be during peak periods. And that can be peak hours of a day or it can be more in the
componenttext: Well, we saw, I think, quarter-on-quarter, first quarter versus first quarter last year, it was up about 10%. I think as far as truly using all that capacity, it'll just be during peak periods. And that can be peak hours of a day or it can be more in the summer. Third quarter is usually our highest quarter over there. So that's probably when we'd see at the most. The other piece of that that is important for us it provides more capacity for this interruptible volumes once that's worked out and approved and moving forward, so that'll be the knock on effect of it.

So those are the 2 big things, along with the normal seasonal demand decreases we expect and have seen every year in the second quarter in the Eastern Med. So I mean, that's what it's all attributed to. No different than we expected going into the year.

componenttext: Yes. I think we continue to gather data from all the testing we did last year. You'll remember we tested quite a few different completion techniques last year and we're starting to zero in on the ones we are going to implement across the basin for most of this year. I think when you look at our performance, really in the last 6 to 9 months with everything that we tried, we're at/or above the tight curves that we've been expecting to see as we test this downspacing areas. I think it's really pretty much on track right now. We'll continue to look for ways to improve the completions going forward.

And on the capital budget for the year, could you just remind us what your assumption was when you set the budget the terms of service cost reductions and then what you've seen to date and if your plan is to continue to reinvest those savings in completions DJ or is it to keep it on the balance sheet going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we'll have the opportunity continue to drive savings down continue to look at which makes most sense, which creates more value. when you think you look at it, it was -- the $2.9 billion was -- and when we were looking at the budget, we were lookin
componenttext: I mean, we'll have the opportunity continue to drive savings down continue to look at which makes most sense, which creates more value. when you think you look at it, it was -- the $2.9 billion was -- and when we were looking at the budget, we were looking at that relative to a $50 to $55 oil price and we were assuming probably, on a full year basis, around 10%, if I remember right, on the average savings overall on Miocene. And you see a little higher savings that we're seeing on some of the completion part, but you have to look at the total cost. I think it's too early for us to adjust anything yet, which is why we haven't changed our capital outlook for the year. But we'll continue to look at that as we get another quarter under our belt.

componenttext: Gary, in response to Leo's question, you addressed this a little bit but on a follow-up on that. You'd said that you're trying different things in the DJ. And so far, pretty much everything has kind of met your expectations. You are doing a lot of testing on downspacing, particularly in Wells Ranch last year. And I'm just wondering with the slowdown in the drilling activities, does that slowed down that whole downspacing process or are you comfortable saying what the level of spacing is at least in Wells Ranch at this point? I've realized varies across the field. And if you're not ready to say, do you have a time line on how much data you think you need to see before you will be?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: yes, we're not ready to say I say as far as when it will be prior towards the end of this year. I think what I would point out is that we said all 3 last year that we're devoting a large part of that program to testing downspacing at 24 wells per section
componenttext: yes, we're not ready to say I say as far as when it will be prior towards the end of this year. I think what I would point out is that we said all 3 last year that we're devoting a large part of that program to testing downspacing at 24 wells per section and 32 wells per section and then we wanted to get the wells on and really gather some longer-term data. And we have ramped that downspacing program almost down to nothing this year. and that doesn't really have anything to do with the commodity environment. That was the plan all along until we have gathered the data on the pilots that we did last year. So all the resource numbers everything we've ever talked about, location tons for the fields always been based on 16 wells per section. We've talked about we do expect it to be different spacing and different parts of the field. 16 wells per section has an average is certainly still a very good number, a conservative number I think. We see some areas where we do expect it to be greater spacing than that, more than 16 wells. There maybe some areas that are not being less than 16. But still feel very comfortable overall with where we're at.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: I think the other part of that, too, and Gary alluded to the amount of downspacing drilling we did last year that we've been bringing wells on now. we'll start to have a sense of that across, I think it was all initial 5 IDP areas had some downspacing last year. So it's -- we'll get a much larger database here this year to compare and look at beyond just the Wells Ranch area.

componenttext: I think we're still early in the cycle, right? I think, as I mentioned earlier, we'll continue to focus on what would make sense to add to the portfolio, but it has to be accretive from the standpoint that it'd be an opportunity that had running room and inventory that competes with our current inventory because we've got a nice inventory already out there. I think the benefit is then part of the benefit, both for looking at opportunities and being able to accelerate our own when you got a deep portfolio is maintaining that financial strength.
