headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joshua. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued our earnings release and also posted to our website a few supplemental slides for this call.
componenttext:
Thanks, Joshua. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Noble Energy's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call and Webcast. This morning, we issued our earnings release and also posted to our website a few supplemental slides for this call. Later this morning, our 10-Q will be available. Following the remarks by Dave Stover, we'll open the call for Q&A with the executive team and wrap things up in less than an hour.
Finally, I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as references non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those.
With that, let me turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm extremely pleased with how Noble Energy has performed in the early part of 2015. This is highlighted by our production, which has been very strong across the board. And whil
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I'm extremely pleased with how Noble Energy has performed in the early part of 2015. This is highlighted by our production, which has been very strong across the board. And while still early, we're confident enough to raise our full year volume outlook. Our successes also include improving capital efficiency and reducing operating costs. And results so far this year are right where we expect it, if not a little better. Another major accomplishment was gaining alignment with our partner in the Marcellus to reduce our activity levels. And in the DJ Basin, strong results and continued operational efficiencies are driving additional capital allocation in the second half of the year.
Starting off with sales volumes. We sold a record 318,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter, an increase of 17% over the same period last year after adjusting for asset sales. Full year sales are now expected to average between 300,000 and 315,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day as we have raised the bottom end of our range by 5,000 barrels equivalent per day. This updated range now reflects the first quarter outperformance while maintaining our prior expectations for the remaining quarters of the year.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, core U.S. onshore sales volumes increased more than 35%, driven by record production in both the DJ Basin and Marcellus Shale. Horizontal production in these 2 plays was up a combined 60% versus the same time period. Offshore, including the Gulf of Mexico and our International businesses, volumes were relatively flat with the first quarter of last year after adjusting for asset sales. 
Our offshore assets continue to perform very well with world-class run time and lower-than-expected decline rates. Highlighting this performance is nearly 100% run time at both Tamar offshore Israel and Aseng in Equatorial Guinea. It's the combination of these high-quality, low-cost assets and managing a diversified portfolio that continues to provide Noble a competitive advantage. Our U.S. onshore development, major project execution and exploration capabilities provide material resource opportunities and tremendous investment optionality.
As mentioned earlier, we have made substantial progress towards lowering both our capital and operating costs. We've worked closely with our suppliers to achieve an average of 20% savings, seen most prominently in our U.S. onshore business. Our suppliers have moved quickly to assist in adjusting our cost structure, and we continue to work with them in partnership to ensure these early achievements are turned into sustainable cost improvements.
Highlighting our production cost reduction was lease operating expense, which is already down $0.50 per barrel from the fourth quarter, a material change in such a short period of time and putting us on track to meet our full year average expectation. General and administrative costs are down from previous quarters as well. We've also recently completed an organizational realignment, which better positions our workforce for this current environment.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were a little over $900 million, slightly below our internal expectations and trending lower as we move through the year. Total capital for 2015 remains $2.9 billion with $1.8 billion allocated to the onshore U.S. business. The DJ Basin has increased to more than 60% of the onshore U.S. amount with Marcellus now representing slightly less than 40%.
Focusing on our DJ operations. Growth in the first quarter exhibited our strong operating capacity. Total volumes were a record 116,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 22% versus the first quarter of last year. Growth in the horizontal program was even more impressive, up more than 50% over the last year and more than 110% the last 2 years.
Slide 4 highlights continued drilling efficiencies being delivered by our teams. And as you can see, we're now averaging 7 days from spud-to-rig release for a standard lateral length well, almost as fast as we used to drill vertical wells. In fact, we recently drilled a 9,300-foot horizontal well in Wells Ranch in just 7 days. Compared to last year, we're drilling 70% of the total footage while utilizing 40% of the rig count. This is a result of our focus on drilling execution, utilizing the best rigs and crews in the basin and continuing to increase our average lateral lengths per well.
Reduced drilling times are resulting in an increased number of wells that can be completed this year. And we are reallocating some capital here to keep up with the drilling pace, supplementing our one full-time completion crew with a second completion crew in the second half of the year. These efficiencies, along with supplier cost reductions, are driving a downward trend in our well cost. Based on today's drilling and completion costs, we're already meeting our budgeted well cost expectations for the year. 
We have highlighted on Slide 5 a $3.8 million Wells Ranch well. Our overall cost reductions from 2014 include 5% to 15% sustainable cost savings from continuing to reduce drilling times and optimizing equipment usage and a range of 15% to 25% savings from our major suppliers. It is worth noting that the these well costs are all-in and include items that such as pad construction and associated facilities costs. And we have opportunities continue to drive cost down further. Using slickwater for fracs in certain parts of the basin may allow us to save an additional $100,000 to $200,000 per well on a standardized length lateral. We recently brought online 11 wells in East Pony that were completed with slickwater. And these wells are performing at/or above expectations.
Third-party infrastructure uptime improved at the start of the year. And I am pleased with the progress of the expansion projects that are currently underway. The Lucerne-2 plant and additional compressor stations are on track for start-up in late second quarter, providing a material increase in processing and compression capacity on the DCP system. The Grand Parkway low-pressure loop has been approved and is expected to start up by the end of the year, which will have a positive impact on the performance of legacy vertical wells and earlier horizontal wells.
Operating performance in the Marcellus Shale remains exceptional as well. And our production grew 73% versus the first quarter of last year to nearly 400 million cubic feet equivalent per day. Similar to the DJ Basin, we're seeing substantial reduction in drilling times and lower well cost through a combination of utilizing top hole rigs, drilling longer laterals and supplier cost reductions. 
Improvements in drilling times have resulted in a larger inventory of uncompleted wells than we had originally anticipated in both the operated and nonoperated areas of the Marcellus. This affords us the opportunity to reduce rig count in the second half of the year to 1 operated rig and 2 nonoperated rigs while still meeting our planned completion and production goals. Overall, this is a $200 million net reduction to our prior Marcellus expectations. We continue to diversify our natural gas markets and recently began transporting approximately 100 million cubic feet per day of gas out of the basin, including our first sales into Gulf Coast markets. This firm transportation has a relatively low overall cost and gives us further access to better-priced markets.
Moving offshore. We achieved a number of key milestones on our major projects in the Gulf of Mexico during the first quarter. At Rio Grande, all drilling and completion operations are now complete and pipeline installation is scheduled to begin in the second quarter. Rio Grande remains on schedule for first production in the fourth quarter. Development drilling operations at Gunflint are underway and are expected to continue throughout the remainder of 2015. Pipeline installation will commence following the Rio Grande installation and first production from Gunflint remains on schedule for mid-2016. Our Gulf of Mexico projects highlight the benefits of our diverse portfolio by providing strong oil growth exiting 2015 with another step-up in 2016. The cash margins for these projects are very competitive with U.S. onshore resource plays, evident by nearly all of the production being oil and priced at a premium to WTI, combined with attractive production costs.
Moving to the Eastern Mediterranean. Tamar continues to exhibit exceptional reliability and set new milestones for delivery, achieving a record weekly gross sales average of over 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day, driven by seasonal demand and coal plant maintenance. A recently signed agreement to supply interruptible sales of up to 250 million cubic feet per day gross from Tamar to Egypt's domestic market is another example of the strong regional demand for our natural gas. We and our customer are now working to finalize regulatory approvals and transportation agreements needed to start sales. We believe these can be included in the next few months, setting us up for initial sales later in 2015 by utilizing existing infrastructure. Once we have those approvals, we will provide an outlook for sales and adjust our production guidance at that time.
During the first quarter, we received regulatory approval for export sales to the Arab Potash Company and Jordan Bromine Company in Jordan. While a relatively small volume, this does represent the first formally approved regional export of natural gas from Israel and sets forward a path for additional agreements to follow. Meanwhile, we continue to work very intently to establish a comprehensive framework for energy development. Our teams are meeting regularly with the interministerial group established by the Prime Minister's Office for this purpose. And we are encouraged by their efforts to create a sustainable investment climate for energy development in Israel. Early progress has been made, and we look forward to working with the new government. Resolution about standing regulatory matters, including antitrust concerns and export taxation, along with a comprehensive framework for energy development, is still necessary to enable additional project development. We believe the interministerial working group is on track to achieve this objective over the next few months following the seating of the new government.
In Cyprus, we're working closely with the government and plan to submit a preliminary field development plan in the near future. Our Cyprus discovery can be another important contributor toward meeting regional gas demand. We've begun export marketing activities and are greatly encouraged by the level of interest expressed by potential counterparties, not only for gas purchases but also regarding participating in export infrastructure investment. 
Also within our offshore business, you can certainly feel the exploration excitement around our office as we're nearing a very impactful 2015 drilling program. In West Africa, we recently signed a rig contract for the Cheetah exploration prospect in Cameroon and expect this low-cost well to spud early in the third quarter. Cheetah represents our first Cretaceous test in the Douala Basin and has a main resource size in excess of 100 million barrels of oil equivalent gross. A sizable discovery at Cheetah would deliver a very attractive development in less than 100 feet of water depth, where we can move very quickly to first production.
By the end of the second quarter, we anticipate commencing drilling offshore of the Falkland Islands, where we plan to drill 2 exploration wells this year. Our first prospect, Humpback, which we operate with a 35% interest, has a gross main resource size of over 250 million barrels of oil. If successful, Humpback would derisk other large prospects shown on Slide 10 that have cumulative gross resource potential in excess of 1 billion barrels of oil. We recently farmed into the Rhea prospect, also with 250 million barrels of oil potential, which will be our second exploration well in the Falkland Islands. Adding the Rhea opportunity further diversifies our exploration inventory and enhances our overall chance of success as it offsets other oil discoveries in the basin. The prospect is anticipated the spud by year end. We operate Rhea and currently have a 75% working interest.
Let me now provide some insight into our volume profile throughout the year. As mentioned earlier, we've not made any production guidance changes to the remaining quarters. Second quarter sales volumes are anticipated to range between 290,000 and 300,000 barrels of oil per day, impacted by planned facility maintenance and turnarounds in West Africa and the Gulf of Mexico, along with the usual seasonal demand softness for Israel volumes. Further sales are expected to build in the second half of the year with strong seasonal demand in Israel in the third quarter followed by new oil volumes from the start-up of our major projects in the Gulf of Mexico in the fourth quarter. Our diversified portfolio is setting us up to exit 2015 on a nice trajectory. 
So in summary, we're off to a strong start this year. Performance on volumes, capital efficiency and costs is where we expect it, if not a little better -- not a little bit better at this point. And we're on a path approaching cash flow neutrality around mid-year as we anticipated.
So Joshua, at this time, we'd like to go ahead and open the call to questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys delivered impressive drilling efficiencies in the Wattenberg and Eagle Ford in the first quarter. I guess, 2 questions. What do you see is the scope there to improve efficiencies further? And secondly, how are you planning to preserve those effic
componenttext: You guys delivered impressive drilling efficiencies in the Wattenberg and Eagle Ford in the first quarter. I guess, 2 questions. What do you see is the scope there to improve efficiencies further? And secondly, how are you planning to preserve those efficiencies as activity increases, and then an off cycle? So that would appear that's more of a secular benefit than cyclical, like service cost benefits you're enjoying today.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, Evan, it's good to point out that the efficiencies are continuing to improve. And I don't think we're done there. I'll have Gary Willingham talk a little bit about his view up there. But I've been extremely impressed and pleased with what the t
componenttext: Well, yes, Evan, it's good to point out that the efficiencies are continuing to improve. And I don't think we're done there. I'll have Gary Willingham talk a little bit about his view up there. But I've been extremely impressed and pleased with what the team has done by concentrating on each aspect of the drilling cycle, if you will. I mean, if you think about it now, we've actually drilled long laterals in the same time that we used to drill vertical wells 4 to 5 years ago, so it's been a remarkable improvement. But I'll get let Gary talk about what he sees as far as trajectory this year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, when you look at the slide on Page 4, you can see the improvement over time and especially focusing on that spud-to-rig release curve, how that's continued to come down over time. So we were able to do that even in a much higher commodity price
componenttext: Yes, Evan, when you look at the slide on Page 4, you can see the improvement over time and especially focusing on that spud-to-rig release curve, how that's continued to come down over time. So we were able to do that even in a much higher commodity price environment obviously. I think some of the recent performance improvement we've seen to be fair is we're running 4 rigs and we tended to keep the 4 best rigs out of the 10. But I think that's a fairly small part of the improvement that we've seen. Most of it comes from just a continuing focus on how can we make each little part of the drilling process better. And as Dave mentioned, while we average to 7 days for normal length laterals in the first quarter in the DJ, we also drilled a 9,300-foot well in 7 days. Now we also drilled a normal length lateral well in 5 days in East Pony. So that gives us confidence that there's still more improvement to come. And that's what we'll be chasing over the next quarters.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And my second question, given you and CNX have reduced activity in the Marcellus, how do you consider reallocating capital into the Niobrara beyond the completion crew added? And just maybe more broadly, many companies have cited various approaches
componenttext: Great. And my second question, given you and CNX have reduced activity in the Marcellus, how do you consider reallocating capital into the Niobrara beyond the completion crew added? And just maybe more broadly, many companies have cited various approaches into a commodity price recovery with some looking to balance sheet repair earlier, adding rigs in the back half of the year. How do you anticipate responding in an improved commodity price environment? I'll leave it at that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, for now, for '15, we're really still looking at just 4 rigs. So the capital that we're shifting from the Marcellus to the DJ, we're using that to kind of back-end load those 4 rigs that we've already got because again we're drilling wells a l
componenttext: Yes, I mean, for now, for '15, we're really still looking at just 4 rigs. So the capital that we're shifting from the Marcellus to the DJ, we're using that to kind of back-end load those 4 rigs that we've already got because again we're drilling wells a lot faster. So that kind of back-end loads those rigs and provides for a few more completions this year. Most of those completions, incremental completions will be in 2016.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then that's regardless of what the commodity looks like in the back half of the year? So you're pretty set for this year? Or is it responsive or reflective of that environment?
componenttext: And then that's regardless of what the commodity looks like in the back half of the year? So you're pretty set for this year? Or is it responsive or reflective of that environment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say at this point, it's too early to change anything for the year. I mean, the one change that you've noted is that we brought down the capital spending and working with our partner in the Marcellus. And then as Gary pointed out with the efficien
componenttext: Yes, I'd say at this point, it's too early to change anything for the year. I mean, the one change that you've noted is that we brought down the capital spending and working with our partner in the Marcellus. And then as Gary pointed out with the efficiencies of these 4 rigs and just assuming we stay at 4 rigs this year in the DJ, we're going to drill more wells. And now we're going to allocate more money to completion, so we'll come out of the year putting ourselves in, I'd say, even a better position heading into '16 there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, if I may. There's a comment in the press release about the efficiency gains in the DJ will result to more wells this year than perhaps you originally planned. So I guess, I have kind of 2 questions around that. One is why continue t
componenttext: A couple of questions, if I may. There's a comment in the press release about the efficiency gains in the DJ will result to more wells this year than perhaps you originally planned. So I guess, I have kind of 2 questions around that. One is why continue to drill in this -- I guess, it's an improving environment we're in. But why continue to drill when some of your peers are deferring completions? What's your take on that? And secondly, how does it change the mix of those incremental wells between long laterals and, I guess, your standard length wells? And I've got a quick follow-up, please.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll start with that. But I'd say where we are right now, and as Gary has pointed out, we continue to get more and more efficient with these 4 rigs, And I would expect we could continue to see that trend this year. So we've kind of got a base loa
componenttext: Yes. And I'll start with that. But I'd say where we are right now, and as Gary has pointed out, we continue to get more and more efficient with these 4 rigs, And I would expect we could continue to see that trend this year. So we've kind of got a base load of operation now between what we're focusing on at East Pony and Wells Ranch with this rig activity, with this 4-rig activity. And what is enabling us to do now is to bring more wells ready for -- more wells will have drilled by the end of year and more wells ready to complete by the end of the year, which I think will give us some very nice momentum as we exit this year and look towards 2016. So it just gives us a lot more capacity with what we can do there as we continue to gain efficiency. And I think that part of that efficiency is driven by focusing on this continued improvement with these 4 rigs and with these dedicated crews that we have up there. Gary, another view?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, the only thing I would add to your point on how does it change the mix of ERLs, we'd be looking at increasing our spud count this year by probably about 15% in the DJ. I think those incremental wells that will be targeted towards year end will be roug
componenttext: No, the only thing I would add to your point on how does it change the mix of ERLs, we'd be looking at increasing our spud count this year by probably about 15% in the DJ. I think those incremental wells that will be targeted towards year end will be roughly the same, 50% ERLs that we've got in the budget. But if it's off from that much, it's not going to change the annual average that much either way.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the answer. Dave, my follow-up, I guess, is, I guess, pretty standard question around the regulatory situation in Israel. I think you'd suggested that postelection, things were perhaps looking a little bit more promising in terms of get
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the answer. Dave, my follow-up, I guess, is, I guess, pretty standard question around the regulatory situation in Israel. I think you'd suggested that postelection, things were perhaps looking a little bit more promising in terms of getting going again on Leviathan forward sales and so on. Any update you can share to the extent you can? And I'll leave it at that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think the main thing while they've been going through their election cycle and pulling the new government together, the works continued behind the scenes with this interministerial committee. And I think we've been very pleased with the progress we'
componenttext: No, I think the main thing while they've been going through their election cycle and pulling the new government together, the works continued behind the scenes with this interministerial committee. And I think we've been very pleased with the progress we've seen, especially the focus on coming up with what we've talked about, this comprehensive solution, this kind of roadmap, the sanction, if you will. And so I've been very pleased with the progress we've seen and the commitment to getting this thing ready so that we can start back up as things develop here. And part of the reality of it is the new government is going to have to get in place, going to have to get seated. But the real positive part of that is nobody is waiting or has been waiting for that. Everybody has been working diligently to address the things that need to be addressed, so they can put this comprehensive framework together. I can ask Keith. Keith has been the one here, Keith Elliott here, that's been more intimately involved with it than me. And he can give you his feel for his outlook on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Doug, that the -- my sense is that the government through the formation of the interministerial committee is really reflecting the recognition that the establishment of this investment framework, a framework that lends itself to companies, o
componenttext: Yes. I think, Doug, that the -- my sense is that the government through the formation of the interministerial committee is really reflecting the recognition that the establishment of this investment framework, a framework that lends itself to companies, ourselves and other players, new entrants into the basin, get providing that sort of stable and attractive investment climate, just leads us to be optimistic that they're going to deliver a solution in a reasonable time frame here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, the sales contracts that you had already -- the LOIs, I guess, that you had already signed, are they still good? And obviously, they're on hold. But would you be able to go back to those in fairly quick order? Or have they been completely shelved un
componenttext: Guys, the sales contracts that you had already -- the LOIs, I guess, that you had already signed, are they still good? And obviously, they're on hold. But would you be able to go back to those in fairly quick order? Or have they been completely shelved until you get clarity?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to be engaged with all of those potential customers. We're engaged with them on an ongoing basis. The LOIs are either in place or extensions have been agreed. And all parties really continue to be very prepared to move toward consummation of t
componenttext: We continue to be engaged with all of those potential customers. We're engaged with them on an ongoing basis. The LOIs are either in place or extensions have been agreed. And all parties really continue to be very prepared to move toward consummation of these contracts once we can get the regulatory framework in place. I mean, I think the thing is, and Dave alluded to it in his comments, the thing that I would just call out is there really is a fundamental supply-demand imbalance that the resources in Israel and Cyprus can really lend themselves to helping to address. And I think that hasn't been lost on any of the potential buyers.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Real quickly, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you thought the decrease in service cost could be sustained over time. Can you give us some more color on that, specifically to the cost reductions, not necessarily the efficiency gains? And are y
componenttext: Real quickly, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you thought the decrease in service cost could be sustained over time. Can you give us some more color on that, specifically to the cost reductions, not necessarily the efficiency gains? And are you looking at locking down some of the service cost going forward in the form of contracts or anything like that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that gets all back to how we're working with our major service providers. And I think the way we look at it is this is a partnership. It's not about just beating costs down, but it's a partnership on how do we do business, not only for now b
componenttext: Well, I think that gets all back to how we're working with our major service providers. And I think the way we look at it is this is a partnership. It's not about just beating costs down, but it's a partnership on how do we do business, not only for now but going forward in a way that we can make this more economical for all of us. And so a lot of discussion, when you look at actually with contracting and a lot of that's on an annual basis on some of our major suppliers, it can be a little longer than that on some of this. So we'll put in place some of that. But we're looking at the combination of service cost and what else can we do just from improved efficiency on some of this and a combination of those to lock in a lower cost profile, if you will, for longer term here. But it's -- back to Gary's point earlier, it's working on all aspects of that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, appreciate that. And then one of the things I know I've talked to you guys about in the past but service companies are highlighting, and that's the ability to go back and refrac wells, which at this juncture, some people are posing that, that could
componenttext: Okay, appreciate that. And then one of the things I know I've talked to you guys about in the past but service companies are highlighting, and that's the ability to go back and refrac wells, which at this juncture, some people are posing that, that could be a significant driver to higher rates of return obviously for lower capital spending. How are you guys thinking about that in the Wattenberg at this juncture? And how are you studying that currently?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you would expect, especially up in Wattenberg and the DJ Basin, we've had a long history and our predecessors had a long history of utilizing existing wellbores, especially in the vertical world, where they were -- we had been in the mode of refr
componenttext: Well, as you would expect, especially up in Wattenberg and the DJ Basin, we've had a long history and our predecessors had a long history of utilizing existing wellbores, especially in the vertical world, where they were -- we had been in the mode of refracs and even trifracs. So there's a lot of history there. I think in the horizontal world, obviously it poses some other complexities, if you will, with using the long lateral, especially on long lateral lengths. But we did a few up there previously. We've also done a few in the Marcellus. And I think it's probably going to take a little more time. The ones we initially did were probably in areas that hadn't performed as well initially. So we saw some benefit from that. The real test will be when we start, at some point, trying to do this in areas that have had very good results. But after 3 or 4 years or so, like we did in the vertical program, you start to look at can you go back in and bust open some more rock and get some more incremental recovery. I think, David, it's just part of what's in the toolbox of things we're looking at as to how we take the percent recovery from single digit to double digits up there in the basin. And I don't know, Gary, anything else on that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think as Dave said, we've done some in both places, the Marcellus, we did some refracs as well as some reperforating on some older wells and had some very nice results on those, where the production rates came back up to actually the initial rates o
componenttext: No. I think as Dave said, we've done some in both places, the Marcellus, we did some refracs as well as some reperforating on some older wells and had some very nice results on those, where the production rates came back up to actually the initial rates of the wells. DJ, we've done a number, results have been a bit more mixed there. Being able to mechanically isolate the fracs has remained the big issue there. You've seen a lot of talk recently around different means of diverting. We've tried some of those. We're not really ready to comment on the results yet. We're also working on a couple of other ideas that I haven't seen mentioned too much publicly. So we'll continue to chase a few things. I think this is something that eventually a lot of smart engineers in the industry will figure out how to fix it and create a whole another way of opportunity in these fields.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, appreciate that. One last one if I can just sneak it in. How are you guys thinking about hedging in '16 at this juncture with the movement we've seen in the forward strip?
componenttext: Okay, appreciate that. One last one if I can just sneak it in. How are you guys thinking about hedging in '16 at this juncture with the movement we've seen in the forward strip?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've got some volume hedged in '16. I think it's, what, 25%?
componenttext: We've got some volume hedged in '16. I think it's, what, 25%?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: 29%, David. I think the way our hedging program has been very successful over time in that we try to average in. So we'll set up a plan rate, and then we'll watch the market and go slowly. So that's allowed us to be well-hedged through time. And we've had
componenttext: 29%, David. I think the way our hedging program has been very successful over time in that we try to average in. So we'll set up a plan rate, and then we'll watch the market and go slowly. So that's allowed us to be well-hedged through time. And we've had big hedge settlements in '09, big positive hedge settlements in '09, and of course, this year and again '16, depending on how things play out. At the same time, we haven't given up much headroom, had negative settlements of any note. So the program has been effective, and we'll continue to do it, current year plus 2 and typically about 50% of the volume and average in.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we'll continue to look for opportunities in an upswing in commodity market. But as Ken said, the target is 50% on global oil and 50% on U.S. gas is kind of what we hold ourselves to.
componenttext: I mean, we'll continue to look for opportunities in an upswing in commodity market. But as Ken said, the target is 50% on global oil and 50% on U.S. gas is kind of what we hold ourselves to.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll move on to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And next, we'll move on to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could ask a question on the DJ. We see 8% sequential production growth there quarter-over-quarter. I think that's the highest we've seen in a while. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether that's maybe the beginning of a trend we see
componenttext: I wonder if I could ask a question on the DJ. We see 8% sequential production growth there quarter-over-quarter. I think that's the highest we've seen in a while. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether that's maybe the beginning of a trend we see as you kind of unload the spring and get the midstream debottlenecked or maybe if it's more reflective of kind of a reduced operational pace, and so kind of reduced offset well shut-ins from fracs. And can you kind of give us a sense of the bigger picture there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Charles, I appreciate it. I think it was a big quarter in the DJ. Obviously, I think we benefited some from coming off the activity levels late last year, which we actually dropped or reduced from 10 rigs late last year into starting this year off o
componenttext: Well, Charles, I appreciate it. I think it was a big quarter in the DJ. Obviously, I think we benefited some from coming off the activity levels late last year, which we actually dropped or reduced from 10 rigs late last year into starting this year off or, say, starting this year off here in the first quarter, moving down to 4 on that. So we'll see that change a little bit. Gary can talk a little bit of how he sees the year laying out as we go through the year. And we still have some of the big processing facility to come on here in the end of the second quarter, too, which will impact things.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't attribute any of it really or much of it to lower activity levels and less offset shut-ins with fracs. As you probably remember, a lot of our completions in 2014 were towards the back-end loaded, so a lot of wells came on late in 4Q and we
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't attribute any of it really or much of it to lower activity levels and less offset shut-ins with fracs. As you probably remember, a lot of our completions in 2014 were towards the back-end loaded, so a lot of wells came on late in 4Q and we certainly got an uplift from that in the first quarter of this year. We have dropped down from the 10 rigs to the 4 rigs. So we're working off that completion backlog that we brought into the year as well. I think when you look at our profile through the year, we expect 1Q to be the highest, be fairly flat maybe through the first half, and then start to decline in the second half as we get back into more of an equilibrium that you would expect with only running the 4 rigs. Now what it remains to be seen on top of that is how much an uplift we truly get from the start-up of the Lucerne-2 gas plant that DCP is bringing on in June. That's a $200 million a day plant. We would certainly expect to see some recovery from our legacy program, the vertical wells, the older horizontal wells from reduced pressures when that plant comes on. We've got a little bit of that baked into the plan, but we couldn't see more than that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And don't forget, as we talked on the last call, we've kind of level-loaded our completions here for the year. And so as we get more completions later in the year, as I mentioned earlier, that actually helps us on next year's volume.
componenttext: And don't forget, as we talked on the last call, we've kind of level-loaded our completions here for the year. And so as we get more completions later in the year, as I mentioned earlier, that actually helps us on next year's volume.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That makes sense, Dave. And Gary, that's good detail on what you guys have kind of -- that you have a portion of the Lucerne portion -- actually, I guess, I should say the possible Lucerne uplift baked in. Dave, if I could get you to go back to ta
componenttext: Got it. That makes sense, Dave. And Gary, that's good detail on what you guys have kind of -- that you have a portion of the Lucerne portion -- actually, I guess, I should say the possible Lucerne uplift baked in. Dave, if I could get you to go back to talk about the Eastern Med. And I recognize that maybe you guys don't want to go into too much detail. But I'm going to try see if we can maybe get a little more out of you. So you've got -- I recognize that they haven't seated the new parliament and haven't worked out the new coalition and that sort of thing. But maybe you could talk a bit about how you got this finalized agreement because it seems like -- and I know this news came out a little bit earlier. But that to me, seems like, while it's not a big deal, it's an important hurdle that you now have exports approved to go out of the country. But kind of how did that come together in the absence of a seated parliament? And how should we -- does that have any implications for what the process looks like for your interruptible Egypt agreement?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good connection there, Charles. I'd say that yes, even though it is a small volume, it is important from the standpoint that it was the first real export agreement. So we had a chance to work through the process, if you will, and get some of the kinks out
componenttext: Good connection there, Charles. I'd say that yes, even though it is a small volume, it is important from the standpoint that it was the first real export agreement. So we had a chance to work through the process, if you will, and get some of the kinks out in that process on how you approach that and how you get an approval of that type of thing. So for that first agreement over there to Jordan, probably Keith can expand on that a little more since he has been closer to it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, I think with respect to the Arab Potash, Jordan Bromine agreement that you're referring to, that really is a result of ongoing engagement with the government really over a period of probably 1 year, 1.5 years, where we've been pursuing reall
componenttext: Yes, Charles, I think with respect to the Arab Potash, Jordan Bromine agreement that you're referring to, that really is a result of ongoing engagement with the government really over a period of probably 1 year, 1.5 years, where we've been pursuing really implementation of the export policy that the government established back in 2012 and 2013 time frame. So a number of these things are within the control of specific ministries. And so this is a case in point where it's completely within the remit of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources. Others are more complex that require the alignment across ministries. And that's really been the benefit that we've seen in this interministerial working group. It's caused a number of ministries that typically don't work as closely together as might be needed to create the kind of framework that investors look for. It's provided a venue for those groups to work together. And that's been the real positive thing, I think, that's come out of this for us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But I think the second part of your question, does it help with setting a pathway for the interruptible contract approval by the governments, and actually both governments, Israel and Egypt, for that? And I think it does help with that. And that's one we'
componenttext: But I think the second part of your question, does it help with setting a pathway for the interruptible contract approval by the governments, and actually both governments, Israel and Egypt, for that? And I think it does help with that. And that's one we're continuing to keep our eye on and push because we think that could be another very important milestone, if you will, in how things are progressing over there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Because -- and just to sneak this in, David, because that would establish a precedent for Israeli exports to Egypt, even though it's via an existing pipeline network. And so if you get that in place, then presumably you've got one big hurdle down o
componenttext: Right. Because -- and just to sneak this in, David, because that would establish a precedent for Israeli exports to Egypt, even though it's via an existing pipeline network. And so if you get that in place, then presumably you've got one big hurdle down on the idea of getting Leviathan gas through some new offshore pipeline to Egypt?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Because then you would've had approvals on contracts, precedent contracts, if you will, to both neighboring countries that are also going to be important for Leviathan.
componenttext: Right. Because then you would've had approvals on contracts, precedent contracts, if you will, to both neighboring countries that are also going to be important for Leviathan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on the DJ. The first, you've highlighted $3.8 million well cost for the Wells Ranch, 4,500-foot lateral. I just wanted to see where you think that can go based on the trends in service cost deflation and efficiency gains that you're
componenttext: A couple of questions on the DJ. The first, you've highlighted $3.8 million well cost for the Wells Ranch, 4,500-foot lateral. I just wanted to see where you think that can go based on the trends in service cost deflation and efficiency gains that you're seeing, and then whether you think as you allocate more capital and drill more wells, given the rig efficiencies, whether you actually see any upward pressure on cost as more of the operators seem to be willing to allocate or may be willing to allocate more capital there towards the end of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I think, Brian, as you pointed out, we showed a $3.8 million Wells Ranch cost and case. And that's reflective of what we've been experienced and experienced here earlier in the first quarter. Is there room for it to continue to come down? I'd s
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I think, Brian, as you pointed out, we showed a $3.8 million Wells Ranch cost and case. And that's reflective of what we've been experienced and experienced here earlier in the first quarter. Is there room for it to continue to come down? I'd say probably as we continue to get more efficient. But it's probably worth Gary talking a little bit about how he sees that playing out.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd probably feel a little even stronger about it than Dave. The $3.8 million is what we had in the budget. We essentially have achieved that by the end of the first quarter. And when you look at other wells that we've drilled in the Wells Ranch sinc
componenttext: Yes, I'd probably feel a little even stronger about it than Dave. The $3.8 million is what we had in the budget. We essentially have achieved that by the end of the first quarter. And when you look at other wells that we've drilled in the Wells Ranch since then, by the end of April, we were drilling wells as low as $3.4 million, some in the $3.6 million, $3.7 million range.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is drill and complete.
componenttext: This is drill and complete.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Drill and complete, yes, and continuing to drive that cost down. So I think one thing worth noting, and I think we had it in the notes, but when we talk drill and complete numbers, whether it's the $3.8 million on the slide or the $3.4 million that we've
componenttext: Drill and complete, yes, and continuing to drive that cost down. So I think one thing worth noting, and I think we had it in the notes, but when we talk drill and complete numbers, whether it's the $3.8 million on the slide or the $3.4 million that we've done since then, that really is an all-in cost. That includes all the pad costs that's allocated to the wells, new facilities allocated to the wells as well as when we get into areas where there's vertical legacy wells, if any prep work needs to be done on those, that gets allocated back to the wells. So that truly is an all-in cost. I think hitting the $3.4 million in April says a lot about our ability to continue to drive it down, especially as we continue to drive drilling times down to those 5-day records I mentioned on a normal length lateral and 7 days on a long length lateral. But the cost savings is really coming across the board. It's coming in drilling efficiencies, it's coming in supply cost reductions, it's coming in greater utilization of consolidated facilities. And we're just going to continue to push it. We've got a technical limit case that's actually significantly below the $3.4 million even, and we're working towards that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'd say, Brian, where we are and we've represented is what we've done now on a fairly consistent basis for the first quarter, probably too early to call victory on beneath that yet. But we're getting some very good indications that there's more to come
componenttext: So I'd say, Brian, where we are and we've represented is what we've done now on a fairly consistent basis for the first quarter, probably too early to call victory on beneath that yet. But we're getting some very good indications that there's more to come there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And then a couple months ago, it seemed like there was a level of either optimism or hopefulness that there would be some consolidation opportunities that may come up. I just wanted to see with the oil price is, the valuation is hig
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And then a couple months ago, it seemed like there was a level of either optimism or hopefulness that there would be some consolidation opportunities that may come up. I just wanted to see with the oil price is, the valuation is higher, how you're thinking about that and where you see opportunity.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think like everybody, we're continuing to keep our eye open. We probably with some of our realignment of internal resources, we've dedicated some more folks to our business development group to continue to proactively look at what would be of in
componenttext: I mean, I think like everybody, we're continuing to keep our eye open. We probably with some of our realignment of internal resources, we've dedicated some more folks to our business development group to continue to proactively look at what would be of interest to us. I think as far as anything new, it would have to be something that would have the scale to be in a core area or add to a core area and have to be something had an inventory that would compete with the inventory we have from an economic development standpoint. So I'm sure like most everybody else, if you've got a position of strength like a financial position that we have, you'll continue to look for as there are things that would be accretive to your opportunity set but too early to tell right now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: I just had a quick question on the Marcellus. So just want to make sure I understand, the $200 million net reduction in capital, is that just effectively deferring new spuds because you've reiterated your completion count and production volumes for the region in 2015?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really a reflection of bringing down that rig activity on both sides, the wet gas and the dry gas, for the -- really the biggest impact to that will be the second half of the year. And with the efficiencies that we've continued to gain out there, too
componenttext: It's really a reflection of bringing down that rig activity on both sides, the wet gas and the dry gas, for the -- really the biggest impact to that will be the second half of the year. And with the efficiencies that we've continued to gain out there, too, we continue to build up the inventory of completions. So it just didn't make sense to continue drilling a lot of wells and stacking up a lot of completions out there at this point in time.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary. It's primarily on the drilling side. I think we've reduced our new wells online in the Marcellus by about 4 wells for the year. So it's pretty immaterial, mostly on the drilling side.
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary. It's primarily on the drilling side. I think we've reduced our new wells online in the Marcellus by about 4 wells for the year. So it's pretty immaterial, mostly on the drilling side.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just one question on the Eastern Mediterranean program, with the added capacity from the Ashdod compression project, realistically, how often do you think you'll be able to take advantage of that additional capacity? In other words, do yo
componenttext: Okay, great. And just one question on the Eastern Mediterranean program, with the added capacity from the Ashdod compression project, realistically, how often do you think you'll be able to take advantage of that additional capacity? In other words, do you foresee enough domestic demand growth to allow for more net sales on top of just seasonal peaking needs for air-conditioning in the third quarter?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we saw, I think, quarter-on-quarter, first quarter versus first quarter last year, it was up about 10%. I think as far as truly using all that capacity, it will just be during peak periods. And that can be peak hours of a day or it can be more in th
componenttext: Well, we saw, I think, quarter-on-quarter, first quarter versus first quarter last year, it was up about 10%. I think as far as truly using all that capacity, it will just be during peak periods. And that can be peak hours of a day or it can be more in the summer. The third quarter is usually our highest quarter over there. So that's probably when we'll see it the most. The other piece of that, that is important for us is it provides more capacity for these interruptible volumes once that's worked out and approved and moving forward. So that will be the knock-on effect of it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: And next, we'll move on to Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: I was hoping you could speak to well cost in the Marcellus. You talked a lot about DJ. But can you give us a sense of what type of cost you're seeing today, both on an operated and nonoperated basis and the improvements you've seen?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Gary, do you want to provide any color on that?
componenttext: Okay. Gary, do you want to provide any color on that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our drill and complete in the Marcellus is it varies obviously across the basin. But average is probably about $8 million, $7 million to $8 million for a 7,000-foot lateral, 8,000-foot lateral in that range. It's pretty much $1 million per 1,
componenttext: Yes, I think our drill and complete in the Marcellus is it varies obviously across the basin. But average is probably about $8 million, $7 million to $8 million for a 7,000-foot lateral, 8,000-foot lateral in that range. It's pretty much $1 million per 1,000-foot of lateral is the way to think about it right now.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, obviously, you guys made a conscious effort on a decision here with your partner to reduce activity. I'm imagining that probably part of that was due to weak gas prices that we're experiencing here. Can you talk at all a
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, obviously, you guys made a conscious effort on a decision here with your partner to reduce activity. I'm imagining that probably part of that was due to weak gas prices that we're experiencing here. Can you talk at all about what type of gas prices you and your partner think you guys would need to see before picking up activity again?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what you're seeing is reflective now of coming out of winter and where the prices and the outlook for pricing are for the rest of this year coming out of winter. I think we'll continue to meet with them regularly. I mean, we've got monthly reviews
componenttext: I think what you're seeing is reflective now of coming out of winter and where the prices and the outlook for pricing are for the rest of this year coming out of winter. I think we'll continue to meet with them regularly. I mean, we've got monthly reviews with them and more regular discussion on the longer-term outlook. And yes, I don't think either of us are prepared to nail down a particular price for a particular activity yet.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, just going over to second quarter guidance here. You guys obviously are expecting volumes to come down here in terms of sales volumes. Could you kind of give us some granularity in terms of the level of maintenance you're expecting on the s
componenttext: Okay. I guess, just going over to second quarter guidance here. You guys obviously are expecting volumes to come down here in terms of sales volumes. Could you kind of give us some granularity in terms of the level of maintenance you're expecting on the second quarter if you had kind of a number you could sort of throw out there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The main part of that, I think the vast majority of it, is all the -- or the largest portion of it is the downtime and planned downtime in West Africa between the planned downtime and lifting schedules there. So I think that's kind of approaching 15,000 b
componenttext: The main part of that, I think the vast majority of it, is all the -- or the largest portion of it is the downtime and planned downtime in West Africa between the planned downtime and lifting schedules there. So I think that's kind of approaching 15,000 barrels a day equivalent or so. And then you have some knock-on effects that as you've got some facilities that have some rig moves and so forth that affect our volumes in the Gulf of Mexico. So those are the 2 big things, along with the normal seasonal demand decreases we expect and have seen every year in the second quarter in the Eastern Med. So I mean, that's what it's all attributed to, no different than we expected going into the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, you spoke a lot about well cost coming down in the DJ. Have you seen anything in terms of improved well performance in the DJ, other than just faster drilling times and more cost?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, you spoke a lot about well cost coming down in the DJ. Have you seen anything in terms of improved well performance in the DJ, other than just faster drilling times and more cost?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we continue to gather data from all the testing we did last year. You'll remember we tested quite a few different completion techniques last year, and we're starting to zero in on the ones we are going to implement across the basin for most o
componenttext: Yes, I think we continue to gather data from all the testing we did last year. You'll remember we tested quite a few different completion techniques last year, and we're starting to zero in on the ones we are going to implement across the basin for most of this year. I think when you look at our performance really in the last 6 to 9 months with everything that we tried, we're at/or above the type curves that we've been expecting to see as we test these downspaced areas. So I'd say everything is pretty much on track right now. We'll continue to look for ways to improve the completions going forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think I mentioned, Leo, on my call, 11 wells up there in East Pony that we did some different completion on. And those have been a positive improvement, too.
componenttext: And I think I mentioned, Leo, on my call, 11 wells up there in East Pony that we did some different completion on. And those have been a positive improvement, too.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a combination, Leo, of really looking for ways where we can continue to drive costs down without impacting the value of the property. So those 11 wells in East Pony that are slickwater, that saves $100,000 to $200,000 per well off the D&C cost. And
componenttext: That's a combination, Leo, of really looking for ways where we can continue to drive costs down without impacting the value of the property. So those 11 wells in East Pony that are slickwater, that saves $100,000 to $200,000 per well off the D&C cost. And as Dave says, they're performing as expected or better.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: On the DJ, noting that there was the asset sale during the quarter, are you looking to sell other assets in the basin outside of the IDPs? And if so, any thoughts on what the use of capital would be if those came to fruition?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as you saw from what we sold earlier this year, it would be areas that are -- for us, would be long-term development. They'd be outside of the IDP areas, things that we wouldn't have plans for, for a number of years and somebody else may fit
componenttext: Well, I think as you saw from what we sold earlier this year, it would be areas that are -- for us, would be long-term development. They'd be outside of the IDP areas, things that we wouldn't have plans for, for a number of years and somebody else may fit into their portfolio sooner. But there's not a whole lot of that up there that we'd be looking at. It'd be around the fringes, I guess. I don't know, Gary, any other comment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's fair to say, it'd be around the fringes. There might be some other small deals, but I wouldn't expect anything of the magnitude of that one any time soon.
componenttext: No, that's fair to say, it'd be around the fringes. There might be some other small deals, but I wouldn't expect anything of the magnitude of that one any time soon.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the capital budget for the year, could you just remind us what your assumption was when you set the budget in terms of service cost reductions, and then what you've seen to date and if your plan is to continue to reinvest those savings in com
componenttext: Okay. And on the capital budget for the year, could you just remind us what your assumption was when you set the budget in terms of service cost reductions, and then what you've seen to date and if your plan is to continue to reinvest those savings in completions in the DJ? Or is it to keep it on the balance sheet going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we'll have the opportunity of continuing to drive savings down, to continue to look at which makes most sense, which creates more value. Whereas I think when you look at it, it was -- the $2.9 billion was -- and when we were looking at the budget,
componenttext: I mean, we'll have the opportunity of continuing to drive savings down, to continue to look at which makes most sense, which creates more value. Whereas I think when you look at it, it was -- the $2.9 billion was -- and when we were looking at the budget, we were looking at that relative to a $50 to $55 oil price and we were assuming probably on a full year basis, around 10%, if I remember right, on the average savings overall on those. And you see a little higher savings that we're seeing on some of the completion part, but you have to look at the total cost. So I think it's too early for us to adjust anything yet, which is why we haven't changed our capital outlook for the year. But we'll continue to look at that as we get another quarter under our belt.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mike Scialla with Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mike Scialla with Stifel.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gary, in response to Leo's question, you addressed this a little bit, but I want to follow up on it. You'd said that you're trying different things in the DJ. And so far, pretty much everything has kind of met your expectations. You were doing a lot of te
componenttext: Gary, in response to Leo's question, you addressed this a little bit, but I want to follow up on it. You'd said that you're trying different things in the DJ. And so far, pretty much everything has kind of met your expectations. You were doing a lot of testing on downspacing, particularly in Wells Ranch, last year. And I'm just wondering with the slowdown in the drilling activities, has that slowed that whole downspacing process? Or are you comfortable saying what the level of spacing is, at least in Wells Ranch at this point? I've realized that it varies across the field. And if you're not ready to say, do you have a time line on how much data you think you'd need to see before you will be?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we're not ready to say it yet. I'd say as far as when, it will be probably towards the end of this year. I think what I would point out is that we said all of 3 last year that we're devoting a large part of that program to testing downspacing a
componenttext: Yes. Well, we're not ready to say it yet. I'd say as far as when, it will be probably towards the end of this year. I think what I would point out is that we said all of 3 last year that we're devoting a large part of that program to testing downspacing at 24 wells per section and 32 wells per section, and then we wanted to get the wells on and really gather some longer-term data. And we have ramped that downspacing program almost down to nothing this year. And that doesn't really have anything to do with the commodity environment. That was the plan all along until we have gathered the data on the pilots that we did last year. So all the resource numbers, everything we've ever talked about, location counts for the field has always been based on 16 wells per section. We've talked about we do expect it to be different spacing in different parts of the field. 16 wells per section is an average that's certainly still a very good number, a conservative number, I think. We see some areas where we do expect it to be greater spacing than that, more than 16 wells. There maybe some areas that end up being less than 16. But I still feel very comfortable overall with where we're at.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the other part of that, too, and Gary alluded to the amount of downspacing drilling we did last year, that we've been bringing wells on now. We'll start to have a sense of that across -- I think it was all of initial 5 IDP areas where we had some
componenttext: I think the other part of that, too, and Gary alluded to the amount of downspacing drilling we did last year, that we've been bringing wells on now. We'll start to have a sense of that across -- I think it was all of initial 5 IDP areas where we had some downspacing last year, so it's -- we'll get a much larger database here this year to compare and look at beyond just the Wells Ranch area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And to follow up on the slickwater comment, it sounds like working nicely in East Pony. Is that potential for the rest of the field as well?
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And to follow up on the slickwater comment, it sounds like working nicely in East Pony. Is that potential for the rest of the field as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we'll just have to see, Mike. I think we've definitely seen encouraging early results in East Pony. We've done some slickwater test in the past in other parts of the field. And it's been less conclusive, I'd say, in the other parts of the field. S
componenttext: I think we'll just have to see, Mike. I think we've definitely seen encouraging early results in East Pony. We've done some slickwater test in the past in other parts of the field. And it's been less conclusive, I'd say, in the other parts of the field. So we'll just have to continue to test things in different areas and see what's the best application in each area. But East Pony is looking good.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And some of this may evolve, too, as you're getting down into increased density or tighter density, where you're not having to carry your proppant as far away from the wellbore and you're getting that higher concentration near the wellbore. That may drive
componenttext: And some of this may evolve, too, as you're getting down into increased density or tighter density, where you're not having to carry your proppant as far away from the wellbore and you're getting that higher concentration near the wellbore. That may drive some changes in how we use fluids and just concentrations here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: I mean, we're probably comfortable with that for this first well. We would be looking at a project where we would get down into that 50% or so range overall. And we're talking to some folks now out there. But whether something changes before we drill the well or not is not dependent on drilling of this well. This is a pretty low-cost well. I mean, it's in -- I mean, relatively, it's in about 1,500 feet of water depth and the TD is 9,000 feet or so. So it's a very nice prospect offsetting some recent discoveries. So it was a nice addition to the portfolio and somewhat derisking some of our play types down in that area.

componenttext: I was just curious from the standpoint of the lower service cost environment. Does that accelerate the potential for sanctioning projects in the portfolio still in order to lock in lower costs for long lead items?

componenttext: I think the piece on as far as sanctioning projects would be for those big offshore projects, projects like in Eastern Med, it will be dependent on how the pricing environment holds up when we're getting closer to sanction. I think directionally, it's heading to where you potentially have the ability to lock in some lower-cost projects than you would have a year or 2 ago. We might have the opportunity, just as a reminder, like we did coming out the 2008, 2009 period, when we were able to lock in kind of Tamar, Aseng and Alen, and take advantage of a lower supply cost, service cost environment. So it's going to be dependent on where we are when we really get back to truly negotiating the final agreements.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just from the standpoint of the Falklands, what's the infrastructure like down there? You had mentioned that Cheetah was successful in Cameroon, that you can get that on relatively quickly. I was just kind of curious on the -- if the Falklands, a successful find down there, what type of time frame to bring to Falklands...

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, it would be much longer time frame. You have to have large resources. You have to have -- probably bring in some like an FPSO facility, a stand-alone vessel. And so it's a little -- a much different environment than in Cameroon. In Cameroon, what
componenttext: I mean, it would be much longer time frame. You have to have large resources. You have to have -- probably bring in some like an FPSO facility, a stand-alone vessel. And so it's a little -- a much different environment than in Cameroon. In Cameroon, what you mentioned, it's in very shallow water. It's like taking and putting us in the Gulf of Mexico, a very shallow water platform. And you could do that very fast. Falklands would be a longer time to development.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're still early in this cycle here, right? I think, as I mentioned earlier, we'll continue to focus on what would make sense to add to the portfolio. But it'd have to be accretive from the standpoint that it'd be an opportunity that had ru
componenttext: Well, I think we're still early in this cycle here, right? I think, as I mentioned earlier, we'll continue to focus on what would make sense to add to the portfolio. But it'd have to be accretive from the standpoint that it'd be an opportunity that had running room and inventory that competes with our current inventory because we've got a nice inventory already out there. So I don't know, it's early to say what that market could look like over time. I think the benefit is that -- part of the benefit, both for looking at new opportunities and being able to accelerate our own when you've got a deep portfolio is maintaining that financial strength. And that's why we made sure we're in the position we're in now.
