headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Noble Energy's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Noble Energy's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very bright. At this time, we would like to go ahead and open the call to questions. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our quarterly earnings release and new guidance for the remainder of the year. Following another strong quarter, w
componenttext:
Very bright. At this time, we would like to go ahead and open the call to questions. Thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our quarterly earnings release and new guidance for the remainder of the year. Following another strong quarter, we've again raised our full year volume outlook for Noble Energy, while keeping our capital program consistent with prior expectations. Our new guidance and comments today also incorporates an outlook for these new Texas assets, which we're excited to share following the closing of the Rosetta Resources acquisition in late July. We also posted to our website a number of supplemental slides for this call which you will find helpful as we talk to our prepared remarks. Later this morning, our 10-Q will be available as well. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, Executive VP of Operations, we'll open the call for questions and complete in about an hour. [Operator Instructions] 
Management members joining for the Q&A session are Ken Fisher, Executive VP and CFO; Susan Cunningham, Executive Vice President, Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, Senior VP, Eastern Med. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brett. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I want to share with you why I continue to have great confidence in our business and strategy. While these are challenging times in our industry, it does not diminish the fact that Noble
componenttext:
Thanks, Brett. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I want to share with you why I continue to have great confidence in our business and strategy. While these are challenging times in our industry, it does not diminish the fact that Noble Energy has exceptional assets as well as a financial strength and operational excellence to realize their potential. Our positive momentum, including the recent closing of the Rosetta acquisition, gives us great optimism for the future as we continue to execute on our strategy of driving value from a high-quality diversified portfolio that provide investment choices. Our core competitive advantages continue to be focused on U.S. onshore unconventional development, combined with material offshore exploration and proven major project execution. Additionally, we have the financial strength to navigate through a volatile market and take advantage of opportunities. All oil and natural gas companies are facing choppy seas right now, but I believe investors are very well positioned with Noble Energy. We continue to effectively manage the things that are within our control and position the business for long-term value creation. Our diversified portfolio underpins strong performance in the second quarter. Volumes again exceeded expectations, and meaningful reductions are being realized on both capital and operating cost. Sales volumes were nearly 300,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, even with the impact of scheduled facility maintenance in both the Gulf of Mexico and West Africa. For the second time this year, we raised our Noble Energy legacy volume outlook for the full year. This is a result of our flexibility to reallocate capital throughout the year as we continue to see efficiency improvements in the DJ Basin program. Second quarter capital expenditures declined sequentially to under $800 million and we remain on track to meet our original $2.9 billion capital forecast. Our capital is trending well quarterly for the year as we manage the cash flow in the second half of the year. 
I'm also extremely pleased with our progress in reducing cash cost, specifically in the onshore business where lease operator expense was reduced to approximately $4 per barrel of oil equivalent in the quarter. This is down more than 20% from the first quarter. Total lease operating expense per barrel of oil equivalent for Noble Energy is now back to pre-2010 level reflecting our portfolio changes an intense focus on reducing controllable cost. 
Operational execution continues to be an area of keen focus as we look to maximize long-term profitability with a number of major accomplishments achieved during the second quarter. This included our onshore horizontal production growth of 45% versus the same quarter of last year and record low drilling times in both the DJ Basin and Marcellus shale. Drilling complete cost, all in, are trending below targeted low-cost in both plays. 
In our offshore business, the Ash compression project in Israel has been completed, increasing our peak deliverability. And at the same time, pipeline installation and side modifications are progressing as planned on Big Bend and Dantzler in the Gulf of Mexico. First production from this field is expected in the fourth quarter and around the end of the year, respectively. 
On the offshore drilling side, we have 3 rigs currently operating. 1 progressing our Gunflint development and 2, drilling machine exploration wells, including prospect offshore Falkland Islands and Cameroon. So from an execution standpoint, I am pleased with how our business is operating. 
The acquisition of Rosetta enhances and further diversifies our onshore and conventional portfolio baddie to premiere low-cost operating assets. Strong underlying asset performance results from other operators in and around our acreage as well as recent M&A activity in these basins continues to affirm the long-term value of our transaction. It was the right opportunity at the right time for Noble Energy. These high-quality assets provides prolific and low-cost production in the Eagle Ford with running room and its deep inventory of liquids-rich opportunities in the emerging Delaware basin. Without question, these new areas will have a substantial impact to Noble Energy. When you think about more than 60,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day of production, at least 1,800 identifiable locations and around 1 billion barrel of oil equivalent potential, that's a very sizable business that can grow materially into the future. We've hit the ground running, and we're already seeing more value potential than we originally assumed. 
Combined, our Texas assets will deliver 15% compound annual growth for several years within the operating cash flow to this business. As such, we aren't pouring capital away from any of our strong return opportunities, which is one reason this investment was so unique. 
As shown on Slide 3, we now have sizable position in 4 of the premier U.S. unconventional plays. This provides substantial flexibility in our future capital allocation and the ability to accelerate activity when appropriate. We will also realize about $40 million per year in G&A synergies, while taking advantage of Noble's lower cost of capital. 
Let me now hand it over to Gary to walk through an operations update.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. I'd like to start off by sharing my thoughts on why the Rosetta acquisition was such a great move for Noble Energy. Our technical knowledge of these basins was built over the last several years as our business development and new venture tea
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. I'd like to start off by sharing my thoughts on why the Rosetta acquisition was such a great move for Noble Energy. Our technical knowledge of these basins was built over the last several years as our business development and new venture teams assess all of the best basins in the U.S. From this work, two things became apparent. First, we needed to focus our existing onshore U.S. portfolio on the DJ Basin and Marcellus Shale, which consistently ranked among the top basins. This cost has exited another of plays over the last few years. Secondly, we want to be ready to further enhance our portfolio by capturing opportunities and other competitive basins then they became available. The Eagle Ford and Delaware basins are both top-tier plays, and we've now obtain premier positions in some of the best parts of each. Over the last few years, we have dramatically improved performance in the DJ Basin, and then transferred an accelerated those learnings in the Marcellus. With the addition of the Eagle Ford in Delaware positions, we are confident that our operational expertise will again unlock incremental value that otherwise would not have been delivered. Our acquisition model applied value almost entirely to the existing production but lower Eagle Ford inventory and the upper Wolfcamp  potential in the Delaware. We see a lot of room to increase value further our multizone development in both ways, refrac potential and additional locations that are not assumed in our current counts. 
The high-quality nature of our Eagle Ford asset is demonstrated on Slide 5. The map illustrates estimated recoveries for lateral foot in the basin. You can see the outline of our acreage, the largest being a core position in northern West County where we will focus our Eagle Ford activity over the next few years. This is a sweet spot of some of the most productive rock in the plate, with tremendous resource recoveries ranging between 1 million and 3 million-barrel of oil equivalent per well based on a 5,000-foot lateral. We have highlighted in the table our current assumptions, including inventory count based on current strip pricing and assumed spacing, estimated ultimate recoveries and average well cost. 
Highlighted on Slide 6 is the 3 million barrels equivalent type curve for Southgate's ranch represented by the blue lines. This is an increase of 25% from Rosetta's prior type curve shown in red. The green line is the average of 2 recent wells, which are outpacing even our increased type curve by another 20%. 
We have provided our detailed Eagle Ford plans on Slide 7 showing accelerating well activity through at least 2018. Our plan is to focus on the lower Eagle Ford for the last few years, increasing well lateral links to an average of around 7,000 feet. We are currently drilling our first Eagle Ford well and have already implemented improvements that have material increased footage drilled per day. 
Moving over to the Permian. This is an area where we see tremendous value and upside as we accelerate the appraisal activities and move quickly to development boat. The Delaware is a emerging as a world-class basin with multizone potential. Development plans will include multi-well pad drilling, centralized production facilities and the potential for longer laterals, none of which were being done in the these assets. We will rapidly incorporate and leverage learnings from the DJ Basin and the Marcellus as we plan the long-term development of the basin. 
Our focus on the Permian will be on the Delaware basin position, which is a contiguous 45,000 net acres. In the DJ Basin, we've already experienced the significant value uplift of the large-scale systematic development approach can bring in terms of maximizing recoveries, lowering capital and operating costs and minimizing the aboveground impacts. 
On Slide 8, we have shows how these acreage compares to our  DJ Basin, East Pony, IDP area in terms of size. This is clearly a material position for Noble. We've already identified over 1,200 gross locations based on current strip prices for development with 70% of these in the Wolfcamp A and Third Bone Spring and the remainder in Lower Wolfcamp zones. 
Highlighted on Slide 9 are recent global wells and those are some other operating in and around our acreage. For the Noble wells, the peak 30-day average production rates from a normalized 5,000-foot lateral is nearly 1,300 barrels of oil equivalent per day on a 2 stringed basses, and more than 70% of this production is crude oil. This production rates are impressive and consistent with other operator results in the area. Similar to what we have shown for the Eagle Ford, we have provided our 700,000-barrel of oil equivalent type curve, again for 5,000-foot lateral on Slide 10. This type curve is up 30% from Rosetta's previous type curve. Recent well performance represented by the 14 wells in the green line gives us a lot of confidence in the potential of these assets. 
We've also highlighted on the slide some of the anticipated operating efficiencies that Noble Energy will bring to these assets. You can see the substantial reduction in drilling cost per lateral foot that we have driven in the DJ Basin and Marcellus versus historical performance in these areas, combining Noble drilling expertise and knowledge of multizone development with Rosetta skill set said knowledge will no doubt deliver substantial operational improvement in the Delaware. 
On Slide 11, we have provided our detailed plans for acceleration in the Permian resulting in 70 wells drilled in 2018 and anticipating continued activity growth beyond that.  Under the current plan, capital investment in the Delaware is essentially equivalent to the Eagle Ford beginning next year and exceeds the Eagle Ford beginning in 2018 with an even earlier acceleration in the Delaware possible as our plans continue to evolve. 
Our outlook for the combined Texas assets has production growing to more than 100,000 barrels equivalent per day in 2018 as shown on Slide 12. We estimate substantial annual free cash flow at the end of our forecasted period, which would only provide additional investment flexibility. 
I'll now transition to the DJ Basin where both our underlying operational performance and the infrastructure capacity continue to improve. to rig release time averaged just over 6 days in the quarter for standard link lateral. Last quarter, it was 7 days, it was already below our budgeted assumption for 2015. Dave mentioned our well cost are trending under our target for the year second half 2015 all in well cost, including drilling, completion and allocated facilities are expected to be $3.5 million in Wells Ranch and $3.9 million in East Pony. These are both $300,000 below our budget assumptions. In addition, when you normalize our loan lateral well cost back to a normal link equivalent well, we are slightly below $3 million for these more capital efficient wells and roughly 60% of our drilling in the second half of this year will be extended laterals. 
With current rig efficiencies and 4 rigs for the rest of the year, we expect to drill a total of 240 equivalent wells in 2015 compared to our original budget expectation of about 200 with the same number of rigs. That's an amazing increase in performance and a key contributor to our 2015 production uplift. 
On the completion side, we continue to optimize stage links, profit loads and fluid types across our IDPs. Most recently, we've seen very strong performance utilizing slick water in East Pony with the majority of these wells are performing similar hybrid gel completions nearby. Our success and growth in East Pony has been tremendous. Net production in the East Pony IDP is now approximately 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 100% from this time a year ago. And as a reminder, more than 75% of East Pony volumes are oil. 
At the end of the second quarter, third-party infrastructure in Greater Wattenberg got a much-needed boost with the start-up of the city gas processing plant, which is ramping the full capacity of 200 million cubic feet per day. The addition of the Lucerne-2 is increasing third-party gas capacity on the DCP system by 1/3 to a total of 800 million cubic feet per day. Now earlier this year in certain parts of the field, line pressure averaged north of 250 PSI, which created a tough producing environment for many of the legacy vertical and horizontal wells. Since Lucerne-2 start up, we've seen line pressure produce by as much as 50 to 70 psi in the early part of july and that should be even greater as the plant reaches full capacity. Volumes for July averaged to more than 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day with peak days greater than 115,000 per day. Additional infrastructure projects in the basin continues to progress on the schedule as well, including the Grand Parkway low pressure gathering loop. The combination of all of these projects position the basin well exiting 2015 and into 2016, and while we remain guarded in our production guidance until consistent midstream performance as seen, the early look is certainly very positive. 
Finally, in the Marcellus Shale, our operations continue to improve. Our drilling teams are performing extremely well, and we drilled our longest lateral ever as a company in the second quarter, nearly 14,000-foot horizontally. In addition, we're looking forward to the production results from our first Utica well before the end of the year. 
Given the price environment, we're further reducing drilling activity in the basin and alignment with our joint venture partner. In the middle part of the third quarter, operator and horizontal drilling will be reduced to 0 rigs for the remainder of the year. And on the dry gas nonoperated side, we anticipate going from 2 horizontal rigs to 0 early in the fourth quarter. These shifts in drilling do not impact our completion schedule for the remainder of 2015, and we're working with our partner on the right level of investment for 2016 with both companies focused on a cash-neutral program for the JV next year. Let me now been hand it back to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. I want to spend a few minutes on the progress on the regulatory front in Israel and our updated 2015 outlook before opening for questions. Over the last several months, we've worked diligently with the government on establishing a regulato
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. I want to spend a few minutes on the progress on the regulatory front in Israel and our updated 2015 outlook before opening for questions. 
Over the last several months, we've worked diligently with the government on establishing a regulatory framework to provide necessary certainty for future investment. The product is a comprehensive framework that addresses the needs and interests of all parties, including Noble Energy, the government and citizens of Israel and its neighbors who can all benefit from this abundant gas resources. Both the Prime Minister's Office and the Minister of Energy have endorsed the framework and are working to achieve final approval. For Noble Energy, this framework should provide certainty around regulatory and fiscal matters necessary to support future investment in the expansion of Tamar and the first phase of development Leviathan. For Israel, it provides price transparency and market competition. These projects can develop additional gas supplies within the country and bring the financial and geopolitical benefits of regional exports. We continue to engage with future export customers in the region on the potential to deliver both Israeli and word gas to market. The opportunity for expansion of natural gas used in Israel and the demand for natural gas in the region remains strong. I look forward to unlocking tremendous unrecognized value in Noble as these projects come together. Company-wide, there are a number of positive catalysts in the second half of the year, which provides both near and long-term benefit. We are encouraged that production capacity in the DJ Basin will continue to respond positively as we benefit from important infrastructure expansion, while we focus on long laterals and additional completion learnings through the remainder of the year. As Gary mentioned, the integration of the Rosetta assets is going very well with a strong second quarter, our volumes where higher and cost lower than expected, these assets are off to a great start and complementary to Noble's overall performance. Offshore, 2 new fields are anticipated to add 20,000 barrels equivalent per day by the end of the year in the Gulf of Mexico. In addition, we will have results from 2 material exploration prospects this quarter, including the 250 million barrels [indiscernible] prospect in the Falkland Islands and 100 million plus prospects in Cameroon. Success in either of these wells with our well in the later this year with derisk additional exploration potential provide new development opportunities and add significant value for Noble Energy. As mentioned earlier, we are raising our previous full year 2015 volume guidance. I'm pleased we complete this amounted increase while holding full year capital flat to original plan and maintaining flexibility on our onshore activity should conditions and cash flow outlook change. We've also provided new quarterly guidance for the remainder of the year, which includes the integration of the Eagle Ford and Permian assets. This guidance reflects the quarterly trend of lower capital and operating costs through the remainder of the year while underlying volumes growth. Yes, these are tough times, but we're well positioned with exceptional assets and strong operating and financial capacity to navigate through these challenges no matter the duration. We've been very thoughtful in our decision processes throughout the year as we continue to maintain strong capital discipline and manage the cash flow in the second half of the year. I am convinced Noble Energy's future is very bright. At this time, we would like to go ahead and open the call to questions.

componenttext: Yes, Doug, when you look at how we're managing the cash flow, if you look at how this plays out this year and especially when you -- I refer you to the guidance we laid out for third and fourth quarter, you see our capital spend continues to come down dramatically as we enter the fourth quarter. A big part of that is the role off of this 50 well of the capital spending on some of those Gulf of Mexico projects. We'll actually have Dantzler on here by the middle of the fourth quarter -- I mean Big Bend by the middle of the fourth quarter and Dantzler by the end of the year. So you'll have 2 of the 3 big projects and their capital spend actually rolling off. So we expect to be even in this $50 to $60 world, we expect to be managing the cash flow here by the end of the year, and that will set us very nicely for the next year.

componenttext: Yes, Doug, I think the real decision there is it's not the time to be continuing to drill wells in the Marcellus with the outlook on gas price until we see that change. That being said, with some of the completion inventory and the some of the completion activity, we'll still be ramping up in the second half of this year. And I think we'll still be flat to up some next year with that inventory, even with the drilling activity. I think the real impact of the drilling activities when you start to look at the late '16 and '17 time frame, then that will be dependent on when the ramp back up, will be dependent on our outlook for gas price.

componenttext: Yes, Dave, I think when we look at 2016, and you're right, it's too early to get far ahead of ourselves, but when you look at, and we look at our finishing this year and how we're set up for next year, we've got a lot of flexibility. So I think that positions us extremely well and that flexibility allows us to adapt to a changing environment and a changing cash flow environment to be ready to accelerate when it makes sense and to be able to have the flexibility to hold back up if that mad sense but still have a growing business.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we've added some more flexibility and diversity when you look at our mix of onshore assets now. I think between the Marcellus, we've talked about how we're thinking about that going into the year. On the DJ, we'll continue to see the impact of the
componenttext: I think we've added some more flexibility and diversity when you look at our mix of onshore assets now. I think between the Marcellus, we've talked about how we're thinking about that going into the year. On the DJ, we'll continue to see the impact of the Lucerne-2-plant coming up. We'll see the line looping system later this year, so that will give us some more insight on how we want to play off capital and match capital with capacity going into next year. And then in the, both the Delaware Basin and Eagle Ford, we've laid out our base plans. I'd say, all of those, we've got the flexibility to adapt and adjust as make sense when you look at the commodity outlook. Our big offshore projects, the only one really we'll still have in play next year will be finishing Gunflint. The majority with that investment will be done by this year, we'll have Gunflint online the middle of next year. We finished the compression project at Ashdod this year, so the next investment in Israel will be dependent on the framework coming together. So I think we're really good place there. On the exploration front, we'll have our rig in the Gulf of Mexico focused on appraisal and exploration next year. But overall, we're well positioned to bring capital down, to continue to follow the trend that we've gotten to the fourth quarter this year, and then make sure we're managing to the outlook that we see.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan, first off, [indiscernible] lateraling those curves are normalized to the 5,000-foot lateral, so even though we're drilling longer, longer laterals in the area, that's not driving the type curves. Dave is right, it's really two things. It's movi
componenttext: Yes, Ryan, first off, [indiscernible] lateraling those curves are normalized to the 5,000-foot lateral, so even though we're drilling longer, longer laterals in the area, that's not driving the type curves. Dave is right, it's really two things. It's moving more south in the ranch area, which is a much more prolific area, and then it's just continuing to improve on the completion designs. Very similar to what we've done in the DJ Basin and the Marcellus with reduced spec stage and cluster spacing. And also starting to increase our sand loadings up to 2,000 pounds in some cases. So a lot of the same types of things we've done into other areas just bringing them to the Eagle Ford and soon to be in the Permian as well.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo. I mean, we're watching as everybody is as the government's kind of going through the public process and they're in the process of working to bring that framework to final resolution, final approval. I think we're both committed and still remain
componenttext: Yes, Leo. I mean, we're watching as everybody is as the government's kind of going through the public process and they're in the process of working to bring that framework to final resolution, final approval. I think we're both committed and still remain committed to seeing this done by the end of the summer. But I'll say, the timing's important on this. But the actual last thing and sustainable framework in the nature of the framework and having a framework that allows us to move forward with investment in Israel is the most important element. I think what's very encouraging so far is that -- and think back about this. When you go back to over the last year, what's been accomplished. I mean in the progress on getting to a framework has been nothing short of a tremendous effort on all parties -- party like the government committed on doing this and on our team and our partners that have worked so hard to bring that to bear. I mean, a complete comprehensive framework that sets up the ability to go forward with confidence and investment is a big step. Another big step has been the commitment and support of the Prime Minister's Office and the Energy Ministry to make this happen. So I think when you look at it, the step again, the framework to where it is and now the recognition and understanding of how important this is, not only to the country but to the region, has just been tremendous.

componenttext: Well, I'll go through what we've kind of laid out on probabilities, and then Susan and probably give you some more insight as to your thoughts on the both of those wells. And then also don't forget the array of prospect later this year, which probably have a slightly higher probability. I think on Humpback and Cheetah, they're both in that 25% -- plus-or-minus 25% range, both interesting, exciting prospects, both with a little different color. In Humpback, that's our first true exploration test on this huge acreage position down in the Falklands. I mean, you think about it, you think about how our acreage position overlays the North Sea, for example, its' just our position down there in the Falklands it's about half of the North sea. So it will be real interesting to see what transpires here as we break out a new play, but it's a new play in areas where there's been proven hydrocarbon discoveries, some fairly significant when you look at the whole scheme of things. In Cameroon, to me, what exciting to me is like Gulf of Mexico prospect on steroids as I talked about it. When you look at the shallow water depth and a high potential. But let me turn it over to the real expert here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. The 25% is about right, plus or minus, for the 2 prospects that are drilling right now in radio will be higher than that regardless of the outcome of Humpback. What's great about Humpback is the follow-up, it's over 1 billion barrel of oil equ
componenttext: Yes, David. The 25% is about right, plus or minus, for the 2 prospects that are drilling right now in radio will be higher than that regardless of the outcome of Humpback. What's great about Humpback is the follow-up, it's over 1 billion barrel of oil equivalent just in that immediate area if we have some encouragement there. So it's pretty significant. And Cheetah is only 10 miles offshore for the coast in Cameroon, and it's in about 85 feet of water, so it will be very quick and easy and Cheetah tie in to develop if successful.

componenttext: I was wondering if I could ask a bit about the Eagle Ford assets and your outlook there. I think you mentioned in your prepared comments and also on the slides that your location count at the strip. But as I look at these assets, one of the defining -- one of the things that sets them apart is the NGL percentage. So the strip is a little more obscure when it comes to talking about NGLs. Can you talk about what your current assumptions are there? And what your outlook is, especially in light of -- it's been kind of maybe -- it's taken on the chin hard here in 2015 and maybe what your thoughts are for an outlook and how that affects your appetite for those NGL heavy assets?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's something you have to take a hard look at, Charles. I think as you look at it, we've not assumed that NGL pricing is really going to change a lot this year. I think as we look at it and visit with our marketing folks, probably in the ne
componenttext: Well, I think it's something you have to take a hard look at, Charles. I think as you look at it, we've not assumed that NGL pricing is really going to change a lot this year. I think as we look at it and visit with our marketing folks, probably in the next year, as you get more ships, and so forth, especially you can move more propane and butane, that just start to see some real alleviation of pressure there. That being said, close to the Gulf Coast and some Gulf Coast markets with the Eagle Ford volumes. So that's helpful. But it's just part of the mix that we take into effect and account when we look at the economics of word. I'll say the economics of the Eagle Ford, especially as you're hearing Gates Ranch and the South Gates Ranch stack up with everything and anything, even considering all of those.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, you're right, Charles, that we're focusing initially on the Wolfcamp A. And I think within that, you have to look at how do you most effectively drain that told Wolfcamp A horizon. I think there's opportunities to maybe even have a multiple latera
componenttext: I mean, you're right, Charles, that we're focusing initially on the Wolfcamp A. And I think within that, you have to look at how do you most effectively drain that told Wolfcamp A horizon. I think there's opportunities to maybe even have a multiple laterals, not that we're counting on that in Wolfcamp A, but also starting to pick up some of that Third Bone Spring drainage. I think those will be the 2 initial pieces. And then you move down to kind of that B and C as a longer-term optionality that I don't doubt the industry will break out economically over time, but we're not counting on it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, so that kind of more extensive development of the Wolfcamp A, that could get the Third Bone Spring that something we could maybe start to see in '16?
componenttext: Got it, so that kind of more extensive development of the Wolfcamp A, that could get the Third Bone Spring that something we could maybe start to see in '16?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think as we get into '16, '17 and also in '18 where we kind of start to see the Delaware program really ramp up, you'll start to draw in some of that horizon. We'll start to see some impact from that. But really still what we laid out as a plan is landi
componenttext: I think as we get into '16, '17 and also in '18 where we kind of start to see the Delaware program really ramp up, you'll start to draw in some of that horizon. We'll start to see some impact from that. But really still what we laid out as a plan is landing all our laterals in the Wolfcamp A. We haven't specifically target landing a lateral in the Bone Spring yet in that program.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you built your position in the DJ, you followed your acquisition with the U.S. exploration acquisition. As you look to the Eagle Ford and Permian, what's your ultimate goal in terms of the size and the position you're looking for? And do you see addi
componenttext: When you built your position in the DJ, you followed your acquisition with the U.S. exploration acquisition. As you look to the Eagle Ford and Permian, what's your ultimate goal in terms of the size and the position you're looking for? And do you see additional opportunities that are front and center downturn to make that happen?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, I'll go back to what we talked about since we announced the Rosette acquisition. One of the first keys to the Rosetta was to be comfortable in and of itself that have enough size and growth within those asset, that it wasn't dependent on anoth
componenttext: Yes, Brian, I'll go back to what we talked about since we announced the Rosette acquisition. One of the first keys to the Rosetta was to be comfortable in and of itself that have enough size and growth within those asset, that it wasn't dependent on another acquisition. That said, being in the neighborhood, I think we'll continue to look at what's available out there and make sure we understand the value of different opportunities. I'd say we have a strong solid balance sheet that gives us the ability and the flexibility to be able to take advantage of opportunities if a great opportunity came around. But that's not the focus of what we're doing now. The focus of what we're doing now is on execution. And I think you can see that showing up, not only in what was delivered in the first half of the year, but what we're set up to deliver in the second half of the year, and that's the same focus we're applying to the Rosetta assets.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good time into my follow-up, which is on the execution point and the legacy assets, the increased guidance that seems to reflect a lot of your outlook for second half uplift. Can you just talk more specifically about the drivers of the increase p
componenttext: That's a good time into my follow-up, which is on the execution point and the legacy assets, the increased guidance that seems to reflect a lot of your outlook for second half uplift. Can you just talk more specifically about the drivers of the increase production guidance between the Marcellus, DJ or elsewhere?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Glad to, Brian. Actually, we've been looking forward to this call for a period of time because we've been looking forward to getting the mid-year. The exciting part for us is we put a plan in effect at the beginning of the year, and we got in motion very,
componenttext: Glad to, Brian. Actually, we've been looking forward to this call for a period of time because we've been looking forward to getting the mid-year. The exciting part for us is we put a plan in effect at the beginning of the year, and we got in motion very, very quickly. And now we're benefiting from the result of delivering on that plan. I'd say we're actually ahead of that plan. And I think that's framed in what you look after the outlook for the second half of the year. When you go back to what we've started the year, we've ramped down and pushed down the Marcellus program pretty quickly. We very quickly reduced activity levels in the DJ from 10 rigs to 4. We level loaded and kind of slowed down some of our completion activity, so we could get Lucerne-2 in place. As a result of how things have looked through the year, actually saw some of the Marcellus planned capital come down. Actually move some of that capital to the DJ. But if that was a reflection on the just the continued improvements on efficiency. We've talked before about those 4 rigs drilling about 70% of the total lateral footage that we did with 10 rigs. So that's all enabled us to where the real driver in the second half of the year, and the biggest driver in that increased guidance is the outlook on this activity and performance in the DJ.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And that's partly, as you say, on the low productivity fronts but also just unlocking the midstream bottlenecks?
componenttext: Got it. And that's partly, as you say, on the low productivity fronts but also just unlocking the midstream bottlenecks?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it all comes together. And Gary may have some more to add on his thoughts here.
componenttext: I think it all comes together. And Gary may have some more to add on his thoughts here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's unlocking that midstream bottlenecks, which we had some increase in there and the original budget, but we've added a bit more based on the early results we're seeing. It's partly the underlying improvement and the completions. We've ment
componenttext: Yes, I think it's unlocking that midstream bottlenecks, which we had some increase in there and the original budget, but we've added a bit more based on the early results we're seeing. It's partly the underlying improvement and the completions. We've mentioned the phenomenal success that we've seen recently in East Pony. And then it's just a greater number of wells coming online throughout the year as we've continued to drive down the drilling times.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bob Morse from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bob Morse from Citi.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gary, you confirmed that the increase of type curve at Gate Ranch and in Eagle Ford were driven a lot by the cluster spacing and the sand loadings. I know overall cost have come down. But on today's cost, can you quantify probably 30% or 25% to 30% in EUR
componenttext: Gary, you confirmed that the increase of type curve at Gate Ranch and in Eagle Ford were driven a lot by the cluster spacing and the sand loadings. I know overall cost have come down. But on today's cost, can you quantify probably 30% or 25% to 30% in EURs, what the associated increasing cost is percentage-wise for doing the increased cost of the spacing in a greater pattern loading?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, I think it's probably in the 10% range, but at the same time, I think we've got greater efficiencies that are going to offset quite a bit of that. I think when you look at what we're seeing already on the drilling side since we've closed the dea
componenttext: Yes, Bob, I think it's probably in the 10% range, but at the same time, I think we've got greater efficiencies that are going to offset quite a bit of that. I think when you look at what we're seeing already on the drilling side since we've closed the deal, we have been able on these first couple of wells to significantly improve the drilling times, especially through the latter links. And I think at the end of the day, going to be able to take probably conservatively a couple of based off of the average deal time on the Eagle Ford wells. So certainly, more stages or more cluster spacing and greater sand loadings adds to the cost, but we see some efficiencies offsetting that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is just on refries. In the Marcellus, I know you've laid down all your rigs this year, but will you continue to test refracs in the Marcellus and what have you seen there? And in the Eagle Ford, you mentioned some of ups
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is just on refries. In the Marcellus, I know you've laid down all your rigs this year, but will you continue to test refracs in the Marcellus and what have you seen there? And in the Eagle Ford, you mentioned some of upside being potential for refracs. What gives you confidence that refracs can be successful in that play?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a combination really of refracs, and in some cases, adding perfs or tightening up those cluster spacing just like we're doing on the new completions. So we may have a few more schedule in the Marcellus this year. I don't think it's going to be a
componenttext: Yes, it's a combination really of refracs, and in some cases, adding perfs or tightening up those cluster spacing just like we're doing on the new completions. So we may have a few more schedule in the Marcellus this year. I don't think it's going to be a significant number, but the early results we've seen on the once we've done encouraging have been very encouraging. Initial rates back up to the original initial rates in many cases. I think what gives us the same level of confidence in the Eagle Ford is almost all of the completions of very much kind of a similar story to the Marcellus, much wider stage of facings, fewer perf clusters, and so it's an opportunity to go in and not only at the first but improve the completion designs is also, I think we'll see some nice uplift there as well.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: When do you plan to do your first refrac on Eagle Ford?
componenttext: When do you plan to do your first refrac on Eagle Ford?

componenttext: I don't know. We got one on the schedule yet. We may try a couple before year end, but I would suspect 2016 will be more of a test.

componenttext: Just wanted to quickly confirm that your Marcellus capital spending for this year is still going to be maintained at that $700 million level? And is the DJ Basin also staying at $1.1 billion, given the additional wells that you talked about adding into the program?

componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just one corporately. Can you just talk about how comfortable you are with your current hedge book and discuss how you're going to approach adding more protection given the volatility?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll make a few comments, and then Ken Fisher can add to that because he watches that continuously, tracks me into more meetings that I can believe on that. But no, we're taking a hard look at that all the time. I mean, with the meat. I mean, we meet
componenttext: Yes, I'll make a few comments, and then Ken Fisher can add to that because he watches that continuously, tracks me into more meetings that I can believe on that. But no, we're taking a hard look at that all the time. I mean, with the meat. I mean, we meet on that probably every couple of weeks to look at what makes sense, of the market, how are we yid position for not just the current year, but the following 2 years as we look at both our global oil and mix and our domestic gas mix. It's also a time period where we reflect and remind ourselves how appreciative we are of having our Israel gas contribution also as kind of a natural hedge, additional hedge, if you will. But we continue to look for a period, especially in any market upswings, which we'd like to see more of an a commodity basis. But as we get into some market upswings, how do we layer in some positions as we go forward. Our philosophy and objective has been to hedge up to 50% on those different streams for managing cash flow. I think with our legacy position on oil, we were about 30% for next year. And I think on gas, it was 25% to 28%, somewhere in that range. But I'll let Ken add a little more color.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean as Dave said, the programs been very successful 3 times. Ensuring that we cut off of the tail risk. So if you look at it, historically had the positives in 2009 in the global financial crisis, and then we'll have about $750 million in settlements o
componenttext: I mean as Dave said, the programs been very successful 3 times. Ensuring that we cut off of the tail risk. So if you look at it, historically had the positives in 2009 in the global financial crisis, and then we'll have about $750 million in settlements of this year where, as Dave, mentioned about 30% of that is oil, 25% hedged on gas go into next year. We don't typically make big moves all at one time, but averaging, so we'll continue to look at that. And then we picked up the Rosetta hedge book as well, and they're pretty well hedged as well, about 35% for oil and 45% on gas production next year. So all in all, our competitive position on the hedge book is strong, and it's a shock absorber that allows us to realize those gains as we bring down the capital plan to the current investment environment and achieve cash flow neutrality.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: I was hoping to get a little bit more color on the production profile in the DJ. You dropped sequentially Q1 to Q2, but the July numbers look good, and with the midstream constraints abating and efficiency gains becoming more apparent, I was just hoping you can talk about what the progression could look like here in the second half and maybe just initial thoughts going into '16 there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with that, and then have Gary provide some more insights. But as Gary said in his notes and his dialogue earlier, we've still remained pretty guarded as to what the full impact of this Lucerne-2 facility will be and then still what the lin
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with that, and then have Gary provide some more insights. But as Gary said in his notes and his dialogue earlier, we've still remained pretty guarded as to what the full impact of this Lucerne-2 facility will be and then still what the line loop will be later this year. We're seeing some very good encouraging results. I would say we expect volumes to be up from second quarter and the third and fourth. But I think it will be nice to get this Lucerne-2 plant fully ramped up. It's been down here for -- not down, but it's been impacted by fact that they've had another facility planned maintenance that we still got a couple of weeks to see the full impact out there. But we've been very pleased, very, very pleased with what we've seen so far as of this ramp up. And let me have Gary give you some more color on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. It's 3Q and 4Q will definitely be up from 2Q in our guidance. I'd second -- we're being very guarded, I would say, at this point until we see more of a sustained performance. The early look is very encouraging though. And we've said we're north
componenttext: Yes, Mike. It's 3Q and 4Q will definitely be up from 2Q in our guidance. I'd second -- we're being very guarded, I would say, at this point until we see more of a sustained performance. The early look is very encouraging though. And we've said we're north of 110 in July, peak days greater than 115. We've actually seen even a couple of days in 120 range. So that i all, without Lucerne-2 running at full capacity yet, they haven't yet made it to the 200 million a day. In the meantime, as Dave mentioned, they've had another facility down from some planned maintenance, which took about 120 million a day out of the system capacity. So that's part of the reason why we're still being a bit conservative for now until we see more than just a couple of days with some decent rates through the system. But I think from their the performance, we're seeing line pressures is down 50 to 75-psi across the field when they've got everything up and running. Very excited about what we're seeing. I think we'll see some very nice numbers in the 3Q and 4Q there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And should really position us well as we exit the year.
componenttext: And should really position us well as we exit the year.

componenttext: And follow-up is on the Eagle Ford. If you look at the Page 5 of your presentation here, does -- there were some pretty big delta and the lateral book EURs and you talked about kind of the sweet spot here, the Southern Gates Ranch area. Maybe you can talk about the difference in returns about that acreage versus what you've seen the upper Eagle Ford what you categorize as lower -- either lower Eagle Ford, and then as a follow-up to that, just what the opportunity set based ultimately seek those number for those locations increase that kind of 600 Boe per lateral foot area?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with that. But yes, I mean, the Southern Gates Ranch Eagle Ford is the best of the best down there, and you see that even the new compare that across all the Eagle Ford acreage in databasing. It is a pure sweet spot there. And then when yo
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with that. But yes, I mean, the Southern Gates Ranch Eagle Ford is the best of the best down there, and you see that even the new compare that across all the Eagle Ford acreage in databasing. It is a pure sweet spot there. And then when you compare -- so it's got the highest returns obviously. I'd say everything that we've put on here has a decent return at a strip price, especially when you look out into the future, and the upper Eagle Ford probably had the most challenged yet, but I think we've got plenty of time before we get to those opportunities. And I would expect we'll continue to improve the outlook on those by the time we get further beyond that 2018 time period. But Gary, did you have anything else?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the South Gate Ranch is really the area we're focusing in right now. And when you look how prolific those wells are, I mean we see returns even in current strip price conditions of 75% to 100% returns in those areas. So extremely strong economics. Th
componenttext: Yes, the South Gate Ranch is really the area we're focusing in right now. And when you look how prolific those wells are, I mean we see returns even in current strip price conditions of 75% to 100% returns in those areas. So extremely strong economics. The other Gates Ranch lower Eagle Ford is obviously lower return than that given the EUR per lateral foot, but still quite economic in this price environment. And then as Dave mentioned, the upper Eagle Ford is the most challenged to date but did have before we get there. Hopefully we'll see will help on those from prices improving in the meantime, I'm confident we'll see how between now, and then us to continue to refine the completion techniques on the areas we're working in the meantime.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it's also worth noting that those locations reference only the locations that met an economic hurdle within the strip pricing environment. So more opportunities beyond that if we get a little better in pricing environment at some point.
componenttext: And it's also worth noting that those locations reference only the locations that met an economic hurdle within the strip pricing environment. So more opportunities beyond that if we get a little better in pricing environment at some point.

componenttext: Regarding the Delaware. You've given an outline of how you're going to spend in terms of drilling completions and IDPs. Would it be your best interest to own more infrastructure there so you don't have similar bottlenecks as you've had in the DJ with third-party GTB? Or you'll just kind of wind your business strategically like you did in the DJ and the Delaware?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I think when you look at it, there's probably more infrastructure closed with there in the basin then there was when we started in the DJ. That being said, I think as we continue to look at how to quit the most value both from integrating the s
componenttext: Yes, John, I think when you look at it, there's probably more infrastructure closed with there in the basin then there was when we started in the DJ. That being said, I think as we continue to look at how to quit the most value both from integrating the subsurface with the surface piece, especially as we start getting further into an IDP concept, we'll continue to look as to what makes sense from an overall facility structure.  I think this is all about going in and having a totally integrated plan, if you will, that includes everything from how you produce under the ground to how you market it on the surface.

componenttext: With the increase in Eagle Ford and Wolfcamp EURs, is there a reason the 100,000 Boe a day production target by 2018 is unchanged? Was improvement and recoveries already considered at the time of acquisition, or is it just conservatism around giving multi-year growth target?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've matched up the growth with the capital spend and the activity level. Again, you've got flexibility here as conditions change and more information's available to continue to update that. But what we're doing right now is honoring the activity level a
componenttext: We've matched up the growth with the capital spend and the activity level. Again, you've got flexibility here as conditions change and more information's available to continue to update that. But what we're doing right now is honoring the activity level and performance that we've input into the model to layout that 3-year program, along with the capital and cash flow that it provides. So we'll continue to that as we go. We're just 2 weeks into this since we've closed. But we're very excited about what we've got and where we're going.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then with minimal capital being allocated in Marcellus in the second half and likely to 2016 and the Noble having a deep portfolio of high return opportunities to allocate capital towards. How strategic is this asset to the company? And do we n
componenttext: Great. And then with minimal capital being allocated in Marcellus in the second half and likely to 2016 and the Noble having a deep portfolio of high return opportunities to allocate capital towards. How strategic is this asset to the company? And do we need to consider anything about the JV structure impacting a potential divestiture should you choose that route?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what we like about the Marcellus, it is still the premier gas play in the U.S. and when you look at the operational performance, it's been outstanding out there, but it's at operational performance across the industry that contributed to this supp
componenttext: I think what we like about the Marcellus, it is still the premier gas play in the U.S. and when you look at the operational performance, it's been outstanding out there, but it's at operational performance across the industry that contributed to this supply-demand imbalance. I think when you look about it though, you love having a high-quality asset, it's the premier asset, and it's mixed in the portfolio. And the optionality that, that gives you for the future with the tremendous amount of running room. The other thing that I think very nice about our position and same with the JV is the fact that it's all essentially held by production out there. So you have the flexibility to adapt to changing conditions and make sure that you're making smart decisions on how you create most value out of an asset like this.

componenttext: Yes. On the DJ Midstream. If I remember right and Ken will straight me out if I misquote this, right, but I think we've spend $500 million to $600 million invested in those assets so far.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
