headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Maybe if I could follow up on CapEx. Can you talk a little bit about the drivers of the lower CapEx level on this quarter? And then as you look at fourth quarter CapEx, is that kind of low-$600 million run rate, is that a reasonable run rate in tha
componenttext: Great. Maybe if I could follow up on CapEx. Can you talk a little bit about the drivers of the lower CapEx level on this quarter? And then as you look at fourth quarter CapEx, is that kind of low-$600 million run rate, is that a reasonable run rate in that kind of activity level in 2016, or should we expect negative or positive drivers one way or the other in the next year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at third quarter for this year, that's kind of an outcome of the way we set up the programs starting the year where we rapidly got in motion to bring down activity. And for example, in the DJ, we ramped down pretty quickly on a
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at third quarter for this year, that's kind of an outcome of the way we set up the programs starting the year where we rapidly got in motion to bring down activity. And for example, in the DJ, we ramped down pretty quickly on activity. We brought the Marcellus and that alignment with our partner in the Marcellus to bring down activity there. Start to see some of the roll off in getting to the completion of some of the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico projects. So not a huge surprise to us, I think the other element there though, we started to see actual cost per well come down pretty dramatically, too. So that factored in, too. I guess being a little ahead of where we expected to be by that time in the third quarter, and you're seeing all of that carry over into the fourth quarter. I think as far as read through the next year, I mean, it's still too early to give out any specifics. But I think as we mentioned earlier, we're going to be managing within cash flow for next year. We've got a lot of flexibility on activity levels, that probably the big swing pieces will be our onshore activity. And again, we'll focus that between what we just talked about in the Texas assets and the DJ Basin as to what's the right activity level there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe if you could talk broadly about your exploration strategy going forward. I mean, how much of the budget should we expect to see allocated exploration going forward? Should it be at similar level to 2015? I guess any of your comments
componenttext: Great. And then maybe if you could talk broadly about your exploration strategy going forward. I mean, how much of the budget should we expect to see allocated exploration going forward? Should it be at similar level to 2015? I guess any of your comments in terms of how that fits within a broader context to capital allocation over the next couple of years?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give you a few comments on how I see it, and Susan can maybe expand on how should we think about exploration in this environment. But it'll be a low level again next year. I think it was around 5% or so of our capital this year. I don't see it
componenttext: Yes, let me give you a few comments on how I see it, and Susan can maybe expand on how should we think about exploration in this environment. But it'll be a low level again next year. I think it was around 5% or so of our capital this year. I don't see it being much beyond that next year. The focus next year will probably be in the Gulf of Mexico as far as actual drilling activity. But then the rest of it is looking at how we build inventory right now. And let me ask Susan to just expand a little bit on her comments about this environment.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're really focused -- this is a great time to really be focused on getting the best quality portfolio that we can possibly get. Our -- we do expect that our percentage in terms of capital in 2016 might be a little higher than this year just because
componenttext: Yes, we're really focused -- this is a great time to really be focused on getting the best quality portfolio that we can possibly get. Our -- we do expect that our percentage in terms of capital in 2016 might be a little higher than this year just because the capital is down. We're drilling in the Gulf of Mexico a little bit, but not significantly. So it's really going to be focused on building the portfolio with real quality possibility.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good. Would that entail -- I mean, I guess, as you look forward, I mean there's a lot of people exiting offshore plays and Deepwater assets around the world. Would you guys look to take advantage in terms of increasing your exposure to longer-term resourc
componenttext: Good. Would that entail -- I mean, I guess, as you look forward, I mean there's a lot of people exiting offshore plays and Deepwater assets around the world. Would you guys look to take advantage in terms of increasing your exposure to longer-term resource and acreage going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. I think the advantage we have is we have an exploration staff that's had a tremendous amount of success in the past that gives us that capability right now where others may not have that, and I think that creates opportunity. I mean, when you
componenttext: I think so. I think the advantage we have is we have an exploration staff that's had a tremendous amount of success in the past that gives us that capability right now where others may not have that, and I think that creates opportunity. I mean, when you step back and look at it, we're benefiting from that capability with our 3 offshore assets now that are delivering tremendous margin and stability. So I think it's something we'll continue to look at, but I think you can do that in this environment at a relatively low cost versus what we've seen in the past few years.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll next go to Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll next go to Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about Israel. I appreciated your prepared remarks, Dave, but one question was, in terms of talking about an FID maybe 12 months from now on a project, can you delve a little bit deeper into what that mea
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about Israel. I appreciated your prepared remarks, Dave, but one question was, in terms of talking about an FID maybe 12 months from now on a project, can you delve a little bit deeper into what that means for -- is it one FID for both Leviathan and this perspective export project from Tamar? How are you thinking about the linkages or the de-linkages of those 2 projects? And if you could, any idea on kind of the timing between FID and kind of for sales from the project scope you're looking at?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. I think the nice part or one of the nice elements of this framework, it actually delinked Tamar and Leviathan. So we're actually looking at those as 2 separate FIDs. And the timing on Tamar is really going to be dependent on getting that cont
componenttext: Sure, Steve. I think the nice part or one of the nice elements of this framework, it actually delinked Tamar and Leviathan. So we're actually looking at those as 2 separate FIDs. And the timing on Tamar is really going to be dependent on getting that contract with the Union Fenose LNG facility hammered out and being able to move forward from that standpoint. Leviathan will be tied to getting its contracts lined out and then the project financing actually pulled together for both of those. I think when you look at actual first production, we've been talking 3 to 4 years from FID, the first production. There's probably an opportunity that Tamar's project could be probably a little quicker than Leviathan, but we'll just have to see how that plays out. The other thing we're keeping a close eye on to and I didn't really mention on the prepared comments, but just this interoperable volume to Egypt/is actually -- could be the first project to come online at very little low-cost to us, but significant from the standpoint of establishing an export arrangement between Israel and the neighboring country. So that's the other one more we're keeping an eye on as we're moving over the next few months, Steve.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just a quick follow-up on the Marcellus. I guess, one question, clearly that seems like an area just listening to your partner's remarks as well, that there's a place where we could see Noble just drawdown the inventory of the docks next year and l
componenttext: Great. Just a quick follow-up on the Marcellus. I guess, one question, clearly that seems like an area just listening to your partner's remarks as well, that there's a place where we could see Noble just drawdown the inventory of the docks next year and limit capital based on your view of higher returns elsewhere. I guess what would have to happen for you to change that view? Is it a question of is there are certain -- would a dollar higher gas price kind of make that project compete for returns elsewhere? If you can kind of size, what's the hurdle rate to get capital back into the Marcellus, I guess, is what I'm getting in?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we're well aligned with our partner to manage within cash flow. So obviously, every dollar gas price improvement helps the cash flow in that area and we'll continue to look at it. I think you're right from that standpoint that the plan goin
componenttext: Well, I think, we're well aligned with our partner to manage within cash flow. So obviously, every dollar gas price improvement helps the cash flow in that area and we'll continue to look at it. I think you're right from that standpoint that the plan going into next year, at least as we're both looking at it now, is to focus on completion activity and being pretty selective and judicial on how we manage that. And then we'll just have to keep watching the market. As we've talked about, this doesn't feel like the gas price to drill into in that market, but we'll just continue to watch how that changes. We've got tremendous amount of flexibility because the acreage is pretty much all held by production, which was another key advantage of the partnership when we got into that arrangement. So that just gives us a lot of flexibility to manage it, and we're well aligned with our partners. So that's a good position to be in going into the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Bob Brackett with Standford Bernstein.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Bob Brackett with Standford Bernstein.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got a question on the Texas assets. It looks like they were producing maybe 66,000 in 1Q and they're running at 54,000 for 3Q. What's causing that decline? Is that a drop in CapEx or a build in docks or something else?
componenttext: Got a question on the Texas assets. It looks like they were producing maybe 66,000 in 1Q and they're running at 54,000 for 3Q. What's causing that decline? Is that a drop in CapEx or a build in docks or something else?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob. I'll have Gary expand on that, but I tell you, it's right on track with what we projected when we modeled this for the acquisition. We fully expected the third quarter to be a low quarter, probably the low quarter for the year based on the way w
componenttext: Yes, Bob. I'll have Gary expand on that, but I tell you, it's right on track with what we projected when we modeled this for the acquisition. We fully expected the third quarter to be a low quarter, probably the low quarter for the year based on the way we saw activity shaping up, but Gary can give you some other color.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, it's tied to completion timing. You might remember that Rosetta's full year guidance for the assets was 60 for the year. They had it coming through the year. As Dave said, 3Q was always intended to be the low point of the year. So I'd say we're
componenttext: Yes, Bob, it's tied to completion timing. You might remember that Rosetta's full year guidance for the assets was 60 for the year. They had it coming through the year. As Dave said, 3Q was always intended to be the low point of the year. So I'd say we're right on track with what we've anticipated all along.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the only thing I was going to add, Bob, with what we've seen from the results of what we've focused on so far, I think we're in position and kind of our overall theme is to be able to do more with spending less out there as we've seen on both the initi
componenttext: So the only thing I was going to add, Bob, with what we've seen from the results of what we've focused on so far, I think we're in position and kind of our overall theme is to be able to do more with spending less out there as we've seen on both the initial wells out-of-the-box on drilling and then some of these initial completions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, efficiencies are definitely trending up better than we had modeled actually. If you'll recall that we, a few months ago, increased our type curve for the area. Our most recent wells in the Eagle Ford are exceeding even that increased type curve by 3%
componenttext: Yes, efficiencies are definitely trending up better than we had modeled actually. If you'll recall that we, a few months ago, increased our type curve for the area. Our most recent wells in the Eagle Ford are exceeding even that increased type curve by 3% to 5% at least. So we put a slide out there and had some commentary on a couple of the most recent wells. We think the one that's in early stages of flow back right now is probably the best well ever completed on the acreage. That's a result of bringing a lot of the completion design concepts that we refined in the DJ and the Marcellus to the Eagle Ford. So it's going to be interesting to see what we're able to do here in the next few months, I think.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think a rig in each basin will be enough to hold production flat?
componenttext: And do you think a rig in each basin will be enough to hold production flat?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's what we're going to start off. And I think with the drilling efficiencies that we're seeing, it's fair to model more wells per rig, certainly for '16 than what's been done in the past.
componenttext: I think that's what we're going to start off. And I think with the drilling efficiencies that we're seeing, it's fair to model more wells per rig, certainly for '16 than what's been done in the past.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, when you look at what we've laid out there, and consistent with starting off with the rig in each of those basins, we actually expect those volume will continue to grow. We don't see that 15% growth -- average growth over the next 3 years changi
componenttext: Actually, when you look at what we've laid out there, and consistent with starting off with the rig in each of those basins, we actually expect those volume will continue to grow. We don't see that 15% growth -- average growth over the next 3 years changing from what we've laid out in managing within cash flow. So nothing's changed on that. In fact, we're feeling even better about it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll know get next go to John Herrlin with Societe Generale.
componenttext: And we'll know get next go to John Herrlin with Societe Generale.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned savings that you're getting with things like slick water and you talked about improvements in the Eagle Ford, et cetera. What kind of well designs are you using very differently? Are you dropping intermediate strings of casing? Are you doing
componenttext: You mentioned savings that you're getting with things like slick water and you talked about improvements in the Eagle Ford, et cetera. What kind of well designs are you using very differently? Are you dropping intermediate strings of casing? Are you doing slide and sleeve, plug-and-perf, what's kind of different in your approach, if anything?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the DJ?
componenttext: In the DJ?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then the Eagle Ford.
componenttext: Yes, and then the Eagle Ford.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the DJ, slick water has been the biggest drivers so far of bringing those costs down. We are doing some mono bore completions like you've heard from others which allows you to drop that intermediate string of casings. So we're testing that to ensure th
componenttext: In the DJ, slick water has been the biggest drivers so far of bringing those costs down. We are doing some mono bore completions like you've heard from others which allows you to drop that intermediate string of casings. So we're testing that to ensure that we think that's a viable economic solution going forward, but we are doing some of that. In the Eagle Ford, most of the improvement has come on bringing again those same completion techniques from the Marcellus and the DJ. So reduced stage and cluster spacing. This most recent wells that we expect to be the best ever is a reduced stage and cluster spacing well, roughly 2,000 pounds of sand per foot, and like I said, performing very well. So we're continuing to test a number of things, but we seem to be on the right track.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. Next one for me on Israel, I know it's early, you're not at FID and all that. But in [indiscernible]   cost have to be coming down. Do you have any kind of a sense where things are now versus when you were looking a few years back.
componenttext: Great, thanks. Next one for me on Israel, I know it's early, you're not at FID and all that. But in [indiscernible]   cost have to be coming down. Do you have any kind of a sense where things are now versus when you were looking a few years back.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not yet. What we didn't want to do is get out ahead of ourselves on rebidding cost, so we'll get into that as we move through 2016. And that's when I'll start to have a real sense as to how much. I mean, you've got to believe when you look at the numb
componenttext: No, not yet. What we didn't want to do is get out ahead of ourselves on rebidding cost, so we'll get into that as we move through 2016. And that's when I'll start to have a real sense as to how much. I mean, you've got to believe when you look at the number of projects that have either been delayed or deferred, that the use of this equipment, which is a lot of a high-cost piece, lay vessels and so forth, is going to be coming down just based on usage. We know rig costs are down, way down from what we had, I'm sure, assumed originally when we put the estimates together. So you can see where the moving pieces ought to apply some downward pressure. But in totality, we won't have some real insight into that probably until mid-year or so.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll next go to Leo Mariani with RBC.
componenttext: We'll next go to Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had a question around the drilled on completed inventory. I think on your press release, you guys talked about 50 wells in Texas, 40 in the DJ and 80 in the Marcellus. I would -- I'm assuming that the Marcellus, obviously, is built up as a result of
componenttext: Just had a question around the drilled on completed inventory. I think on your press release, you guys talked about 50 wells in Texas, 40 in the DJ and 80 in the Marcellus. I would -- I'm assuming that the Marcellus, obviously, is built up as a result of dropping the rigs here. But just curious if sort of the Texas docks and the DJ are more normal course of business. Are you guys purposely trying to defer some of the completions here because of low-price environment? And are there kind of commodity price hurdles that you're hoping to hit before you start frac-ing these wells in each of the areas?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Leo, this is Gary. I'd say it's more normal course of business. We're not intentionally building up drilled and completed inventory in any area.
componenttext: Leo, this is Gary. I'd say it's more normal course of business. We're not intentionally building up drilled and completed inventory in any area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are there any commodity price hurdles that you guys are hoping to see in the Marcellus before you start bringing those wells online?
componenttext: Okay. Are there any commodity price hurdles that you guys are hoping to see in the Marcellus before you start bringing those wells online?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I think as Dave has mentioned, we're trending towards cash flow neutral for a budget for the Marcellus next year. That's kind of where we're seeing with our partners so we're taking that into account. Because we've laid down all the drilling ri
componenttext: Well, yes, I think as Dave has mentioned, we're trending towards cash flow neutral for a budget for the Marcellus next year. That's kind of where we're seeing with our partners so we're taking that into account. Because we've laid down all the drilling rigs. We've had some completion activity towards the end of this year, and then we'll have more completion activity next year versus drilling activity.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll just have to monitor that as we go relative to the price and the impact on cash flow, Leo.
componenttext: We'll just have to monitor that as we go relative to the price and the impact on cash flow, Leo.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess your costs were extremely low this quarter. You guys cited a 5-year record here. Just looking at your guidance, looks like you are expecting cost to uptick a little bit in the fourth quarter. Is something sort of going on there? Is it mo
componenttext: Okay. And I guess your costs were extremely low this quarter. You guys cited a 5-year record here. Just looking at your guidance, looks like you are expecting cost to uptick a little bit in the fourth quarter. Is something sort of going on there? Is it more just the function of being conservative? Can you kind of explain that a little bit?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you've got the mix. You have a much larger impact of the Gulf of Mexico, the new production coming in from the Gulf, which is at a little higher operating costs. You've got the Eastern Med dropping off significantly, seasonally, as it always does in
componenttext: Well, you've got the mix. You have a much larger impact of the Gulf of Mexico, the new production coming in from the Gulf, which is at a little higher operating costs. You've got the Eastern Med dropping off significantly, seasonally, as it always does in the fourth quarter, expected to. And those are probably the 2 main pieces, just those 2 mixes.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to really focus on the Appalachia, and it looks like you guys are pulling back on the Marcellus waiting for things to improve. And my question for you is how do you feel about the Utica? I noticed that you have a well in Marshall County, West Vi
componenttext: Yes, just to really focus on the Appalachia, and it looks like you guys are pulling back on the Marcellus waiting for things to improve. And my question for you is how do you feel about the Utica? I noticed that you have a well in Marshall County, West Virginia. I was just wondering, how much it costs at this stage? And then when do we really kind of need to treat the Utica dry gas as the next Marcellus?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a good question. Irene, on the last one, we just don't have that much history and that much Utica acreage to have a strong opinion on it relative to the Marcellus. I'll tell you, we'll start to get some insight from our own operations here as
componenttext: Well, that's a good question. Irene, on the last one, we just don't have that much history and that much Utica acreage to have a strong opinion on it relative to the Marcellus. I'll tell you, we'll start to get some insight from our own operations here as we bring our first Utica well on probably later this year. But then I think the real question on the Utica has been kind of the decline relative to the Marcellus, and as you referenced, the overall cost project at the deeper depths. So we don't have a big inventory. We've probably got probably 20,000 acres or so of Utica position that we've brought in along with our partners. We picked up additional acreage out in the basin, but we're probably in the early stages of us doing that.  Gary may have some other insights from his perspective.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, when Dave said 20,000 acres, that's gross. That's in the JV that we have an interest in. So our net, it's about half that, about 10,000 acres. We just drilled the one well, so I guess it's too early to speculate on what cost would be on the developme
componenttext: Yes, when Dave said 20,000 acres, that's gross. That's in the JV that we have an interest in. So our net, it's about half that, about 10,000 acres. We just drilled the one well, so I guess it's too early to speculate on what cost would be on the development-type scenario because we've done quite a bit of science on this first well, but we do expect to have it on here in the fourth quarter, and should be able to start talking about it a bit more in the next call next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: How much did you spend at this first well?
componenttext: How much did you spend at this first well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's in the $15-plus million range on this first well, but like I said, there's quite a bit of science in that one.
componenttext: It's in the $15-plus million range on this first well, but like I said, there's quite a bit of science in that one.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will look at that one as a development well scenario.
componenttext: I will look at that one as a development well scenario.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question with Michael Rowe with TPH.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question with Michael Rowe with TPH.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had one question about the DJ Basin. So you mentioned you're dropping a rig late in the latter part of this year, but you're drilling wells more quickly, and your anticipated well count's a bit higher for the year than budgeted. So can you just pro
componenttext: I just had one question about the DJ Basin. So you mentioned you're dropping a rig late in the latter part of this year, but you're drilling wells more quickly, and your anticipated well count's a bit higher for the year than budgeted. So can you just provide a little bit more context around kind of how the well counts going to change for the full year? And any changes to the capital budget for that region as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. It's Gary. I think it's -- again, it's driven by efficiency. So we've recently dropped to 3 rigs from 4. I don't see our latest guidance on well count changing that much given the increasing efficiency we continue to see. I think the last nu
componenttext: Yes, Michael. It's Gary. I think it's -- again, it's driven by efficiency. So we've recently dropped to 3 rigs from 4. I don't see our latest guidance on well count changing that much given the increasing efficiency we continue to see. I think the last numbers we put out there was about 200 wells, plus or minus actual well count and about 250 on an equivalent basis.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our change to DJ capital occurred first half of the year when we actually shifted some money into the DJ earlier in the year, and that turned out to be a pretty smart move with what we've seen from the impact with the Lucerne-2 plant coming on.
componenttext: I think our change to DJ capital occurred first half of the year when we actually shifted some money into the DJ earlier in the year, and that turned out to be a pretty smart move with what we've seen from the impact with the Lucerne-2 plant coming on.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then lastly, just on the Gulf of Mexico wells. These are obviously coming on line and adding quite a bit of production cash flow over the next 12 months. Can you just remind us kind of how we should think about the production profile and
componenttext: Okay, great. And then lastly, just on the Gulf of Mexico wells. These are obviously coming on line and adding quite a bit of production cash flow over the next 12 months. Can you just remind us kind of how we should think about the production profile and declines for these wells over the first, call it, 12 to 24 months?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say over the first 12 months, once you get them fully lined out here towards the end of November or so, I think they will hold pretty flat. I mean, there'll be some ups and downs, but they will hold pretty flat for the first 12 months. And then I
componenttext: Yes, I'd say over the first 12 months, once you get them fully lined out here towards the end of November or so, I think they will hold pretty flat. I mean, there'll be some ups and downs, but they will hold pretty flat for the first 12 months. And then I'd say decline from -- after the first year or so is probably 20% to 30% range. Now the nice part about it is that's not the end of the opportunity in that Rio Grande area because the one of the things we'll be looking at pretty hard over the first year is the potential based on production performance for another development well at Big Bend and also potential for water injection support going forward. So a lot of things still to look out there, and we see how it fully plays out.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Kelly with Seaport Global.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Kelly with Seaport Global.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: I was hoping to get a better understanding for Israel in 2016. Interested, if we'd assume similar weather next year versus '15, what organic growth could be: one, just no change to under the regulatory front; and two, if we do have a comprehensive agreement signed here for the next couple of weeks?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you're talking about volumes, I think we're going into next year, I think, it'll be relatively flat. We benefited this year from the fact that we had the compression project at ash dot that would fully up and running. And so we were able to take full a
componenttext: If you're talking about volumes, I think we're going into next year, I think, it'll be relatively flat. We benefited this year from the fact that we had the compression project at ash dot that would fully up and running. And so we were able to take full advantage of that this past quarter, and you can see the nice impact from that. I think the wildcard over there is if we can this interruptible supply agreement and actually start physically moving volumes from Israel to Egypt next year. We're not assuming anything for that at this point until it happens but that could be a significant opportunity.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: How quick could that be up and running there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think physically up and running, I think you could it in a matter of months. I think it's all a matter of getting the agreements finalized, getting both governments signed up and on board, and I know they're both very supportive from all discussions. An
componenttext: I think physically up and running, I think you could it in a matter of months. I think it's all a matter of getting the agreements finalized, getting both governments signed up and on board, and I know they're both very supportive from all discussions. And then getting all the agreements with the owners of the pipeline in place and gas moving. But as far as physical activity to move gas, it doesn't take much, I don't think.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: Okay, great. And my follow up is kind of longer term to look at, Leviathan and Tamar. I know there's a lot of moving parts and variables here, it might be way premature to ask this. But if you guys are thinking about this in terms of the potential internal NAV of these projects, how should we think about it? How really impactful could these projects be to you?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think if you just take a look and you model out the cash flows per year from the types of volumes when you look at, for Leviathan, adding over 1 BCF a day, we've talked about an average maybe 1.2 BCF a day or so forth when it's a fully up and running he
componenttext: I think if you just take a look and you model out the cash flows per year from the types of volumes when you look at, for Leviathan, adding over 1 BCF a day, we've talked about an average maybe 1.2 BCF a day or so forth when it's a fully up and running here in the initial phase, when you look at Tamar adding 400 million to 500 million cubic feet a day and you just model those cash flows out, it starts to give you an impression of how impactful those projects can be.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you, a macro and a micro. On the macro front, how closely linked in your mind are changes in commodity prices for changes in CapEx, so that's first. And then second on the micro front, just back up to the DJ and the slick water fracs. Ca
componenttext: Two questions for you, a macro and a micro. On the macro front, how closely linked in your mind are changes in commodity prices for changes in CapEx, so that's first. And then second on the micro front, just back up to the DJ and the slick water fracs. Can we think of applying this to the majority of the Wells Ranch wells and even at the longer lateral lengths? And maybe just talk about what's going on at East Pony on slick water versus Wells Ranch?

componenttext: Let me take the first one and I'll let Gary think the second part of that. But on the CapEx versus commodity price, I mean, they're linked from the standpoint of our focus, especially in these lower commodity price world of managing within cash flow. So it's going to be a direct linkage there between what commodity prices and how it impacts our cash flow, and therefore, what capital we invest, so...

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and on the slick water, how we roll that out. Like I said, we're focused on the Wells Ranch and East Pony right now, it seems to be working quite well on those areas. We'll continue to test it in those areas as where most of our activities going to b
componenttext: Yes, and on the slick water, how we roll that out. Like I said, we're focused on the Wells Ranch and East Pony right now, it seems to be working quite well on those areas. We'll continue to test it in those areas as where most of our activities going to be next year anyway. As far as the long laterals, we're certainly pumping slick water on long laterals, I would say, on the longest laterals, the 9,000-foot type wells, we're still pumping gelled hybrid in those first few stages and the toad just because if we have a screen out situation, it's a bit more problematic and costly to get those cleaned out. So we want to make sure we can carry the sand whole way, but otherwise, we're pumping slick water on the majority of those as well.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our quarterly earnings release and we also posted to our website a number of supplemental slides for this call. You will find them helpful as we talk to our
componenttext:
Thanks, Jamie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our quarterly earnings release and we also posted to our website a number of supplemental slides for this call. You will find them helpful as we talk to our prepared comments. Later this morning, our 10-Q will be available on the website as well. 
Following prepared comments, we'll open the call for question and answer and we'll complete in approximately an hour. [Operator Instructions] 
Management members participating today are Dave Stover, Chairman and CEO; Ken Fisher, Executive VP and CFO; Gary Willingham, Executive VP of Operations; and Susan Cunningham, Executive VP of Exploration and New Ventures. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in the latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We had a great quarter, and as you can see from our operating results, we were able to achieve more while spending less. Before discussing specific items, I want to take a moment
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We had a great quarter, and as you can see from our operating results, we were able to achieve more while spending less. 
Before discussing specific items, I want to take a moment to reflect on the quarter. First, I'm extremely pleased with the fact that we were able to significantly reduce capital and controllable cost while still delivering outstanding organic volume growth. Second, it is notable that discretionary cash flow was greater than our capital this quarter. And third, we saw continued capital efficiencies in our onshore program, supporting returns and margin improvements in the business. This all positions us extremely well for finishing the year strong and beginning 2016 even stronger. 
Starting the rest of our discussion with capital expenditures. We continue the trend of reducing our quarterly capital. This has come not only from adjusting our activity levels but also from our relentless focus on increasing operating efficiencies and driving down well cost. Capital expenditures for the third quarter were down approximately 20% from the second quarter of this year and 50% from the first quarter. This was accomplished despite the incremental capital allocated to our new Texas assets beginning this quarter. We've made great progress towards our goal of aligning capital with cash flows. Full year 2015 capital has now been reduced to slightly less than $3 billion, approximately $100 million under previous expectations. While working the capital side of the business, we've put an equal effort into bringing controllable unit cost down. We reduced third quarter lease operating expense and total production cost per barrel of oil equivalent to their lowest level in 5 years. These results have been delivered while maintaining a best-in-class safety record and the lowest recordable incident rate in our history. So I couldn't be more pleased with the efforts of our business units. 
Operationally, we've continued our tremendous momentum. Sales volumes for the third quarter totaled 379,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, substantially outperforming both original guidance and our raised expectations. I am pleased that each asset in the portfolio delivered higher volumes than our original forecast for the third quarter, and we're carrying that overall momentum into the fourth quarter. We have raised fourth quarter volumes now to range between 385,000 and 405,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
A major contributor to our performance has been the DJ Basin. The operating teams have done an amazing job enhancing value by realizing material efficiency gains, drilling longer laterals and improving completion techniques. Third quarter sales volumes averaged a record 116,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and total liquids production was a quarterly record as well, up 10,000 barrels per day from a year ago, most of which is crude volumes. 
This quarter, we saw the positive impact of the late June start-up of DCP's Lucerne-2-plant. Lower line pressures helped our legacy vertical production, which averaged 25,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day during the quarter. This is an increase of more than 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day above pre-Lucerne-2 rates. 
Additional infrastructure build-out continues with the Grand Parkway low-pressure line-loop system. This project is on schedule for start-up at the end of this year or early next year and will further improve gas infrastructure reliability in the basin. Drilling performance continues to be exceptional, and we have lowered spud-to-rig release time from standard lateral wells to between 5 and 6 days. Total well costs, including allocated facilities capital, are on track to be below $3.5 million in Wells Ranch for a standard lateral. We're also on track to be less than $3 million for a normalized long lateral. We've continued to modify completion techniques and we are seeing good success with slick water fluid completions in certain areas. 
On Slide 8, we have highlighted a recent development area, which includes our first slick water wells in Wells Ranch. Early results show strong production performance and lower overall well cost. During the quarter, we closed on the merger with Rosetta Resources, which established the new core operating positions for Noble Energy in the Eagle Ford and Delaware basins. While still early, initial results show that we are materially enhancing the value of these assets. Since closing, we drilled 7 lower Eagle Ford wells and 1 Delaware Wolfcamp A well. We have already substantially reduced spud-to-rig release times in both plays. In the Eagle Ford, spud-to-rig release times averaged 8 days for a 5,000-foot lateral, a reduction of approximately 30% from the average on these assets earlier this year. And our first operated well in the Delaware basin was drilled 10 days faster than the average of prior wells on our acreage. 
Production performance in the lower Eagle Ford remains very strong. We've highlighted on Slide 9 the 2 most recent well results, which are Noble Energy's initial, designed and executed completions in the Eagle Ford. They include modified completion designs versus the historical practice on these assets. Both wells are performing materially above the 3 million-barrel type curve for the area. In fact, the most recent wells, which is still in flow back, looks to be the best well ever completed on the acreage. 
These are strong and improving early results, highlighting the very productive nature of this acreage position and the value from Noble's technical expertise. Moving forward, we have plans to continue testing enhanced completion designs, including reduced stage and cluster spacing that we've brought from our other onshore plays. We anticipate a 1-rig program in the Eagle Ford and a 1-rig program in the Delaware as we exit this year. 
Now turning to our offshore operations. Both Big Bend and Dantzler recently commenced production. I want to commend our exploration, appraisal and development teams for their outstanding performance on this project. Delivering both fields ahead of schedule and on budget extends our exceptional track record of major project execution and highlights the competitive advantage for Noble. Production is quickly ramping to an expected combined gross maximum rate of over 40,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day or about 20,000 per day net to Noble. In fact, Big Bend is already tested close to full rate over the weekend, and Dantzler should ramp up quickly as well. These fields are major contributors to our fourth quarter and 2016 cash flow and oil volume growth. 
At Gunflint, the rig has completed drilling operations, and well completions are underway. Installation of pipelines and subsea equipment has begun. And first production remains on schedule for mid-2016. 
Moving to West Africa. Our operated projects at both Aseng and Alen continued to outperform internal estimates. The nonoperated Alba compression project, which will stem fill decline and extend productive resource life, advanced to over 80% complete and is on schedule for startup mid- next year. As expected, temporary Alba field shut-in while installing the compression module will result in a sizable impact to both first and second quarter 2016 sales volumes. 
On the exploration front. Our initial operated well offshore in the Falkland Islands provides substantial knowledge about the petroleum system. We will use well results to recalibrate the seismic interpretation. The Humpback play was just one of several play types across our vast 10 million acres. At the end of the year or beginning of next year, we will drill the Rhea prospect in the northern license area, which is adjacent to proven oil discoveries. Results should be available toward the end of the first quarter. 
In Israel, our natural gas sales averaged a record 305 million cubic feet of gas per day during the third quarter, an increase of 15% for the same period last year. For the month of August and most of September, the field averaged over 1 billion cubic feet per day, and stellar operational performance continued with nearly 100% uptime at the facilities. Marketing efforts in the Eastern Mediterranean continue where regional demand for our natural gas remains strong. 
The recent Egyptian discovery by another operator, which is targeted to domestic Egyptian use for power and industrials has heightened the interest in the basin. Regional customers remain undersupplied by almost 4 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day now, and we estimate that shortfall growing to 9 billion cubic feet per day by 2025. The proven reliability and performance at Tamar, along with the fully appraised and flow tested Leviathan field, have us well positioned to supply gas to this undersupplied region. 
During the third quarter, a number of significant steps were completed to provide a clear line of sight for the next round of project developments in the region. The regulatory framework for hydrocarbon development was finalized and approved by the Israeli cabinet and the Knesset. And the Israeli government is currently taking action to follow through on this framework. Yesterday's announcement from the Prime Minister's office is a further indication of the commitment to moving forward with gas development. 
So as we're approaching 2016, we intend to be cash flow neutral or better while maintaining long-term operational capacity. Our diversified portfolio provides exceptional investment optionality, and we will continue to be extremely disciplined and diligent in our capital allocation process. Next year's onshore capital program will again focus on those activities with the highest returns and value. Our positions in the DJ Basin and Texas should continue to attract the majority of our investment. Offshore capital will mainly be attributed to 1 rig -- to our 1-rig exploration and appraisal program in the Gulf of Mexico until Israel projects are sanctioned. While exploration capital will remain lower in 2016 than previous years, we believe this is a great environment to enhance and deepen our exploration inventory of high-quality opportunities at a relatively low cost of entry. Although production growth is not the focus, our 2016 volumes will likely be higher than pro forma 2015 levels. The momentum of our business can deliver this at significantly lower capital program within this year. As I mentioned at the beginning of my comments, we intend to continue achieving more while spending less. I believe we are well positioned to build a great future. With that, Jamie, I'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first call from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know it's early for the budget and I appreciate your comments earlier. Philosophically, how are you thinking about that budget in terms of what you're solving for? Right, I mean, your offshore startups, your DCs, your operational momentums, you clearly
componenttext: I know it's early for the budget and I appreciate your comments earlier. Philosophically, how are you thinking about that budget in terms of what you're solving for? Right, I mean, your offshore startups, your DCs, your operational momentums, you clearly have an ability to grow volumes within cash flow to strip. Are you looking to generate free cash flow into '16, or are you solving for more minimal operation capabilities to the trough? Any color there will be appreciated.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I appreciate, Evan. I think we're still in the early stages of finalizing the plans for next year. You've hit on a couple of the key elements. We are going to manage within cash flow, that's the way we're setting ourselves up. I think, at the same ti
componenttext: Yes, I appreciate, Evan. I think we're still in the early stages of finalizing the plans for next year. You've hit on a couple of the key elements. We are going to manage within cash flow, that's the way we're setting ourselves up. I think, at the same time, as you mentioned, we have a lot of flexibility, especially when you look at the overall portfolio. So I think as we look to next year, we're going to make sure we maintain our financial strength. We're going to make sure we allocate the capital to the projects with the greatest returns and value. And then at the same time, while we maintain the financial strength, we're going to watch and make sure we're keeping the operational capacity such that, as things do turn around and we get into a higher price environment, we're well positioned to be able to take advantage of that very quickly. So I think those are all some of the things that we think about as we're looking at next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe I could switch gears on Israel, and I appreciate your -- the macro demand commentary and the update. Once the framework is approved there, which could be any day, could you provide color on what happens next? I mean, where are you in the
componenttext: Great. And maybe I could switch gears on Israel, and I appreciate your -- the macro demand commentary and the update. Once the framework is approved there, which could be any day, could you provide color on what happens next? I mean, where are you in the process of Leviathan feed or Tamar expansion and any the range of potential capital spend there in 2016?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I think to start with, we'd still expect minimal capital spend in '16. The main pieces that will come together as you move forward with the framework, you have the contracts -- you have the actual contracts, the marketing arrangement, if you will,
componenttext: Right. I think to start with, we'd still expect minimal capital spend in '16. The main pieces that will come together as you move forward with the framework, you have the contracts -- you have the actual contracts, the marketing arrangement, if you will, moving those LOIs to executed contracts that will move forward. The same time, that will set up the opportunity to finalize financing. And in conjunction with all of that, we'll be going to back up to the market to bring in the new cost for the projects in the new market environment. So I think what we've continued to say is, now that the framework's been approved and moving forward with that, we've been looking at kind of a time frame of about 1 year to bring all of this together to move to FID.

componenttext: Yes, that's really on the full field. So it will be a mix of the full field impact. But that's as we expected, that's no different than what we've been planning for since we started the compression project. So that's all been accounted for in the way we have continued to look at '16 and...

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: Got it. That makes sense, and that's helpful. And then shifting back over to the DJ where you guys have had great results, particularly this last quarter. But the -- it's a little -- could you give us the narrative in your mind about how you progressed to the slick water fracs? And really, the -- I guess the question is, is this something that just works in the oil? Is it more appropriate for the more oil-rich areas, unless you guys really were really on this hybrid gel frac really because that what was typical for the field more in the gas center of it? Or how has this progression worked?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say, starting with -- I'm extremely pleased that the teams continues to look at what the next step and next evolution in development here. They're always kind of pushing the envelope and testing what could be even more efficient. I think I'll le
componenttext: Well, I'd say, starting with -- I'm extremely pleased that the teams continues to look at what the next step and next evolution in development here. They're always kind of pushing the envelope and testing what could be even more efficient. I think I'll let Gary kind of expand and talk about how they've thought through this process and how it applies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. We've talked about many times in the past how we're constantly looking for ways to improve our completions out there and also how we don't expect one optimal completion design to work across the entire field is likely to be different dependi
componenttext: Yes, Charles. We've talked about many times in the past how we're constantly looking for ways to improve our completions out there and also how we don't expect one optimal completion design to work across the entire field is likely to be different depending on where we're operating at any given time. So where we've been focusing the slick water completions most recently is in East Pony and Wells Ranch, which is the oiler part of the field. We haven't really had that much activity back in the core gassy part of Wattenberg recently. So too early to say whether slick waters might provide some benefit there in the future. Again, we're focused on Wells Ranch and East Pony right now. But we're seeing some very nice results. There's a slide in the pack that shows an area of Wells Ranch where we've got a number of slick water wells that are significantly outperforming the old hybrid gels in those areas. We're seeing similar results in East Pony, and we'll continue to test that as we go forward. And it also reduces our well cost by about $400,000 per well. So it's a good performance to-date.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: So a quick follow-up on that last question, if I may. So the slick water, I think you said in your commentary that there are some areas where you're choosing to move forward with that. What's the differentiating factors of why that wouldn't be deployed across the whole play? And I guess as an add-on, what are the implications for how we should think about the type curve that you've given us on those areas?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's just too early to say what other parts of the basin that will be applicable to, Doug. As you know, we like to move in a fairly measured approach as we test new completion techniques and like to show that it's repeatable before we just ma
componenttext: Yes, I think it's just too early to say what other parts of the basin that will be applicable to, Doug. As you know, we like to move in a fairly measured approach as we test new completion techniques and like to show that it's repeatable before we just make wholesale changes across the basin. So we'll continue to monitor these wells. We'll shift more activity in these specific areas, the slick water in the near future. But before we're ready to declare that's the right way to go across the basin, we'll just take a more measured approach to it. I think as far as the uplift, I think if you look at the performance on those wells on the slide for Wells Ranch, I'd say that the performance that we're seeing to date, no reason to suspect our near-term activity in Wells Ranch where we're using slick water that we'd see anything different than that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably a little early to get into too much of that. But we laid out at last call our initial look coming out of the box with Rosetta of how we would start to ramp up the Delaware basin over the next couple of years. The bigger ramp in Delaware
componenttext: Yes, it's probably a little early to get into too much of that. But we laid out at last call our initial look coming out of the box with Rosetta of how we would start to ramp up the Delaware basin over the next couple of years. The bigger ramp in Delaware, I think, really starts in 2017. But we'll be evaluating the -- both the returns and value add per incremental capital in each of those areas between -- especially between DJ, Eagle Ford and Permian, and it gives us a lot of flexibility now with all 3 of those assets that are performing very well.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll next go to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll next go to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Maybe if I could follow up on CapEx. Can you talk a little bit about the drivers of the lower CapEx level on this quarter? And then as you look at fourth quarter CapEx, is that kind of low-$600 million run rate, is that a reasonable run rate in tha
componenttext: Great. Maybe if I could follow up on CapEx. Can you talk a little bit about the drivers of the lower CapEx level on this quarter? And then as you look at fourth quarter CapEx, is that kind of low-$600 million run rate, is that a reasonable run rate in that kind of activity level in 2016, or should we expect negative or positive drivers one way or the other in the next year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at third quarter for this year, that's kind of an outcome of the way we set up the programs starting the year where we rapidly got in motion to bring down activity. And for example, in the DJ, we ramped down pretty quickly on a
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at third quarter for this year, that's kind of an outcome of the way we set up the programs starting the year where we rapidly got in motion to bring down activity. And for example, in the DJ, we ramped down pretty quickly on activity. We brought the Marcellus and that alignment with our partner in the Marcellus to bring down activity there. Start to see some of the roll off in getting to the completion of some of the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico projects. So not a huge surprise to us, I think the other element there though, we started to see actual cost per well come down pretty dramatically, too. So that factored in, too. I guess being a little ahead of where we expected to be by that time in the third quarter, and you're seeing all of that carry over into the fourth quarter. I think as far as read through the next year, I mean, it's still too early to give out any specifics. But I think as we mentioned earlier, we're going to be managing within cash flow for next year. We've got a lot of flexibility on activity levels, but probably the big swing pieces will be our onshore activity. And again, we'll focus that between what we just talked about in the Texas assets and the DJ Basin as to what's the right activity level there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe if you could talk broadly about your exploration strategy going forward. I mean, how much of the budget should we expect to see allocated exploration going forward? Should it be at similar level to 2015? I guess any of your comments
componenttext: Great. And then maybe if you could talk broadly about your exploration strategy going forward. I mean, how much of the budget should we expect to see allocated exploration going forward? Should it be at similar level to 2015? I guess any of your comments in terms of how that fits within a broader context to capital allocation over the next couple of years?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give you a few comments on how I see it, and Susan can maybe expand on how should we think about exploration in this environment. But it'll be a low level again next year. I think it was around 5% or so of our capital this year. I don't see it
componenttext: Yes, let me give you a few comments on how I see it, and Susan can maybe expand on how should we think about exploration in this environment. But it'll be a low level again next year. I think it was around 5% or so of our capital this year. I don't see it being much beyond that next year. The focus next year will probably be in the Gulf of Mexico as far as actual drilling activity. But then the rest of it is looking at how we build inventory right now. And let me ask Susan to just expand a little bit on her comments about this environment.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're really focused -- this is a great time to really be focused on getting the best quality portfolio that we can possibly get. Our -- we do expect that our percentage in terms of capital in 2016 might be a little higher than this year just because
componenttext: Yes, we're really focused -- this is a great time to really be focused on getting the best quality portfolio that we can possibly get. Our -- we do expect that our percentage in terms of capital in 2016 might be a little higher than this year just because the capital is down. We're drilling in the Gulf of Mexico a little bit, but not significantly. So it's really going to be focused on building the portfolio with real quality possibility.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: But would that entail -- I mean, I guess, as you look forward, I mean there's a lot of people exiting offshore plays and Deepwater assets around the world. Would you guys look to take advantage in terms of increasing your exposure to longer-term resource
componenttext: But would that entail -- I mean, I guess, as you look forward, I mean there's a lot of people exiting offshore plays and Deepwater assets around the world. Would you guys look to take advantage in terms of increasing your exposure to longer-term resource and acreage going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think so. I think the advantage we have is we have an exploration staff that's had a tremendous amount of success in the past that gives us that capability right now where others may not have that, and I think that creates opportunity. I mean, when you
componenttext: I think so. I think the advantage we have is we have an exploration staff that's had a tremendous amount of success in the past that gives us that capability right now where others may not have that, and I think that creates opportunity. I mean, when you step back and look at it, we're benefiting from that capability with our 3 offshore assets now that are delivering tremendous margin and stability. So I think it's something we'll continue to look at, but I think you can do that in this environment at a relatively low cost versus what we've seen in the past few years.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll next go to Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll next go to Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about Israel. I appreciated your prepared remarks, Dave, but one question was, in terms of talking about an FID maybe 12 months from now on a project, can you delve a little bit deeper into what that mea
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about Israel. I appreciated your prepared remarks, Dave, but one question was, in terms of talking about an FID maybe 12 months from now on a project, can you delve a little bit deeper into what that means for -- is it one FID for both Leviathan and this prospective export project from Tamar? How are you thinking about the linkages or the de-linkages of those 2 projects? And if you could, any idea on kind of the timing between FID and kind of for sales from the project scope you're looking at?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. I think the nice part or one of the nice elements of this framework, it actually delinked Tamar and Leviathan. So we're actually looking at those as 2 separate FIDs. And the timing on Tamar is really going to be dependent on getting that cont
componenttext: Sure, Steve. I think the nice part or one of the nice elements of this framework, it actually delinked Tamar and Leviathan. So we're actually looking at those as 2 separate FIDs. And the timing on Tamar is really going to be dependent on getting that contract with the Union Fenose LNG facility hammered out and being able to move forward from that standpoint. Leviathan will be tied to getting its contracts lined out and then the project financing actually pulled together for both of those. I think when you look at actual first production, we've been talking 3 to 4 years from FID, the first production. There's probably an opportunity that Tamar's project could be probably a little quicker than Leviathan, but we'll just have to see how that plays out. The other thing we're keeping a close eye on, too, and I didn't really mention on the prepared comments, but just this interoperable volume to Egypt/is actually -- could be the first project to come online at very little cost to us, but significant from the standpoint of establishing an export arrangement between Israel and the neighboring country. So that's the other one more we're keeping an eye on as we're moving over the next few months, Steve.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just a quick follow-up on the Marcellus. I guess, one question, clearly that seems like an area just listening to your partner's remarks as well, that there's a place where we could see Noble just draw down the inventory of the docks next year and
componenttext: Great. Just a quick follow-up on the Marcellus. I guess, one question, clearly that seems like an area just listening to your partner's remarks as well, that there's a place where we could see Noble just draw down the inventory of the docks next year and limit capital based on your view of higher returns elsewhere. I guess, what would have to happen for you to change that view? Is it a question of is there are certain -- would a $1 higher gas price kind of make that project compete for returns elsewhere? If you can kind of size, what's the hurdle rate to get capital back into the Marcellus, I guess, is what I'm getting in?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we're well aligned with our partner to manage within cash flow. So obviously, every $1 gas price improvement helps the cash flow in that area and we'll continue to look at it. I think you're right from that standpoint that the plan going in
componenttext: Well, I think, we're well aligned with our partner to manage within cash flow. So obviously, every $1 gas price improvement helps the cash flow in that area and we'll continue to look at it. I think you're right from that standpoint that the plan going into next year, at least as we're both looking at it now, is to focus on completion activity and being pretty selective and judicial on how we manage that. And then we'll just have to keep watching the market. As we've talked about, this doesn't feel like the gas price to drill into in that market, but we'll just continue to watch how that changes. We've got tremendous amount of flexibility because the acreage is pretty much all held by production, which was another key advantage of the partnership when we got into that arrangement. So that just gives us a lot of flexibility to manage it, and we're well aligned with our partners. So that's a good position to be in going into the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Bob Brackett with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question on the Texas assets. It looks like they were producing maybe 66,000 in 1Q and they're running at 54,000 for 3Q. What's causing that decline? Is that a drop in CapEx or a build in docks or something else?
componenttext: I have a question on the Texas assets. It looks like they were producing maybe 66,000 in 1Q and they're running at 54,000 for 3Q. What's causing that decline? Is that a drop in CapEx or a build in docks or something else?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob. I'll have Gary expand on that, but I'll tell you, it's right on track with what we projected when we modeled this for the acquisition. We fully expected the third quarter to be a low quarter, probably the low quarter for the year based on the wa
componenttext: Yes, Bob. I'll have Gary expand on that, but I'll tell you, it's right on track with what we projected when we modeled this for the acquisition. We fully expected the third quarter to be a low quarter, probably the low quarter for the year based on the way we saw activity shaping up, but Gary can give you some other color.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, it's tied to completion timing. You might remember that Rosetta's full year guidance for the assets was 60 for the year. They had it coming through the year. As Dave said, 3Q was always intended to be the low point of the year. So I'd say we're
componenttext: Yes, Bob, it's tied to completion timing. You might remember that Rosetta's full year guidance for the assets was 60 for the year. They had it coming through the year. As Dave said, 3Q was always intended to be the low point of the year. So I'd say we're right on track with what we've anticipated all along.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the only thing I was going to add, Bob, with what we've seen from the results of what we've focused on so far, I think we're in position and kind of our overall theme is to be able to do more with spending less out there as we've seen on both the initi
componenttext: So the only thing I was going to add, Bob, with what we've seen from the results of what we've focused on so far, I think we're in position and kind of our overall theme is to be able to do more with spending less out there as we've seen on both the initial wells out-of-the-box on drilling and then some of these initial completions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, efficiencies are definitely trending up better than we had modeled actually. If you'll recall that we, a few months ago, increased our type curve for the area. Our most recent wells in the Eagle Ford are exceeding even that increased type curve by 3%
componenttext: Yes, efficiencies are definitely trending up better than we had modeled actually. If you'll recall that we, a few months ago, increased our type curve for the area. Our most recent wells in the Eagle Ford are exceeding even that increased type curve by 3% to 5% at least. So we put a slide out there and had some commentary on a couple of the most recent wells. We think the one that's in early stages of flow back right now is probably the best well ever completed on the acreage. That's a result of bringing a lot of the completion design concepts that we refined in the DJ and the Marcellus to the Eagle Ford. So it's going to be interesting to see what we're able to do here in the next few months, I think.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think a rig in each basin will be enough to hold production flat?
componenttext: And do you think a rig in each basin will be enough to hold production flat?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's what we're going to start off. And I think with the drilling efficiencies that we're seeing, it's fair to model more wells per rig, certainly for '16 than what's been done in the past.
componenttext: I think that's what we're going to start off. And I think with the drilling efficiencies that we're seeing, it's fair to model more wells per rig, certainly for '16 than what's been done in the past.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, when you look at what we've laid out there, and consistent with starting off with the rig in each of those basins, we actually expect those volume will continue to grow. We don't see that 15% growth -- average growth over the next 3 years changi
componenttext: Actually, when you look at what we've laid out there, and consistent with starting off with the rig in each of those basins, we actually expect those volume will continue to grow. We don't see that 15% growth -- average growth over the next 3 years changing from what we've laid out in managing within cash flow. So nothing's changed on that. In fact, we're feeling even better about it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2015
